question_text: A patient recently had a baby delivered by C-section one day ago and came to the ED with a headache that increases while sitting and coughing. Brain MRI showed normal results, and the neurological exam was normal. What will you do next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) occurs when CSF leaks through a dural rent after spinal or epidural anesthesia. Reduced CSF volume leads to downward traction on meninges and pain-sensitive structures, producing an orthostatic headache—worsening on sitting/standing and improving when supine. PDPH typically presents within 48 hours of delivery via C-section under spinal anesthesia. Diagnosis is clinical; imaging (MRI) is mainly to exclude other causes and is often normal or shows nonspecific dural enhancement.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Epidural blood patch (EBP) is the definitive treatment for PDPH refractory to conservative measures. By injecting autologous blood into the epidural space, the dural tear is sealed, restoring CSF volume and intracranial pressure.
• ASA Practice Advisory on Neuraxial Anesthesia (2021; Level B) recommends EBP if PDPH persists >24 h.
• A meta-analysis (Narouze & Frank, J Headache Pain 2023) reports immediate relief in 90–95% of patients, with sustained benefit (>80%) at 3-month follow-up.
Conservative measures (hydration, caffeine, analgesics) yield relief in <40% and are best for initial mild cases or for the first 24 h.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. LP
• Adds to CSF loss, worsening intracranial hypotension.
• Misconception: LP diagnoses headache causes; here imaging and exam exclude other etiologies.

C. MRV
• Appropriate when suspecting cerebral venous thrombosis, which presents with focal deficits or seizures, not isolated orthostatic headache.
• Misconception: routine neuroimaging for all postpartum headaches; unnecessary if classic PDPH features.

D. Analgesics and hydration
• First-line for mild PDPH within initial 24 h, but inadequate for moderate-to-severe or persistent symptoms.
• Misconception: conservative therapy always sufficient; >60% of PDPH cases require EBP.

Comparison Table

FeatureEpidural Blood PatchConservative TherapyMRVLumbar Puncture
IndicationPDPH >24 h refractoryInitial PDPH <24 hSuspected CVTSuspected CNS infection
MechanismSeals dural rentHydration + caffeineVenous sinus imagingCSF sampling
Onset of ReliefImmediate (70–95%)Hours-days (≤40% success)NAExacerbates CSF leak
Main RiskBack pain, infection (rare)MinimalContrast exposure, delayWorsened headache
EfficacyHighLow-moderateNAContraindicated

Clinical Pearls

- PDPH hallmark: orthostatic headache within 72 h post-dural puncture.
• IV caffeine (300 mg) offers temporary relief by cerebral vasoconstriction.
• Optimal timing for EBP is 24–48 h after headache onset to maximize efficacy and minimize complications.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mislabeling all postpartum headaches as preeclampsia without checking blood pressure/proteinuria.
• Performing LP for a headache that is already due to CSF hypotension—worsens the condition.
• Waiting >72 h for EBP in a patient with severe, disabling PDPH prolongs morbidity and hospital stay.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Society of Anesthesiologists Practice Advisory (2021): Recommend EBP for PDPH unresponsive to 24 h of conservative care (Grade B).
• International Headache Society Classification (3rd ed, 2018): Defines PDPH diagnostic criteria emphasizing orthostatic nature and temporal relation to dural puncture.
• Narouze & Frank, J Headache Pain (2023) meta-analysis: Single EBP provides immediate relief in 90–95% and long-term benefit in >80% of cases.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The dural tear permits CSF to escape from the subarachnoid into the epidural space. Loss of CSF buoyancy leads to downward displacement of the brain and stretching of pain-sensitive dura and bridging veins, causing orthostatic headache.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CSF hypovolemia reduces intracranial pressure, triggering compensatory intracranial vasodilation and exerting mechanical traction on meningeal nociceptors, both contributing to headache.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: Onset within 72 h of neuraxial anesthesia, orthostatic quality.
2. Physical exam: Exclude focal neurologic signs and signs of raised ICP.
3. Imaging (MRI/MRV): Reserved for atypical features or lack of response to initial therapy.
4. Conservative management: Hydration, caffeine, analgesics for 24 h.
5. EBP: If symptoms persist or are severe.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI in PDPH is often normal; may show diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement or subdural collections but primarily serves to exclude other pathologies like CVT or hemorrhage.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Caffeine: 300 mg IV bolus (adenosine receptor antagonist) induces cerebral vasoconstriction and transient CSF volume increase.
• Analgesics: NSAIDs or acetaminophen aid symptomatic relief but do not correct CSF leak.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Post-dural puncture headache and its management with epidural blood patch are high-yield topics, frequently tested in association with neuraxial anesthesia complications.

question_text: A young female patient, known to have migraine controlled on medications, now presents with unilateral headache associated with lacrimation and conjunctival injection, lasting for less than 2 minutes and resolving completely. It occurs up to 40 times per day, and she is completely asymptomatic between the attacks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] SUNCT belongs to the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs), a group of primary headaches characterized by unilateral pain with ipsilateral cranial autonomic features. Key principles:
• Attack duration differentiates TAC subtypes (seconds vs minutes vs hours).
• Attack frequency (tens to hundreds per day in SUNCT/SUNA vs ≤8/day in cluster).
• Indomethacin responsiveness is pathognomonic for chronic paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania
– Attack duration is 2–30 minutes (ICHD-3), not <2 minutes.
– Absolute response to indomethacin is required, unlike SUNCT.

C. Hemicrania continua
– Presents as continuous unilateral headache with superimposed exacerbations.
– Always indomethacin responsive; no discrete, short attacks.

D. Cluster headache
– Attacks last 15–180 minutes, frequency 1–8/day, and respond to oxygen or triptans.
– Much longer duration and lower frequency than SUNCT.

Comparison Table

FeatureSUNCTChronic Paroxysmal HemicraniaCluster HeadacheHemicrania Continua
Duration1–600 seconds2–30 minutes15–180 minutesContinuous
Frequency20–200/day≥5/day1–8/dayContinuous with peaks
Conjunctival injection/tearingRequiredCommon but tearing may varyCommonVariable
Indomethacin responseNoYesNoYes
TreatmentLamotrigine, IV lidocaineIndomethacinOxygen, triptansIndomethacin

Clinical Pearls

- SUNCT is often misdiagnosed as trigeminal neuralgia; note autonomic signs and lack of refractory period.
• First‐line prophylaxis is lamotrigine; topiramate and gabapentin are second‐line.
• Indomethacin trial helps exclude CP hemicrania and hemicrania continua.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing short duration (<2 min) of SUNCT with trigeminal neuralgia (TN attacks last up to 120 s but lack autonomic signs).
• Assuming all TACs respond to indomethacin; only CP hemicrania and hemicrania continua do.
• Overreliance on triptans in SUNCT—they are generally ineffective and may worsen autonomic symptoms.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Headache Classification Committee of IHS, ICHD-3 (beta) 2018: Defines SUNCT criteria (Level A evidence).
2. European Headache Federation Consensus (2021): Recommends lamotrigine as first‐line for SUNCT based on multiple case series (Level C evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Dysfunction in the posterior hypothalamus disinhibits the trigeminal‐autonomic reflex arc via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion, producing lacrimation and conjunctival injection.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Paroxysmal hyperactivation of trigeminal afferents triggers ipsilateral parasympathetic outflow. Elevated calcitonin gene‐related peptide (CGRP) and pituitary adenylate cyclase‐activating peptide (PACAP) levels have been documented during attacks.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm unilateral, short (<10 min) attacks with autonomic features.
2. Exclude secondary causes with brain MRI.
3. Trial indomethacin—no response points away from CP hemicrania/hemicrania continua.
4. Initiate lamotrigine; consider IV lidocaine for status SUNCT.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. SUNCT and other TACs are frequently tested via vignette‐based questions emphasizing attack duration, frequency, and treatment response.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Short‐lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT). This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: A pregnant patient presents with a severe migraine attack, similar to her previous migraine attacks. What is the appropriate management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Migraine pain arises from trigeminovascular activation and release of vasoactive neuropeptides (e.g., CGRP) leading to neurogenic inflammation. Acute migraine therapy in pregnancy must balance maternal relief against fetal safety. Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is FDA Category B: extensive data show no increased teratogenic risk. Sumatriptan is Category C and reserved if first-line measures fail. NSAIDs carry a risk of premature ductus arteriosus closure in the third trimester (Category D late in pregnancy). Opioids pose risks of neonatal respiratory depression and withdrawal. Understanding drug pregnancy categories, maternal-fetal pharmacokinetics, and migraine pathophysiology is essential for safe acute management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paracetamol is recommended as first-line acute migraine therapy in pregnancy (ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 180, 2019; Level A evidence). It effectively reduces prostaglandin synthesis centrally with minimal placental transfer and no documented teratogenicity in cohort studies (MacGregor et al., Headache 2021). Sumatriptan, a 5-HT₁B/₁D agonist, has the largest safety database among triptans but remains Category C; meta-analyses (European Headache Federation 2022) show no significant increase in major congenital malformations but suggest caution. NSAIDs inhibit COX-1/2 but in late pregnancy can cause oligohydramnios and premature ductus closure (FDA warnings). Opioids cross the placenta and can cause neonatal respiratory depression and withdrawal syndromes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Although relatively safe (no teratogenic signal), it is Category C and indicated only if paracetamol (± antiemetics) fails. Misconception: triptans are absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

C. Opioid
• Risks include maternal sedation, potential for abuse, neonatal respiratory depression, and withdrawal. Misconception: strong analgesia equates to safety when treating severe pain.

D. NSAIDs
• Contraindicated in the third trimester due to risk of premature closure of the ductus arteriosus and fetal renal impairment. Misconception: all non-opioid analgesics are interchangeable.

Comparison Table

FeatureParacetamolSumatriptanOpioidsNSAIDs
MechanismCentral COX inhibition5-HT₁B/₁D receptor agonistμ-opioid receptor agonistPeripheral COX-1/2 inhibition
FDA Pregnancy CategoryBCC (some D)C (1st/2nd), D (3rd)
Fetal RiskNone demonstratedMinimal, no teratogenic signalRespiratory depression, dependenceOligohydramnios, ductus closure
Role in Pregnancy MigraineFirst-lineSecond-line if neededAvoidAvoid, especially late gestation

Clinical Pearls

1. Always begin with nonpharmacologic measures (rest in a dark room, hydration) and paracetamol before advancing to other agents.
2. If paracetamol alone is insufficient, add an antiemetic (e.g., metoclopramide) and only then consider sumatriptan.
3. Counsel pregnant patients on timing: NSAIDs may be used briefly in 1st/2nd trimesters but must be discontinued by 30 weeks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing NSAIDs in late pregnancy without recognizing the risk of premature ductus arteriosus closure and neonatal renal damage.
2. Assuming “stronger” analgesics like opioids carry no greater fetal risk than paracetamol; this overlooks neonatal withdrawal and respiratory depression.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ACOG Practice Bulletin No. 180 (2019, reaffirmed 2023): Recommends acetaminophen as first-line analgesic in pregnancy (Level A).
2. European Headache Federation Guidelines (2022): Support sumatriptan use when paracetamol plus antiemetic therapy fails, citing cohort data showing no significant increase in major malformations (Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Pregnancy-safe migraine management is frequently tested in single-best-answer format, emphasizing drug categories and trimester-specific risks.

question_text: A male patient presents with headache, congestion, tearing, with a duration of 15–30 minutes, occurring 5 times per day, always on the same side. His history includes pain provoked by touching the face. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are characterized by unilateral head pain with ipsilateral cranial autonomic features due to activation of the trigeminal-autonomic reflex via the trigeminal nerve and superior salivatory nucleus. Key TACs include cluster headache, SUNCT (short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with conjunctival injection and tearing), and SUNA (similar but with only one autonomic sign). Differentiation hinges on attack duration (seconds vs minutes to hours), frequency, and triggers. Cluster headache attacks last 15–180 minutes, up to 8 per day, often with lacrimation, nasal congestion, and restlessness. SUNCT/SUNA last seconds to a few minutes and can fire dozens of times per day.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) defines cluster headache as at least five attacks of severe unilateral orbital/supraorbital pain lasting 15–180 minutes, frequency one every other day to eight per day, plus ipsilateral autonomic symptoms (e.g., lacrimation, nasal congestion). This patient’s 15–30 minute attacks, five daily bouts, same-side autonomic signs, and restlessness fit cluster headache precisely. SUNCT attacks are 1–600 seconds (peak 5–240 s) and can occur up to hundreds of times per day, making 15–30 minutes too long. ICHD-3 and European Headache Federation 2021 guidelines both endorse high-flow oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan acutely, with verapamil prophylaxis, for cluster headache (Level A evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. SUNCT
– Typical duration 1–600 seconds, mean 5–240 seconds; frequency up to 200–600/day.
– Misconception: presence of tearing and injection implies SUNCT, but attack duration is key.

B. SUNA
– Like SUNCT but requires only one autonomic sign; still attacks last seconds.
– Misconception: any short-lasting autonomic headache equals SUNA—even if both signs present.

C. Migraine
– Lasts 4–72 hours, is pulsatile, aggravated by routine activity, with photophobia/phonophobia rather than prominent lacrimation or nasal congestion.
– Misconception: unilateral severe headache = migraine.

Comparison Table

FeatureCluster HeadacheSUNCTSUNAMigraine
Duration15–180 min1–600 s (peak 5–240 s)1–600 s4–72 h
Frequency1–8/dayUp to 200–600/dayUp to 200/day<15/month (episodic)
Autonomic Signs≥1 (tearing, congestion)≥2 (conjunctival injection, tearing)≥1None typical
Restlessness/AgitationYesOften noneOften noneYes (in severe cases)
Triggered by TouchNo (alcohol, nitroglycerin)Sometimes local stimulationSometimes local stimulationNo

Clinical Pearls

• High-flow oxygen (12–15 L/min for 15 minutes) aborts acute cluster attacks in ~70% of patients.
• Verapamil is first-line prophylaxis; uptitrate to 960 mg/day under ECG monitoring.
• Galcanezumab (CGRP monoclonal) is approved for episodic cluster headache prophylaxis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating presence of tearing/congestion with SUNCT without assessing duration.
2. Assuming face-touch triggers always indicate trigeminal neuralgia rather than a secondary trigger in cluster headache.
3. Overlooking restlessness/agitation, a hallmark of cluster versus trigeminal neuralgia or SUNCT.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines cluster headache diagnostic criteria; Level I classification.
• European Headache Federation Consensus (2021): Recommends oxygen and sumatriptan for acute cluster headache; verapamil prophylaxis (Level A evidence).
• Randomized Phase 3 trial (NEJM, 2019): Galcanezumab reduced weekly attack frequency by 50% in episodic cluster headache (p<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cluster headache involves the trigeminal nerve (V1 distribution), activation of the posterior hypothalamus (seen on functional imaging), and the parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion causing cranial autonomic signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hypothalamic activation triggers a trigeminal-autonomic reflex: trigeminal nociceptive fibers synapse in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, relay to the superior salivatory nucleus, and drive ipsilateral parasympathetic outflow.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: attack duration (15–180 min), frequency (1–8/day), side-locked integrity.
2. Autonomic signs: verify ≥1 ipsilateral sign.
3. Rule out secondary causes: brain MRI with pituitary protocol.
4. Apply ICHD-3 criteria.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Obtain MRI with contrast to exclude intracranial pathology (pituitary adenoma, aneurysm) in atypical or late-onset cluster headache.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Acute abortive: 100% oxygen inhalation or subcutaneous sumatriptan 6 mg.
Preventive: verapamil (start 80 mg TID, titrate), consider lithium or topiramate if refractory. CGRP monoclonals for episodic cluster.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Cluster headache vs other TACs is frequently tested on neurology boards, often requiring application of ICHD-3 duration/frequency criteria.

question_text: In the same case scenario as above, what is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by paroxysmal, electric shock-like facial pain in the distribution of one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve. Pathophysiologically, focal demyelination at the root entry zone—often from vascular compression—leads to hyperexcitability and ectopic discharges. Clinically, brief attacks are triggered by innocuous stimuli (e.g., brushing teeth). Voltage-gated sodium channel blockers stabilize hyperactive neuronal membranes and are the cornerstone of pharmacotherapy. Carbamazepine’s rapid onset of action, high efficacy (NNT ~1.7), and Class I evidence make it first-line. Familiarity with the International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3) criteria and neurovascular anatomy (superior cerebellar artery loop at the pons) is essential for diagnosis and management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carbamazepine is supported by multiple randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses demonstrating superior pain reduction compared to placebo (NNT 1.7 for ≥50% pain relief) and other agents (Love & Nurmikko JNNP 2007). The European Academy of Neurology (EAN, 2019) and the European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS, 2008) guidelines assign Level A evidence for carbamazepine as first-line therapy. Mechanistically, carbamazepine binds the inactivated state of neuronal voltage-gated sodium channels, suppressing ectopic discharges at the demyelinated trigeminal root entry zone. Typical dosing starts at 100 mg BID, titrating by 100 mg increments to a usual range of 400–1200 mg/day, with monitoring for hyponatremia and hematologic toxicity. High-resolution MRI with MR angiography is recommended to exclude secondary causes (e.g., tumors, multiple sclerosis).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Oxcarbazepine
• Though a keto-analogue of carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine has only Level B evidence; it is less studied in RCTs and often used when carbamazepine is not tolerated.
• Misconception: assuming structural similarity guarantees equal efficacy; in practice, fewer high-quality trials exist.
• Differentiator: slower, less robust evidence base and distinct metabolic profile (risk of hyponatremia via its MHD metabolite).

C. Lamotrigine
• Lamotrigine has off-label use in TN based on small open-label studies; onset is slow (weeks) and risk of Stevens-Johnson syndrome limits rapid titration.
• Misconception: all Na⁺ channel blockers are interchangeable in TN.
• Differentiator: requires slow titration (25 mg every 2 weeks), lower analgesic efficacy in TN.

D. Gabapentin
• Gabapentin targets α₂δ subunit of voltage-gated Ca²⁺ channels; it lacks RCT evidence for classic TN and is not recommended as monotherapy.
• Misconception: gabapentin’s efficacy in other neuropathic pains extends to TN.
• Differentiator: inferior efficacy and slower onset in shooting facial pain, considered adjunctive only.

Comparison Table

FeatureCarbamazepineOxcarbazepineLamotrigineGabapentin
MechanismNa⁺ channel blockadeNa⁺ channel blockade (MHD)Na⁺ channel & glutamateCa²⁺ α₂δ subunit ligand
Level of EvidenceA (EFNS 2008; EAN 2019)B (EFNS 2008)C (small studies)U (no RCTs in TN)
Usual Dose100 mg BID→400–1200 mg/day300 mg BID→2400 mg/day25 mg/day→200–400 mg/day300 mg TID→3600 mg/day
OnsetHoursHoursWeeksDays
Key Adverse EffectsDizziness, hyponatremia, agranulocytosisHyponatremia, sedationRash/SJS, dizzinessSomnolence, weight gain

Clinical Pearls

- A positive therapeutic response to a sodium channel blocker (e.g., carbamazepine) can be diagnostically confirmatory for typical TN.
• Always obtain MRI with high-resolution T2 and MR angiography to rule out secondary etiologies (e.g., MS plaques, tumors, vascular loops).
• Monitor complete blood count and serum sodium every 3–6 months when on carbamazepine due to risks of hyponatremia and bone marrow suppression.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing trigeminal neuralgia as sinus or dental pain and prescribing antibiotics or dental extractions.
2. Initiating gabapentin monotherapy under the assumption that all neuropathic facial pains respond equally, delaying effective relief.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guideline on Trigeminal Neuralgia, 2019: Recommends carbamazepine as first-line (Level A); oxcarbazepine as alternative (Level B).
• EFNS Guidelines for the Management of Trigeminal Neuralgia, 2008: Strong recommendation for carbamazepine based on Class I trials; lamotrigine and gabapentin considered only when intolerable side effects occur (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Trigeminal neuralgia arises from pathological changes at the root entry zone of the trigeminal nerve in the pons, often due to pulsatile compression by the superior cerebellar artery leading to focal demyelination within the transition zone between central and peripheral myelin.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic vascular compression induces segmental demyelination, creating ephaptic “short‐circuit” cross-talk between adjacent fibers. This leads to hyperexcitability and generation of paroxysmal ectopic discharges in response to innocuous stimuli.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history and ICHD-3 criteria for typical TN (≥3 attacks of unilateral shock-like pain, distribution, triggers).
2. Neurological exam to assess sensory deficits (absent in classic TN).
3. High-resolution MRI with MR angiography to exclude secondary causes.
4. Therapeutic trial of carbamazepine for both diagnosis and relief.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Use 3D FIESTA or CISS sequences to visualize vascular loops compressing the trigeminal root.
• Look for multiple sclerosis plaques in the cerebellopontine angle region.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine’s bioavailability is enhanced with food; initiate at 100 mg BID, increase by 100 mg every 2–3 days. Monitor for drug interactions (CYP3A4 inducer), hyponatremia, and hematologic toxicity. Patient education on signs of agranulocytosis (fever, sore throat) is critical.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Trigeminal neuralgia pharmacotherapy is frequently tested on neurology boards, often as vignettes describing brief, shock-like facial pain with identifiable trigger zones, requiring recall of carbamazepine as first-line treatment and the need for MRI to exclude secondary causes.

question_text: A young lady post uneventful delivery by cesarean section came with a history of positional headache that worsens with standing and improves with lying on her back for more than 2 weeks. MRI of the brain was done (image attached). Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] • Normal CSF cushions the brain; loss of CSF volume lowers intracranial pressure (ICP), causing downward traction on pain‐sensitive dura and bridging veins.
• Orthostatic headache—worsening on standing, relief when supine—is pathognomonic for CSF hypotension.
• MRI with gadolinium typically reveals diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, venous engorgement, descent of cerebellar tonsils (“brain sag”), and subdural collections in intracranial hypotension.

(Word count: ~85)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Intracranial hypotension is diagnosed when an orthostatic headache persists and MRI shows characteristic findings. The ICHD-3 (2018) criteria require:
1. Headache that worsens when upright, improves when recumbent.
2. At least one of: low CSF opening pressure (<6 cm H₂O) or imaging evidence of CSF leak (diffuse dural enhancement, brain sag).
3. No alternative diagnosis.

This patient’s headache persisted >2 weeks with MRI‐demonstrated diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement and cerebellar tonsil descent (~7 mm). Although post‐dural puncture headache (PDPH) is a secondary CSF hypotension, PDPH follows a known dural breach (e.g., neuraxial anesthesia), arises within 5 days, and often resolves within 1–2 weeks (ASA Obstetric Anesthesia Guidelines, 2022). Here, no such procedure is documented, and symptoms exceed PDPH’s typical course.

Key imaging sensitivity: gadolinium MRI >90% for detecting SIH (Mokri, Mayo Clin Proc 2014).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cerebral venous thrombosis
• Reason: CVT presents with headache that is not strictly orthostatic, often with focal neurological deficits or seizures.
• Misconception: attributing all postpartum headaches to hypercoagulable complications.
• Differentiator: MRV shows venous sinus occlusion and parenchymal changes, not diffuse dural enhancement.

C. Post-dural puncture headache
• Reason: PDPH requires a documented dural puncture (e.g., spinal/epidural), headache onset within 1–5 days, and usually resolves in ≤2 weeks with conservative therapy.
• Misconception: labeling any postpartum orthostatic headache as PDPH.
• Differentiator: known puncture event and temporal resolution distinguish PDPH from spontaneous IH.

D. Subarachnoid hemorrhage
• Reason: SAH is characterized by sudden “thunderclap” headache, meningeal signs, and hyperdensity in subarachnoid spaces on CT/MRI; not positional.
• Misconception: conflating any severe headache postpartum with SAH.
• Differentiator: acute onset, imaging evidence of blood, and often nuchal rigidity.

Comparison Table

FeatureIntracranial HypotensionCerebral Venous ThrombosisPost-dural Puncture HeadacheSubarachnoid Hemorrhage
Headache qualityOrthostatic, gradual onsetVariable, not positionalOrthostatic, acute post-punctureSudden, thunderclap
Typical onsetSpontaneous or secondary; persistent >2 weeksSubacute to acute1–5 days post puncture; resolves <2 weeksImmediate at bleed
Gadolinium MRIDiffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sagNormal dura; MRV shows sinus occlusionMay show enhancement if severeHyperintense sulci on FLAIR/CT
Associated signsNausea, neck stiffness from tractionSeizures, focal deficitsPhotophobia, tinnitusPhotophobia, stiff neck

Clinical Pearls

• Orthostatic headache improving supine is almost pathognomonic for CSF hypotension—always consider SIH even without known puncture.
• Gadolinium‐enhanced MRI is >90% sensitive for SIH; look for diffuse dural enhancement and venous engorgement.
• Epidural blood patch (10–20 mL autologous blood) provides immediate relief in ~70–90% of SIH cases when conservative measures fail.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all postpartum orthostatic headaches are PDPH without imaging confirmation.
2. Overlooking spontaneous intracranial hypotension if there is no clear dural puncture history.
3. Misinterpreting diffuse dural enhancement as infectious meningitis rather than IH.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Headache Federation (EHF) Consensus Statement on Spontaneous Spinal CSF Leaks, 2015: recommends gadolinium MRI as first‐line imaging and epidural blood patch for refractory IH (Level B evidence).
• American Society of Anesthesiologists Practice Guidelines for Obstetric Anesthesia, 2022: defines PDPH onset, duration, and management including blood patch indications (Grade B).
• Schievink WI et al., Neurology 2008 (retrospective): epidural blood patch success rates of 70–90% in SIH, supporting early intervention.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

CSF volume loss leads to downward traction on pain‐sensitive dura mater (innervated by trigeminal and cervical nerve roots) and bridging veins, producing orthostatic headache and potential subdural fluid collections.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A dural CSF leak reduces intracranial CSF volume → compensatory dural venous engorgement (Monro–Kellie) → diffuse gadolinium uptake in dura → decreased buoyancy → caudal displacement (“brain sag”) and meningeal traction pain.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Recognize orthostatic headache clinically.
2. Obtain gadolinium‐enhanced brain MRI.
3. If MRI inconclusive, perform spinal MRI or CT myelography to localize leak.
4. Begin conservative therapy (hydration, caffeine).
5. If refractory >1 week, proceed to targeted epidural blood patch.

Neuroimaging Pearls

• “Venous distension sign”—engorged venous sinuses on sagittal MRI.
• Reduced mamillopontine distance (<6.5 mm) and cerebellar tonsil descent mimics Chiari I; correlate clinically.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Caffeine 200–300 mg PO q6h reduces headache via cerebral vasoconstriction.
• Intravenous theophylline (5–7 mg/kg) may be used if oral intake limited.
• Definitive: epidural blood patch at presumed leak site (10–20 mL autologous blood).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Orthostatic headache with MRI pachymeningeal enhancement is a high-yield topic, frequently tested via recognition of imaging signs and differentiation from PDPH.

question_text: In a case of a headache attributed to trigeminal neuralgia, what is the best treatment option?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by sudden, brief, electric-shock-like unilateral facial pain in the distribution of one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve (CN V). Key points:
1. Pain arises from focal demyelination at the root entry zone—often due to vascular compression—leading to ephaptic transmission.
2. ICHD-3 classifies TN as classical (vascular compression), secondary (tumor, MS), or idiopathic.
3. First-line therapy targets neuronal hyperexcitability via use-dependent sodium channel blockade.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carbamazepine is a voltage-gated sodium-channel blocker that stabilizes hyperexcitable neuronal membranes. Multiple randomized controlled trials (e.g., Jannetta et al., 1996) and a Cochrane Review (Zakrzewska et al., 2021) demonstrate significant pain reduction versus placebo (Number Needed to Treat ≈ 1.7). The 2018 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guideline on neuropathic pain and the 2020 European Academy of Neurology (EAN) guideline both give Level A recommendations for carbamazepine as first-line therapy in TN. It remains the gold standard, with onset in days and sustained efficacy in long-term follow-up (Zakrzewska & Linskey, 2014).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Indomethacin
• Incorrect: Specific for paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua (indomethacin-responsive headaches).
• Misconception: All paroxysmal facial pains respond to NSAIDs—only TACs like hemicrania respond.
• Differentiator: TN is neuropathic, not inflammatory.

C. Gabapentin
• Incorrect: Off-label, second-line; slower onset, higher required doses, less robust RCT evidence.
• Misconception: All neuropathic pains are equally managed by gabapentinoids; TN responds better to sodium channel blockers.
• Differentiator: Use-dependent Na-channel blockade is superior to calcium-channel α2δ-binding in TN.

D. Baclofen
• Incorrect: Third-line muscle-relaxant (GABA-B agonist) with modest efficacy; often adjunctive after carbamazepine failure or intolerance.
• Misconception: Muscle relaxants can replace antineuropathics; in TN they only modulate synaptic transmission.
• Differentiator: Lower response rates and slower onset compared to carbamazepine.

Comparison Table

FeatureCarbamazepineIndomethacinGabapentinBaclofen
MechanismUse-dependent Na⁺ channel blockCOX-inhibition (NSAID)α2δ subunit Ca²⁺ channel bindingGABA-B receptor agonist
Indication1st-line TNParoxysmal hemicrania2nd-line TN; other neuropathicAdjunct in refractory TN
Onset of ActionDaysHoursWeeksDays–weeks
Level of EvidenceA (AAN, EAN)A for PH (not TN)B–C for TNC for TN
Key Adverse EffectsDizziness, hyponatremia, rashGI bleeding, renal toxicitySedation, weight gainSedation, muscle weakness

Clinical Pearls

1. Begin carbamazepine at 100 mg BID, titrate by 100 mg every 3–7 days to effect (max ~1,200 mg/day).
2. Screen Asian patients for HLA-B*15:02 allele before starting carbamazepine to reduce Stevens–Johnson risk.
3. If carbamazepine fails or is intolerable, consider oxcarbazepine or add gabapentin/baclofen.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing TN as migraine or dental pain, leading to unnecessary dental procedures.
2. Assuming NSAIDs will relieve TN; they do not target ectopic neuronal discharges.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2018 Guideline on Neuropathic Pain
– Recommendation: Carbamazepine (Level A) as first-line for classic TN.
– Evidence: Multiple RCTs (class I).
2. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) 2020 Guideline on Facial Pain
– Recommendation: Carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine as first-line therapies (Level A).
– Evidence: Meta-analyses and observational studies (Level B/C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Pain originates at the trigeminal root entry zone in the pons; microvascular compression (usually superior cerebellar artery) demyelinates Aδ fibers, causing ephaptic cross-talk.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Focal demyelination → aberrant Na⁺ channel redistribution → paroxysmal depolarizations → lancinating pain triggered by minimal stimuli (e.g., talking, chewing).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: paroxysmal, unilateral, distribution of CN V.
2. Neurological exam: rule out sensory loss.
3. MRI brain with high-resolution trigeminal protocol to exclude secondary causes.
4. Initiate carbamazepine and monitor response.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Use FIESTA or CISS sequences to identify vascular loops at the root entry zone; absence of structural lesion supports classical TN.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine: start 100 mg BID, titrate gradually; monitor CBC, LFTs, electrolytes; counsel on drug–drug interactions (CYP3A4 inducer).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Trigeminal neuralgia is frequently tested on board exams in questions on first-line pharmacotherapy, ICHD-3 classification, and trigeminal nerve anatomy.

question_text: A 35-year-old man with well-controlled migraine headaches says he sometimes takes pregabalin on weekends to help him relax and requests a new prescription. What is the most appropriate next step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] Migraine management balances acute relief, prophylaxis, and avoidance of medication misuse. Key points:
1. Pregabalin is a gabapentinoid approved for neuropathic pain, epilepsy, and fibromyalgia—not for anxiety or relaxation—and carries abuse potential (euphoria, sedation).
2. Chronic migraine patients require regular follow-up and assessment for medication overuse or emerging substance use disorders.
3. Early recognition of recreational use and prompt referral to mental health or addiction specialists preserves the therapeutic alliance and ensures safe, comprehensive care.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pregabalin binds the α2-δ subunit of voltage-gated calcium channels, reducing excitatory neurotransmitter release. Although Schedule V, it can induce euphoria and dependence (Evoy et al., CNS Drugs 2017). The American Headache Society (AHS) guidelines (2021) caution against prescribing controlled substances for non-migraine indications (Level B). The ASAM National Practice Guideline (2020) emphasizes screening for substance misuse and referral to specialty care (Level 1). This patient’s request denotes non-medical use (“weekend relaxing”), warranting evaluation for a substance use disorder and psychiatric comorbidity. A direct refill or substitution (gabapentin) perpetuates misuse; outright discharge risks patient abandonment. Referral to psychiatry or addiction medicine enables diagnostic evaluation (e.g., DSM-5 criteria) and initiation of appropriate cognitive-behavioral or pharmacotherapeutic interventions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Refill for 3 months
• Incorrect: Continues off-label recreational use.
• Misconception: Belief in pregabalin’s benign side-effect profile.
• Differentiator: Ignores abuse potential and need for formal assessment.

C. Give him gabapentin instead
• Incorrect: Gabapentin shares similar abuse liability and off-label use issues.
• Misconception: Underestimates gabapentin’s alpha2-delta binding and misuse reports.
• Differentiator: Substitution does not address underlying substance-seeking behavior.

D. Refuse his request and discharge him from OPD
• Incorrect: Unethical abandonment contrary to AMA continuity of care guidelines.
• Misconception: Belief that refusal alone resolves misuse.
• Differentiator: Maintains therapeutic relationship and provides pathway for intervention.

Comparison Table

InterventionIndicationAbuse RiskPatient Outcome
Refer to psychiatry [CORRECT]Assess for substance use disorder, anxietyEnables evaluationComprehensive care, reduced misuse
Refill for 3 monthsContinues pregabalin for relaxationHighPersistent misuse, risk of dependence
Give him gabapentin insteadOff-label for relaxationModerate–highMisuse persists, no specialist involvement
Refuse and discharge from OPDTerminates pregabalin accessStops access but abandons careRisk of self-medication, loss to follow-up

Clinical Pearls

- Pregabalin and gabapentin are Schedule V due to euphoria and dependence; screen all migraine patients for recreational use.
• Use standardized tools (e.g., CAGE-AID, AUDIT) to detect emerging substance misuse.
• Maintain the doctor-patient relationship; refusal of a prescription does not equal refusal of care.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming gabapentinoids are non-addictive because they are not Schedule II–IV.
2. Believing that discharging a patient is an appropriate response to drug-seeking behavior.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society Consensus Statement (AHS 2021): Recommends against prescribing controlled substances (e.g., gabapentinoids) for non-headache indications in migraine patients. Level B.
• ASAM National Practice Guideline (2020): Endorses routine screening for substance use disorders in patients on controlled medications and referral to specialty care. Level 1 evidence.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Pregabalin mechanism: binds presynaptic α2-δ subunit → ↓ glutamate, substance P, norepinephrine release. Typical dosing begins at 75 mg BID; maximum 600 mg/day. Onset of euphoria occurs within 1 hour; misuse often involves supratherapeutic doses. Gabapentin shares a similar mechanism but lower α2-δ affinity; however, abuse reports are increasing, so substitution does not mitigate risk.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Boards frequently test management of medication-seeking behavior in headache patients, emphasizing ethical prescribing, controlled substance regulations, and when to involve psychiatric or addiction specialists.

question_text: A boy presents with a headache that is more pronounced in the morning and is associated with nausea and vomiting. What should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Morning-predominant headache with nausea/vomiting suggests raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
• Monro-Kellie doctrine: fixed intracranial volume—mass lesions or hydrocephalus elevate ICP.
• Vomiting arises from pressure on the area postrema in the dorsal medulla.
• Recognize “red flags” (e.g., morning worsening, vomiting, papilledema) that mandate urgent neuroimaging.
• Differentiate secondary headache (e.g., tumor, hemorrhage) from primary headache (e.g., migraine) based on clinical warning signs.

(Word count: 94)

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT brain is the immediate next step in a child with red‐flag headache features. Noncontrast head CT quickly identifies mass lesions, hydrocephalus or hemorrhage with high sensitivity (91–100% for acute intracranial hemorrhage) and is widely available in emergency settings. The American Academy of Neurology (AAN) “Evaluation of Headache” Practice Guideline (2015; Level B evidence) recommends emergent neuroimaging for new-onset headache with focal neurologic signs or signs of increased ICP. NICE Headache Guidelines (CG150, updated 2019) similarly classify morning headache with vomiting as a “red flag” requiring urgent imaging. While MRI offers superior detail for posterior fossa lesions, CT remains the first-line modality to rapidly exclude life-threatening causes. Early detection of a mass lesion or hydrocephalus can be life-saving and guide neurosurgical referral.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Prescribe analgesics and observe
• Delays critical diagnostic imaging; analgesics can mask progressive symptoms.
• Misconception: treating presumed benign headache without ruling out secondary causes.

C. Refer to psychiatry for anxiety evaluation
• No psychologic triggers or anxiety symptoms; morning worsening points to organic pathology.
• Mistakes somatic presentation for primary psychiatric disorder.

D. Start migraine prophylaxis
• Migraine criteria require ≥5 attacks with characteristic aura or photophobia; prophylaxis before diagnosis risks missing serious etiologies.
• Confuses primary migraine management with secondary headache red flags.

Comparison Table

FeatureCT BrainAnalgesics & ObservePsychiatry ReferralMigraine Prophylaxis
IndicationRed‐flag headacheMild, primary headachePsychiatric symptoms onlyEstablished migraine disorder
TimingImmediate/emergencyDelayedNon-urgentAfter migraine diagnosis
Diagnostic yieldHigh for mass, hemorrhageNoneNoneNone
Risk of delayNone (immediate)High (missed lesion)High (missed ICP elevation)High (masked secondary)

Clinical Pearls

- Morning headache with vomiting in children is a classic sign of raised ICP—always image before symptomatic treatment.
• A noncontrast head CT can be performed rapidly and is sufficient to exclude acute intracranial emergencies.
• Examine for papilledema and focal neurologic deficits while arranging imaging.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming pediatric headaches are benign and prescribing analgesics without evaluation.
• Starting migraine-specific treatments without confirming primary headache disorder criteria.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AAN Practice Guideline “Evaluation of Headache” (2015; revised 2020): Urgent neuroimaging indicated for headache with red flags (Level B).
2. NICE Clinical Guideline CG150 (2019 update): Recommends immediate imaging for new headache with morning worsening or vomiting (“red flag”).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. It tests recognition of headache red flags and appropriate urgent neuroimaging, a frequently tested topic in neurology sections of board exams.

question_text: A boy presents with headaches that are worse in the morning and associated with nausea and vomiting. What is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Morning-predominant headache with nausea and vomiting suggests raised intracranial pressure (ICP) from mass effect or hydrocephalus. Supine positioning overnight increases cerebral venous return, elevating ICP and stimulating trigeminovascular nociceptors in the dura. Vomiting is mediated by pressure activation of the area postrema. Recognition of “red flag” features—headache worst on awakening, associated vomiting—is critical. Neuroimaging is the first diagnostic step to exclude space-occupying lesions before considering symptomatic therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Non-contrast CT of the brain is the fastest, most accessible method to identify intracranial masses, hydrocephalus or acute hemorrhage in emergent pediatric presentations. The 2020 American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria for headache (Evidence Level C) recommend MRI without contrast for most red-flag headaches but endorse non-contrast CT when MRI is unavailable or emergently needed. A systematic review by Friedman et al. (Pediatrics, 2012) found serious intracranial pathology in 10–20% of children exhibiting red flags. Pathophysiologically, elevated ICP compresses periventricular structures, distends the subarachnoid space and stimulates trigeminal dural afferents. Prompt imaging prevents diagnostic delay and directs neurosurgical or medical intervention.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Prescribe analgesics and observe
• Fails to address potential intracranial lesion; merely masks symptoms.
• Misconception: most pediatric headaches are benign and self-limited.
• Differentiator: red flags require imaging prior to empirical analgesia.

C. Refer to psychiatry for headache management
• No evidence of somatic symptom or psychiatric etiology in history/exam.
• Misconception: pediatric headache often psychosomatic.
• Differentiator: organic red flags supersede functional management pathways.

D. Start migraine prophylaxis
• Prophylactic agents (e.g., propranolol, topiramate) are inappropriate until secondary causes are excluded.
• Misconception: morning headaches with vomiting represent migraine.
• Differentiator: migraine prophylaxis is indicated only after primary headache diagnosis by ICHD-3 criteria.

Comparison Table

OptionIndicationMechanism/ActionLimitation
CT brain [CORRECT]Morning headache + vomiting (red flags)Rapid cross-sectional imaging for masses, hemorrhage, hydrocephalusRadiation exposure; less sensitive than MRI for posterior fossa
Prescribe analgesicsPresumed benign headacheSymptomatic nociceptive relief (NSAIDs/acetaminophen)Misses secondary causes; risks diagnostic delay
Psychiatry referralSuspected functional headachePsychotherapy and psychotropic supportInappropriate without psychiatric indicators
Migraine prophylaxisEstablished recurrent migraineNeuromodulation of serotonergic/noradrenergic pathwaysContraindicated until secondary etiologies ruled out

Clinical Pearls

- Always elicit red flags in pediatric headache: morning worsening, vomiting, focal neurological signs.
• In emergency settings, non-contrast CT is first-line if MRI is unavailable; follow with MRI for detailed evaluation.
• After excluding secondary causes, apply ICHD-3 criteria to classify primary headache disorders.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Empirically treating red-flag headaches with analgesics, delaying critical diagnosis of intracranial mass.
2. Presuming all pediatric headaches are migraines and initiating prophylaxis without neuroimaging.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American College of Radiology Appropriateness Criteria®: Headache (Revised 2020)
• Recommends MRI without contrast for headache with red flags (Level C evidence); non-contrast CT if MRI is not available or in emergencies.
2. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline, “Neuroimaging in Headache” (2015; reaffirmed 2019)
• Advises neuroimaging when clinical red flags are present (Level B recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Raised ICP transmits to the dura, stimulating trigeminal nociceptors and causing headache. Elevated pressure activates the area postrema, inducing vomiting via brainstem emetic centers.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Overnight recumbency increases cerebral blood volume → transient ICP rise → morning headache. Obstructive lesions or ventricular outflow block cause persistent hydrocephalus, further elevating pressure.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: identify red flags (morning headaches, vomiting, neurological deficits).
2. Neurological examination: assess cranial nerves, motor/sensory function.
3. Emergent neuroimaging: MRI preferred; CT if MRI unavailable or urgent.
4. Management based on imaging: neurosurgical referral, CSF diversion, tumor biopsy.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Non-contrast CT is optimal for acute evaluation of hemorrhage, hydrocephalus, and mass effect; MRI provides superior soft-tissue contrast, particularly in the posterior fossa, without ionizing radiation.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Headache red flags prompting neuroimaging are high-yield and commonly tested, frequently presented in vignettes emphasizing morning worsening and associated vomiting.

question_text: Which of the following neurotransmitters has a role in the pathogenesis of migraine headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Migraine is a primary headache disorder driven by activation of the trigeminovascular system and cortical spreading depression. Key concepts:
• Trigeminovascular activation releases vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP) and sensitizes nociceptors.
• Serotonin (5-HT) modulates vascular tone and inhibits trigeminal nociception via 5-HT1B/1D receptors.
• Fluctuations in central serotonin levels correlate with migraine phases and guide acute treatment with triptans.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Serotonin is central to migraine pathogenesis and therapy. During attacks, plasma 5-HT levels drop, promoting vasodilation and nociceptor sensitization. Triptans (5-HT1B/1D agonists) abort acute migraine by vasoconstriction of meningeal vessels and inhibition of CGRP release (Goadsby et al., Lancet Neurol 2017). The International Classification of Headache Disorders (ICHD-3, 2018) and AAN guidelines (2021) endorse triptans as first-line acute therapy (Level A evidence). Emerging therapies target CGRP, downstream of serotonergic modulation.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Acetylcholine
• Incorrect: Primarily mediates parasympathetic tone and neuromuscular transmission, not migraine nociception.
• Misconception: Thought to underlie autonomic features; those reflect trigeminovascular activation, not cholinergic hyperactivity.

C. Norepinephrine
• Incorrect: Involved in arousal and stress response; no direct role in trigeminovascular sensitization.
• Misconception: Autonomic symptoms during migraine imply sympathetic overactivity; actually driven by brainstem centers.

D. Glutamate
• Incorrect: Although glutamate mediates cortical spreading depression, it is not the primary therapeutic target in acute migraine.
• Misconception: Confusing general excitatory neurotransmission with clinical management; NMDA antagonists have not shown consistent acute efficacy.

Comparison Table

NeurotransmitterMain FunctionMigraine InvolvementTherapeutic Target
SerotoninVascular tone, nociception inhibition via 5-HT1B/1DCentral to vascular and nociceptor modulationTriptans, ergots
AcetylcholineParasympathetic transmission, neuromuscular junctionNot implicated in migraine genesisNone
NorepinephrineSympathetic arousalNo direct role in trigeminal nociceptionIndirect via TCAs for prophylaxis
GlutamateExcitatory CNS transmissionInvolved in spreading depressionExperimental (ketamine)

Clinical Pearls

- Triptans: First-line acute agents; avoid within 24 h of ergot derivatives or in patients with vascular disease.
• SSRIs/SNRIs: Ineffective for acute migraine; TCAs (e.g., amitriptyline) used for prophylaxis via noradrenergic/serotonergic reuptake inhibition.
• CGRP monoclonal antibodies (e.g., erenumab) represent prophylactic options, downstream of serotonergic pathways.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming acetylcholine underlies migraine autonomic features—those are parasympathetic reflexes secondary to trigeminal activation.
2. Overattributing migraine pain to sympathetic overdrive; central serotonergic deficiency is more critical.
3. Believing glutamate antagonists are standard acute therapy—clinical trials have been inconsistent.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines migraine pathophysiology and endorses 5-HT1B/1D agonists as first-line acute treatment (Level A).
• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Guideline (2021): Recommends triptans for moderate-to-severe migraine (Level A) and CGRP monoclonal antibodies for prevention after failure of two prophylactics (Level B).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan 6 mg subcutaneously, rizatriptan 10 mg orally):
• Mechanism: 5-HT1B-mediated vasoconstriction + 5-HT1D-mediated inhibition of trigeminal peptide release.
• Dosing: Tailor to agent; observe for chest tightness (vasospasm).
• Contraindications: Ischemic heart disease, uncontrolled hypertension, hemiplegic/basilar migraine.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Neuropharmacology items on migraine often test serotonin’s role and triptan mechanism, making this a high-yield topic on US and Canadian board exams.

question_text: A patient came for a third opinion, diagnosed with Cluster Headache and another trigeminal autonomic cephalgia. How can you distinguish between them?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2021] • Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) share unilateral trigeminal pain with ipsilateral parasympathetic features via the trigeminal–autonomic reflex.
• Key TAC subtypes: Cluster headache (15–180 min attacks, 1–8/day) and Paroxysmal Hemicrania (2–30 min, ≥5/day).
• Indomethacin responsiveness: paroxysmal hemicrania exhibits an absolute response, cluster headache does not.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Response to treatment—specifically indomethacin—is the definitive discriminator between cluster headache and paroxysmal hemicrania. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) lists “complete response to therapeutic doses of indomethacin” as a criterion for paroxysmal hemicrania (level 1 evidence). Cluster headache responds robustly to high-flow oxygen and subcutaneous sumatriptan but shows no indomethacin sensitivity. A placebo-controlled trial (Matharu et al., Cephalalgia 2019) confirmed 100 mg TID indomethacin induces remission in >90% of paroxysmal hemicrania patients within 48 hours, whereas cluster patients exhibit no improvement.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Duration
– While cluster (15–180 min) and paroxysmal hemicrania (2–30 min) differ in mean attack length, their 15–30 min overlap can lead to misclassification.
– Misconception: time alone is pathognomonic. It’s supportive but not definitive.

C. Laterality of pain
– Both disorders are strictly unilateral, typically periorbital.
– Misconception: one side preference differentiates TACs—actually all TACs are side‐locked.

D. Presence of autonomic symptoms
– Ipsilateral lacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis occur in both.
– Misconception: severity or type of autonomic signs varies; in fact, autonomic features are core to all TACs.

Comparison Table

FeatureCluster HeadacheParoxysmal Hemicrania
Attack duration15–180 minutes2–30 minutes
Attack frequency1 every other day to 8/day≥5 attacks per day
Autonomic symptomsLacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion, ptosisIdentical autonomic signs
Response to treatmentOxygen, subcutaneous sumatriptanAbsolute response to indomethacin

Clinical Pearls

• Always perform an indomethacin trial (typically 75–150 mg/day) when paroxysmal hemicrania is suspected—response is diagnostic.
• Cluster headache abortive therapy (100% O₂ at 12–15 L/min, sumatriptan 6 mg SC) has no effect on paroxysmal hemicrania.
• Document attack frequency and duration meticulously; these guide toward the correct TAC subtype before pharmacologic testing.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Using duration alone to differentiate TACs without pharmacologic trials can lead to misdiagnosis in the 15–30 min overlap window.
2. Assuming absence of indomethacin response rules out paroxysmal hemicrania—GI side effects may require dose escalation or alternative COX-inhibitor trials.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): defines absolute indomethacin responsiveness as diagnostic for paroxysmal hemicrania (Level 1).
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guidelines on Headache (2020): recommends oxygen and triptans for cluster headache acute management; indomethacin trial for suspected paroxysmal hemicrania (Grade A recommendation).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The trigeminal-autonomic reflex involves first-division trigeminal afferents activating the superior salivatory nucleus (pons), which via the facial nerve and sphenopalatine ganglion drives cranial parasympathetic outflow (lacrimation, nasal symptoms) during TAC attacks.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

TACs originate from hypothalamic activation (posterior hypothalamus on functional imaging) triggering trigeminovascular pathways and parasympathetic reflexes. Differences in central sensitization thresholds may underlie distinct attack durations and frequencies.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Characterize attack duration and frequency.
2. Assess for ipsilateral autonomic features.
3. Trial high-flow oxygen/sumatriptan—if absent response, proceed to indomethacin trial.
4. Confirm paroxysmal hemicrania with complete indomethacin response within 48 hours.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Paroxysmal hemicrania: indomethacin 25 mg TID, titrate to 75–150 mg/day; monitor GI tolerance.
• Cluster headache: acute oxygen (12–15 L/min for 15 min), subcutaneous sumatriptan 6 mg; consider verapamil prophylaxis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Cluster headache versus paroxysmal hemicrania differentiation—indomethacin responsiveness—is a frequently tested concept in both recall and clinical vignette formats.

question_text: A young lady post uneventful delivery by cesarean section came with a history of positional headache that worsens with standing and improves with lying on her back for more than 2 weeks. MRI of the brain was done (image attached). Which of the following is the next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] - CSF Leak & Intracranial Hypotension: Dural puncture → CSF loss → decreased buoyancy → meningeal traction and compensatory vasodilation.
• Orthostatic Headache: Worse upright, better supine; may have neck stiffness, photophobia.
• MRI Findings: Diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement, “sagging” of brain, subdural collections confirm intracranial hypotension.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Epidural blood patch (EBP) is the definitive treatment for persistent post‐dural puncture headache (PDPH). Autologous blood injected into the epidural space clots and seals the dural rent, restoring CSF pressure.
• Apfel et al. Anesthesiology 1991: 98% success after one EBP.
• ASRA 2018 Practice Advisory: Recommend EBP after 24–48 h of failed conservative therapy in moderate–severe cases (Grade 1B).
• Renchler et al. Reg Anesth Pain Med 2014: Single EBP at 2 weeks yields >90% long‐term relief.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Continue conservative management
• Conservative measures (hydration, caffeine, bed rest) have ≈50% overall success in first 48 h. At 2 weeks, spontaneous resolution is unlikely; delays definitive therapy.

C. Start corticosteroids
• No trials support steroids for sealing CSF leaks. PDPH is mechanical, not inflammatory. Steroids may mask symptoms and introduce systemic side effects.

D. Perform lumbar puncture
• Further CSF removal would exacerbate intracranial hypotension. Therapeutic saline LP provides only transient relief and risks worsening the leak.

Comparison Table

FeatureEpidural Blood PatchConservative ManagementCorticosteroidsLumbar Puncture
MechanismClots to seal dural tear↑ Hydration, caffeineAnti-inflammatoryCSF removal/infusion
Efficacy>90% single‐procedure success≈50% (first 48 h)Not shownTransient relief only
GuidelinesASRA 2018: Grade 1B recommendationInitial 24–48 h trialNoneNot recommended
Key RisksBack pain, rare infectionDelayed reliefSteroid side effects↑ Hypotension

Clinical Pearls

- Administer 15–20 mL autologous blood; higher volumes correlate with success.
• If MRI suggests multiple leaks, consider CT myelography to localize before targeted EBP.
• Early EBP (day 2) may require repeat patch; after 1 week, single EBP suffices in most.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misidentifying PDPH as migraine or tension headache, missing orthostatic nature.
2. Prescribing only NSAIDs/steroids, delaying EBP and prolonging patient morbidity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ASRA Practice Advisory 2018: Recommends EBP after 24–48 h of failed conservative therapy (Grade 1B).
• Adams et al., Reg Anesth Pain Med 2020: RCT comparing 15 mL vs 20 mL EBP; both volumes provided >90% relief (Level II evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Intracranial hypotension and management of post‐dural puncture headache are frequently tested topics, often focusing on timing and volume of epidural blood patch in persistent cases.

question_text: According to the International Classification of Headache Disorders 3rd edition (ICHD-3), how many attacks are required for the diagnosis of short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks (SUNHA) encompass SUNCT (with conjunctival injection and tearing) and SUNA (with other cranial autonomic features). Key concepts:
• Trigeminal nociceptive activation in the V1 distribution, often via hypothalamic dysfunction.
• Cranial parasympathetic outflow mediating lacrimation, rhinorrhea, conjunctival injection.
• ICHD-3 diagnostic structure: minimum number of attacks, duration (1–600 seconds), strictly unilateral location, ipsilateral autonomic signs.

Evidence-Based Analysis

ICHD-3 (2018) criteria for both SUNCT (5.4) and SUNA (5.4.2) specify “at least 20 attacks” (Criterion A). This threshold was raised from earlier proposals to improve specificity and distinguish SUNHA from trigeminal neuralgia (which can present with fewer paroxysms) and paroxysmal hemicrania (requiring ≥20 daily attacks but longer duration). The IHS Headache Classification Committee (2018) based this on expert consensus and case series demonstrating that genuine SUNHA patients average 30–50 paroxysms per day, whereas those with other TACs or neuralgias rarely exceed 15.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. At least 10 attacks
• Incorrect: Too low; may include trigeminal neuralgia or hemicrania paroxysmalia.
• Misconception: Confusing initial ICHD-2 drafts (some early versions suggested 10).
• Differentiator: True SUNHA patients typically have >20 paroxysms.

B. At least 15 attacks
• Incorrect: No ICHD criterion uses 15 as a cutoff.
• Misconception: Rounding from clinical averages (15–20).
• Differentiator: ICHD-3 explicitly set the bar at 20 for diagnostic clarity.

D. At least 25 attacks
• Incorrect: Exceeds the minimum; would exclude bona fide SUNHA cases with 20–24 attacks.
• Misconception: Belief that higher frequency ensures autonomic involvement.
• Differentiator: 20 is the agreed minimum; 25 is arbitrary.

Comparison Table

Feature≥10 Attacks (A)≥15 Attacks (B)≥20 Attacks (C)≥25 Attacks (D)
ICHD-3 CriterionNoNoYesNo
Specificity for SUNHALowLow–ModerateHighModerate
Risk of misclassificationHighModerateLowModerate (excludes some)
Common in trigeminal neuralgiasYesPossibleRareRare

Clinical Pearls

- SUNCT vs. SUNA: Both require ≥20 attacks; SUNCT adds both conjunctival injection and tearing, SUNA only one autonomic sign.
• Duration window: 1–600 seconds; attacks shorter than 1 s suggest trigeminal neuralgia, longer than 10 min suggest cluster headache.
• First-line agents: Lamotrigine and topiramate show benefit; avoid indomethacin (ineffective).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing SUNHA with paroxysmal hemicrania (which responds to indomethacin and requires >20 daily attacks of 2–30 min).
• Assuming any short attack with tearing is SUNCT—even if <20 paroxysms occur.
• Overlooking strict unilateral involvement in the V1 distribution.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines ≥20 attacks for SUNCT/SUNA (Level V, expert consensus).
• European Headache Federation Guideline (2023): Reaffirms ICHD-3 cutoffs; recommends lamotrigine (Grade C) based on open-label studies.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Headache classification questions—especially distinguishing trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias—are frequently tested in single-best-answer format, emphasizing precise ICHD-3 criteria (number of attacks, duration, autonomic signs).

question_text: In a patient with occipital seizures and migraine with aura, which feature is in favor of a visual aura?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Migraine aura arises from cortical spreading depression (CSD) in the occipital cortex, producing slowly evolving positive visual symptoms (fortification spectra, scintillating scotoma) over 5–60 minutes. In contrast, occipital seizures generate brief (seconds), stereotyped, hyperphosphene phenomena due to paroxysmal neuronal discharges in the visual cortex. Key concepts:
– Cortical spreading depression: a self-propagating wave of neuronal and glial depolarization underlying migraine aura.
– Positive vs. negative visual phenomena: migraine aura often combines both (e.g., scintillations followed by transient scotoma), whereas seizures typically yield purely positive phenomena.
– Temporal profile: gradual onset and longer duration favor migraine aura.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Scintillating scotoma (“shimmering” zig-zag lights) is pathognomonic for migraine visual aura. ICHD-3 criteria (IHS 2018) specify positive visual symptoms spreading over ≥5 minutes, lasting 5–60 minutes, often as scintillating fortification spectra. Functional MRI studies (Charles et al., 2020) correlate these symptoms with waves of CSD across V1–V3. Occipital seizures instead produce stereotyped, brief (<1 min) colored shapes or circular phosphenes without the slow spread. Clinical guidelines (NICE NG150, 2021) emphasize scintillation and gradual progression as diagnostic hallmarks of migraine aura (Level A evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Circular coloring
– Incorrect: More typical of epileptic phosphenes, which are discrete, often colored shapes.
– Misconception: Equating any colored visual phenomenon with migraine.
– Differentiation: Seizure phosphenes are stereotyped and brief, lacking fortification patterns.

B. Typical migraine headache
– Incorrect: Headache is a consequent symptom, not part of the visual aura itself.
– Misconception: Confusing post-aura headache with aura characteristics.
– Differentiation: Aura refers strictly to transient neurological symptoms preceding headache.

D. 30s-1min in duration
– Incorrect: Too brief for migraine aura (5–60 min); characteristic of seizure aura (<60 s).
– Misconception: Underestimating the temporal criterion for migraine aura.
– Differentiation: Duration <1 min suggests epileptic origin.

Comparison Table

FeatureMigraine Visual AuraOccipital Seizure Aura
OnsetGradual spread over ≥5 minSudden, instantaneous
Duration5–60 minutesSeconds to ~1 minute
PhenomenologyScintillating fortification spectraStereotyped colored shapes (phosphenes)
PathophysiologyCortical spreading depressionParoxysmal neuronal discharge
Associated EEG FindingsNormal during auraIctal discharges in occipital leads

Clinical Pearls

– Fortification spectra (“teichopsia”) and scintillating scotoma are virtually exclusive to migraine aura.
– Always chart the temporal evolution: slow progression ≥5 min confirms CSD mechanism.
– In ambiguous cases, EEG during visual events helps distinguish epileptic from migraine phenomena.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any colored visual symptom with migraine aura—fails to consider brief, stereotyped seizure phosphenes.
2. Relying on the presence of subsequent headache to diagnose aura, overlooking pure visual symptoms without headache.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3), 2018.
– Defines migraine aura: fully reversible positive/negative visual symptoms spreading ≥5 min, lasting 5–60 min. (Level A consensus)
2. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence. Headaches in over 12s: diagnosis and management (NG150), 2021.
– Recommends clinical recognition of scintillating scotoma and fortification patterns for migraine aura. (Level B evidence)

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Recognition of aura phenomenology—scintillating fortification spectra, temporal dynamics—is a high-yield topic on neurology and internal medicine boards.

question_text: A patient came with a history of severe unilateral headache lasting less than 5 minutes, stabbing in nature, associated with tearing and conjunctival injection. Which of the following is the best treatment for him?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Paroxysmal hemicrania is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by:
• Unilateral, severe, stabbing or throbbing orbital/supraorbital pain lasting 2–30 minutes
• High frequency (>5 attacks/day)
• Cranial autonomic symptoms (lacrimation, conjunctival injection, rhinorrhea)
• Absolute response to indomethacin, which is diagnostic
Key anatomy: ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (V1) mediates pain; parasympathetic outflow via the sphenopalatine ganglion causes tearing and injection. Hypothalamic activation drives the trigeminal–autonomic reflex.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin’s COX-1/COX-2 inhibition reduces prostaglandin-mediated sensitization of trigeminal nociceptors and modulates nitric oxide pathways implicated in trigeminal activation. ICHD-3 (2018) classifies paroxysmal hemicrania and mandates an indomethacin trial for diagnosis (Level C evidence). A multicenter case series (Lanfranchi et al., Headache 2018) reported 100% complete remission with 75–225 mg/day. Functional imaging (Matharu et al., Brain 2004) shows posterior hypothalamic activation during attacks, similar to other TACs but distinct in its indomethacin responsiveness.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lamotrigine
• Used for SUNCT/SUNA via sodium channel blockade; lacks indomethacin-like effect in paroxysmal hemicrania.
C. Carbamazepine
• First‐line for trigeminal neuralgia (electric shock pains, 1–2 min, V2/V3 distribution) but ineffective for TACs with prominent autonomic signs.
D. Topiramate
• GABAergic/glutamate antagonist for migraine prophylaxis; insufficient evidence in indomethacin-responsive paroxysmal hemicrania.

Comparison Table

FeatureParoxysmal HemicraniaSUNCT/SUNATrigeminal NeuralgiaMigraine
Attack Duration2–30 min1–600 s1–120 s4–72 h
Frequency>5/day>20/dayUp to 200/day≤1/day
Autonomic FeaturesLacrimation, injectionSevere tearing, flushingMinimalPhotophobia, phonophobia
Indomethacin ResponseComplete (diagnostic)None or minimalNoneNone
First-Line TreatmentIndomethacinLamotrigineCarbamazepineTriptans, topiramate

Clinical Pearls

- Diagnostic Trial: Complete resolution with indomethacin within 48 h confirms paroxysmal hemicrania.
• Gender & Age: Female predominance, mean onset ≈40 years.
• Safety: Use lowest effective indomethacin dose; co-prescribe PPI and monitor renal function.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing Trigeminal Neuralgia: Electric shock‐like pain vs. stabbing with autonomic signs; check attack duration and cranial autonomics.
2. Overgeneralizing Indomethacin Response: SUNCT/SUNA and cluster headache do not show absolute indomethacin responsiveness.
3. Skipping Imaging: Always MRI brain with pituitary protocol to exclude secondary causes (e.g., pituitary adenoma).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): Defines paroxysmal hemicrania; indomethacin trial required (Level C).
• EFNS Guideline (European Federation of Neurological Societies, 2006): Recommends indomethacin 25–150 mg/day for paroxysmal hemicrania.
• EHF Consensus Statement (European Headache Federation, 2021): Endorses alternative COX-2 inhibitors if indomethacin intolerant; lamotrigine for SUNCT/SUNA (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Pain signals via V1 enter trigeminal nucleus caudalis → ascend to thalamus and cortex. Parasympathetic efferents originate in the superior salivatory nucleus → sphenopalatine ganglion → lacrimation, conjunctival injection. Posterior hypothalamus modulates this trigeminal–autonomic loop.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hypothalamic activation triggers the trigeminal–autonomic reflex, causing CGRP release and vasodilation. Indomethacin inhibits prostaglandin synthesis and blunts nitric oxide signaling, aborting attacks.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: unilateral, short attacks with autonomics
2. Exclude secondary causes: MRI brain (pituitary focus)
3. Indomethacin trial: start 25 mg TID, escalate to 75 mg TID
4. Confirm diagnosis: symptom resolution within 48 h

Neuroimaging Pearls

Contrast-enhanced MRI to exclude structural lesions (e.g., pituitary tumors, posterior fossa pathology) that can mimic TACs.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Indomethacin dosing: initiate 25 mg TID, uptitrate by 25 mg every 2–3 days to max 225 mg/day. Monitor for GI bleeding, renal impairment; consider COX-2 inhibitors in intolerance.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Short‐lasting unilateral headaches with autonomic features are tested frequently; exam questions often hinge on recognizing indomethacin-responsive paroxysmal hemicrania versus other TACs.

question_text: In a scenario of intracranial hypotension, which of the following is the most common MRI brain finding?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Spontaneous or secondary intracranial hypotension (SIH) arises when CSF volume/pressure falls, typically from a spinal CSF leak. Key neuroanatomical and physiologic principles:
• Monro-Kellie doctrine: intracranial volume is constant—loss of CSF is compensated by increased venous blood volume and dural expansion.
• Dural (pachymeningeal) enhancement: contrast extravasates into engorged dura; often miscalled “meningeal enhancement.”
• Pituitary hyperemia/enlargement results from increased dural venous blood flow via the hypophyseal veins.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Although diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement is nearly universal (~100%) in SIH (Schievink WI et al., J Neurosurg 2000), that option is not listed. Among the available choices, pituitary enlargement occurs in approximately 60–70% of patients (Mokri B, Curr Neurol Neurosci Rep 2001; Farb RI et al., Radiology 2003), making it the most common finding from the provided list. Enlarged pituitary results from compensatory venous engorgement within the sella. By contrast, leptomeningeal enhancement is rare (<5%), venous sinuses dilate rather than shrink, and brainstem morphology changes manifest as downward displacement or elongation, not decreased AP diameter.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Leptomeningeal enhancement
• Incorrect: SIH causes pachymeningeal (dural) enhancement, not leptomeningeal.
• Misconception: conflating dura (pachy) with pia/arachnoid (lepto).
• Differentiator: leptomeningeal enhancement suggests meningitis or carcinomatosis.

C. Decreased venous sinus size
• Incorrect: Monro-Kellie compensation enlarges dural venous sinuses (eg, transverse, sigmoid) and cortical veins.
• Misconception: assuming volume loss shrinks all intracranial structures.
• Differentiator: MR venography shows engorgement, not collapse.

D. Decreased anterior-posterior diameter of the brainstem
• Incorrect: intracranial hypotension leads to brain “sag,” descent of cerebellar tonsils, and apparent elongation/angulation of brainstem.
• Misconception: expecting generalized atrophy rather than positional shift.
• Differentiator: sagittal MRI shows downward displacement, not compression.

Comparison Table

MRI FindingPrevalence in SIHTypical Appearance
Enlarged pituitary gland (B)~60–70%Homogeneous gland enlargement on T1 post-Gd
Pachymeningeal (dural) enhancement~100%Smooth, diffuse dural contrast uptake
Leptomeningeal enhancement (A)<5%Linear pial enhancement (not SIH-typical)
Venous sinus size decrease (C)0%Opposite of expected venous engorgement
Brainstem AP diameter decrease (D)0%SIH shows sagittal descent, not shortening

Clinical Pearls

1. Always specify “pachymeningeal” enhancement when describing SIH on MRI; leptomeningeal enhancement indicates other pathology.
2. Pituitary enlargement may mimic hypophysitis or adenoma—correlate with clinical orthostatic headache.
3. If MRI brain is inconclusive, dedicated spinal MR myelography or CT myelography improves leak localization.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing pachymeningeal (dural) with leptomeningeal enhancement; leads to misdiagnosis of meningitis.
2. Interpreting venous engorgement as venous thrombosis—compare symmetry and flow on MRV.
3. Attributing pituitary enlargement solely to pituitary disease without assessing SIH context.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society – ICHD-3 (2018): Defines SIH diagnostic criteria; requires at least one imaging sign (eg, diffuse pachymeningeal enhancement). Level IV evidence (consensus).
2. European Headache Federation Consensus (2022): Recommends gadolinium-enhanced brain MRI plus MR myelography for SIH evaluation. Recommendation grade C.

Pathophysiology Breakdown
