• European Headache Federation (2019): “White matter hyperintensities in migraine are benign; routine follow-up MRI is not recommended.” (Grade A recommendation)

Neuroimaging Pearls

- UBOs are small (<5 mm), non-enhancing, T2/FLAIR hyperintense foci without mass effect.
• Predilection for deep/periventricular white matter distinguishes them from cortical lesions seen in demyelinating disease.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2021 exam. Boards frequently test the distinction between incidental benign imaging findings and pathologic processes requiring intervention; recognition of migraine‐associated UBOs and appropriate reassurance is high‐yield.

question_text: A patient with migraine presents with a new onset of headache that is unlike previous migraine headaches and is not improving despite an increased dose and frequency of analgesics. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Headache classification per ICHD-3 divides headaches into primary and secondary. Medication overuse headache (MOH) is a secondary headache developing in patients with a primary headache disorder (e.g., migraine) who overuse acute medications. MOH pathophysiology involves central sensitization via trigeminovascular activation and impaired descending inhibition. Clinically, MOH presents as a daily or near-daily headache that differs in quality from baseline episodic migraine and worsens despite increased medication. Key concepts include defining overuse (≥10–15 days/month depending on drug class for >3 months), recognizing rebound phenomena, and differentiating MOH from chronic daily headache (umbrella term for ≥15 headache days/month), chronic tension-type headache (bilateral, pressing quality), and cluster headache (trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia with ipsilateral autonomic features).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Medication overuse headache (MOH) is diagnosed per ICHD-3 criteria (2018): headache ≥15 days/month in a patient with pre-existing headache disorder who has used acute medications ≥10 days/month (triptans/ergots) or ≥15 days/month (NSAIDs/analgesics) for >3 months, causing headache worsening. In this Part 1 2020 exam scenario, the headache is new, unlike baseline migraine, and refractory to increased analgesics, classic for MOH. The American Headache Society 2021 Guidelines on Migraine Management recommend immediate withdrawal of overused medications (Level A evidence) and initiation of preventive therapy post-withdrawal. Neurobiological studies (Bigal et al., 2007) implicate sensitization of the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and periaqueductal gray dysfunction in MOH. Randomized trials show high relapse rates without structured detoxification (Steiner et al., 2016). Preventive agents post-withdrawal include topiramate (Class I evidence) and CGRP monoclonal antibodies (Class II evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chronic daily headache
• Specific reason: CDH is an umbrella term for headaches occurring ≥15 days/month and does not specify etiology.
• Common misconception: Labeling any frequent headache as CDH, missing the medication overuse etiology.
• Differentiating feature: MOH requires a history of overuse and rebound worsening; CDH lacks specific overuse criteria.

C. Tension-type headache
• Specific reason: Tension-type headache is bilateral, pressing, mild–moderate, without significant nausea or photo/phonophobia.
• Common misconception: Assuming a non–migraine phenotype in an overuser equals chronic TTH.
• Differentiating feature: MOH presents with variable quality, daily frequency, and is directly linked to analgesic overuse.

D. Cluster headache
• Specific reason: Cluster headache features strictly unilateral, severe stabbing pain with ipsilateral autonomic signs and short duration (15–180 min).
• Common misconception: Equating severe headache unresponsive to OTC analgesics with cluster headache.
• Differentiating feature: Cluster has circadian pattern and autonomic features, absent in MOH.

Comparison Table

FeatureMOHCDH (Umbrella)Tension-Type HeadacheCluster Headache
Headache frequency≥15 days/month≥15 days/monthEpisodic <15 / Chronic ≥151–8 attacks/day in clusters
Pain qualityVariable, often diffuseVariableBilateral, pressing/tighteningStrictly unilateral, severe, stabbing
Medication historyOveruse ≥3 monthsNo specific overuse criterionNo overuse criterionNo overuse criterion
Autonomic featuresAbsentAbsentAbsentPresent (lacrimation, rhinorrhea)
Response to withdrawalImprovesN/AN/AN/A

Clinical Pearls

- Per ICHD-3, overuse is defined as ≥10 days/month of triptans or opioids, or ≥15 days/month of NSAIDs/analgesics, for >3 months.
• Structured withdrawal (abrupt or tapered) with short-term bridging (e.g., prednisone) reduces detoxification headache and relapse.
• CGRP monoclonal antibodies (erenumab, fremanezumab) show efficacy in preventing relapse post-detoxification.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Failing to elicit detailed OTC and prescription analgesic history leads to missed MOH diagnoses.
• Misclassifying rebound headaches due to overuse as progression of migraine, delaying appropriate detoxification and prophylaxis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society, 2021: Recommends abrupt withdrawal of overused medications (Level A), followed by preventive therapy; topiramate rating Level B.
2. European Headache Federation, 2019: Advocates multidisciplinary withdrawal programs and supports CGRP monoclonal antibodies for relapse prevention (moderate quality evidence).
3. Lipton et al., 2018 (Phase III RCT): Erenumab reduced monthly headache days by 50% in chronic migraine patients with prior medication overuse (p<0.001).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

MOH involves the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, periaqueductal gray, and dorsal raphe nuclei. Repeated analgesic exposure disrupts descending serotonergic and opioidergic inhibitory pathways, lowering pain thresholds.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic analgesic use downregulates 5-HT₁B/D receptors, upregulates CGRP release, and induces central sensitization. Altered NMDA receptor activity in dorsal horn neurons perpetuates pain facilitation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm pre-existing primary headache disorder.
2. Quantify headache days/month (≥15 suggests chronic).
3. Review acute medication type, dose, frequency, and duration.
4. Apply ICHD-3 criteria for MOH.
5. Exclude secondary causes if red flags present.
6. Develop withdrawal and preventive plan.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Routine imaging in MOH is normal. Reserve MRI/CT for atypical features or red flags (e.g., neurological deficits, sudden onset).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Withdrawal: Abrupt cessation or taper depending on drug class; bridging with naproxen or prednisone.
• Preventive: Topiramate (start 25 mg/day → 100 mg/day), amitriptyline; consider CGRP monoclonal antibodies; avoid opioids/barbiturates.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam.
Medication overuse headache is frequently tested via scenario-based questions requiring application of ICHD-3 criteria and management strategies, appearing on neurology and internal medicine boards.

question_text: What is the sign on brain MRI of a patient with intracranial hypotension?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Intracranial hypotension results from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) volume loss—often due to a spinal CSF leak—and triggers compensatory intracranial venous dilation (Monro-Kellie doctrine). Key neuroimaging principles:
• CSF volume falls → venous distension in dura and pituitary → pachymeningeal (not leptomeningeal) enhancement and pituitary enlargement.
• Brain “sagging” manifests as descent of cerebellar tonsils, reduced mamillopontine distance and flattening of the pons (decreased AP diameter).
• Subdural collections may coexist.
Recognizing these imaging patterns is essential for diagnosing headache secondary to low CSF pressure.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Pituitary enlargement in intracranial hypotension reflects venous engorgement of the pituitary venous plexus. A prospective study by Schievink et al. (Neurology, 2019) found pituitary height ≥6 mm in 65% of SIH patients versus 12% of controls (p<0.001). The American Headache Society 2021 consensus recommends gadolinium-enhanced brain MRI as first-line evaluation; pituitary hyperemia/enlargement is one of the five cardinal MRI signs (Level B evidence). Engorgement resolves after epidural blood patch, confirming its diagnostic significance.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Leptomeningeal enhancement
• Why incorrect: In SIH enhancement is in the dura (pachymeninges), not the arachnoid/pia (leptomeninges).
• Misconception: Confusing pachy- vs leptomeninges.
• Differentiator: Pachymeningeal enhancement is diffuse, smooth, along cranial vault and skull base.

B. Decrease in venous sinus size
• Why incorrect: Venous sinuses dilate (engorge) to compensate for lost CSF volume.
• Misconception: Assuming hypovolemia shrinks venous structures.
• Differentiator: MR venography shows increased cross-sectional area of dural sinuses.

D. Decrease in anterior-posterior diameter of the brainstem
• Why incorrect: Brainstem flattening (especially of the pons) is seen, but AP diameter often increases laterally as it “sags”; overall key sign is descent of hindbrain, not pure AP narrowing.
• Misconception: Equating any pons change with SIH hallmark.
• Differentiator: True hallmark is tonsillar descent and reduced mamillopontine distance.

Comparison Table

Imaging FindingPrevalence in SIHMechanismSpecificity for SIH
Pituitary enlargement (correct)~65%Venous plexus engorgementModerate
Pachymeningeal (not leptomeningeal) enhancement~80%Dural venous dilation + hyperemiaHigh
Venous sinus dilation (vs shrinkage)~75%Compensatory increase in venous volumeModerate
Brainstem “sag” (tonsillar descent)~85%Loss of buoyant CSF support → saggingHigh

Clinical Pearls

• Pituitary enlargement may mimic adenoma; clinical context and other SIH signs (e.g., pachymeningeal enhancement) help avoid misdiagnosis.
• Always use contrast-enhanced MRI in suspected SIH.
• Post-blood patch imaging reversal of pituitary enlargement confirms a CSF leak origin of enlargement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misreading pachymeningeal as leptomeningeal enhancement—only dura enhances in SIH.
2. Assuming small venous sinuses on MRI indicates low flow—actually, sinuses enlarge in compensation.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society. International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (beta), 2013.
• Diagnostic criteria for headache attributed to low CSF pressure require ≥1 imaging sign (e.g., pachymeningeal enhancement, brain sag, pituitary enlargement). (Consensus expert opinion)

2. European Headache Federation. Consensus guidelines for the management of spontaneous intracranial hypotension. J Headache Pain. 2022;23(1):34.
• Recommend gadolinium-enhanced brain MRI as first-line imaging (Level B).
• First-line treatment: targeted epidural blood patch (Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CSF leak → decreased intracranial CSF volume → lowered CSF pressure → compensatory intracranial venous dilation (Monro-Kellie) → engorged dura, venous sinuses, pituitary → imaging findings + brain sag due to lost buoyancy.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical: orthostatic headache, neck stiffness, nausea.
2. MRI brain with gadolinium: look for pachymeningeal enhancement, pituitary enlargement, brain sag, subdural collections.
3. If imaging signs positive, proceed to spinal imaging (MR myelography or CT myelography) to localize leak.
4. Treatment: epidural blood patch (targeted if leak site known).

Neuroimaging Pearls

• Pituitary height >6 mm in adults suggests engorgement.
• Mamillopontine distance <6.5 mm and sagging of cerebellar tonsils >4 mm confirm descent.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. On board exams, intracranial hypotension is most often tested by asking for pachymeningeal enhancement, pituitary enlargement, or brain “sag” signs on MRI. Recognition of the Monro-Kellie compensatory mechanism is key.

question_text: A 33-year-old female with a history of migraines calls the office because of a severe migraine at 32 weeks of pregnancy. There are no complicating features to her headache, and this headache is similar to all her prior headaches. Which of the following abortive therapies would be the most appropriate for this patient?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Migraine abortive therapy in pregnancy requires balancing maternal relief with fetal safety.
• Migraines involve trigeminovascular activation and release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP).
• Abortive agents include NSAIDs, triptans, antiemetics, and rarely steroids or neuroactive drugs.
• In pregnancy, drug categories evolve: NSAIDs are generally avoided in the third trimester due to risk of premature ductus arteriosus closure and oligohydramnios; valproate is teratogenic; triptans have the most human pregnancy data supporting safety when needed (≤100 mg sumatriptan).
• The goal is effective abortive relief without introducing teratogenicity or fetal hemodynamic compromise.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Oral sumatriptan is correct because:
• Sumatriptan (5-HT1B/1D agonist) aborts migraine by cranial vasoconstriction and inhibiting trigeminal neurotransmitter release.
• Multiple prospective cohort studies (e.g., MacGregor et al., 2011; Källén & Otterblad Olausson, 2015) totaling >2,000 exposed pregnancies show no increased risk of major congenital malformations or adverse perinatal outcomes.
• American Headache Society 2015 consensus and European Headache Federation 2021 guidelines designate sumatriptan first-line for acute migraine in pregnancy (Level B evidence).
• Sumatriptan’s placental transfer is modest (20–30%), and elimination half-life (~2 h) allows rapid maternal clearance.
• By contrast, NSAIDs in third trimester increase fetal pulmonary hypertension risk; valproate carries a 9–10% neural tube defect risk and cognitive impairment; ketorolac shares NSAID-related fetal risks.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Oral ibuprofen
• NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis; third-trimester use can cause premature ductus arteriosus closure and oligohydramnios.
• Misconception: “All over-the-counter analgesics are safe in pregnancy.”
• Key differentiator: safe only until 30 weeks, then contraindicated.

C. Intravenous valproic acid
• Valproate is a potent teratogen (neural tube defects, facial dysmorphism, cognitive delay).
• Misconception: “Severe migraine justifies use of any IV agent.”
• Key differentiator: absolute contraindication in pregnancy.

D. Intramuscular ketorolac
• Another NSAID with similar third-trimester risks as ibuprofen (ductus closure, bleeding, oligohydramnios).
• Misconception: “Parenteral route avoids systemic fetal effects.”
• Key differentiator: route does not eliminate prostaglandin‐mediated fetal risk.

Comparison Table

FeatureSumatriptanIbuprofen (3rd tri)Valproic AcidKetorolac (IM, 3rd tri)
Mechanism5-HT1B/1D agonistCOX-1/2 inhibitorGABA transaminase inhibitionCOX-1/2 inhibitor
Fetal safety (3rd tri)Category C, no signal for malformationsCategory D: ductal closure, oligohydramniosCategory D/X: teratogenicCategory D: same as ibuprofen
Onset (PO/IM/IV)30–60 min PO1–2 h PO20–30 min IV30–60 min IM
Board recommendationFirst-line acute therapyAvoid after 30 weeksContraindicatedAvoid after 30 weeks

Clinical Pearls

- Triptans (especially sumatriptan) have the most robust pregnancy safety data among migraine abortives.
• NSAIDs are acceptable in the first and second trimesters but should be discontinued by 30 weeks’ gestation.
• Always review drug half-life and placental transfer when prescribing in pregnancy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming over-the-counter NSAIDs are safe throughout pregnancy – they aren’t in the third trimester.
2. Believing all migraine abortives cross the placenta equally – triptans have lower fetal exposure than many analgesics.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society, “Headache Management in Pregnancy and Lactation” (Cephalalgia, 2015): Recommends sumatriptan as first-line abortive in pregnancy (Level B evidence).
• European Headache Federation, “Guideline on Migraine Management” (J Headache Pain, 2021): Endorses sumatriptan safety in pregnancy and lactation (Level A/B evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Sumatriptan dosing: 50–100 mg PO; may repeat after 2 h (max 200 mg/24 h).
• Mechanism: vasoconstriction of dilated intracranial arteries and inhibition of trigeminal nociceptive neurotransmission.
• Safety: low placental transfer, rapid maternal clearance, no significant teratogenic signal.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam.
Pregnancy-related migraine management is frequently tested as single-best-answer scenarios focusing on pharmacologic safety by trimester.

question_text: A male presents with an occipital headache radiating to the frontal area. On examination, he has tenderness over the occipital protuberance, and the headache worsens with head movement. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Occipital neuralgia is characterized by paroxysmal, sharp or stabbing pain in the distribution of the greater (C2) and/or lesser (C3) occipital nerves. Key concepts:
• Anatomy: The greater occipital nerve emerges from the dorsal ramus of C2, courses between semispinalis capitis and trapezius, and innervates the posterior scalp to the vertex.
• Pathophysiology: Entrapment or irritation of the nerve at fibrous or muscular tunnels leads to focal inflammation, demyelination, and ectopic discharges.
• Clinical examination: Reproduction of pain by palpation 2 cm lateral to the external occipital protuberance, and exacerbation with cervical motion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Occipital nerve block is both diagnostic and therapeutic. The 2019 American Headache Society consensus (Level A evidence) and a meta-analysis (Martinez et al., Headache 2021) demonstrate that injections of 1–2 mL 1% lidocaine combined with a corticosteroid provide significant pain relief in over 70% of patients at 4-week follow-up, with effect durations up to 3 months. By delivering local anesthetic and anti‐inflammatory steroid directly to the perineural space, the block interrupts nociceptive input and reduces perineural edema. Systemic medications (e.g., carbamazepine) have lower response rates and more systemic side effects, while NSAIDs and physical therapy address musculoskeletal contributors but do not target the underlying neuralgia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Carbamazepine
• Why incorrect: Primarily first‐line for trigeminal neuralgia; limited evidence in occipital neuralgia, with <30% response in small case series.
• Misconception: Extrapolating trigeminal neuralgia management to occipital neuralgia.
• Differentiator: Occipital neuralgia responds better to targeted perineural injections than systemic sodium‐channel blockade.

C. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
• Why incorrect: NSAIDs reduce prostaglandin‐mediated inflammation in joints and muscles but do not address neural ectopic discharges or perineural inflammation.
• Misconception: All headache pain is inflammatory and amenable to NSAIDs.
• Differentiator: Neuropathic pain requires nerve‐specific intervention.

D. Physical therapy
• Why incorrect: PT may improve cervical range of motion and muscle tension but has no direct effect on nerve inflammation or ectopic firing.
• Misconception: Mechanical neck pain therapy suffices for neuralgic pain.
• Differentiator: Occipital neuralgia demands perineural blockade for definitive relief.

Comparison Table

FeatureNerve Block (Correct)CarbamazepineNSAIDsPhysical Therapy
MechanismLocal anesthetic ± steroid reduces perineural inflammation & blocks ectopic dischargeNa⁺-channel blockade (systemic)COX inhibition, reduces prostaglandinsMuscle stretching, range‐of‐motion
Onset of reliefMinutes–hoursDays–weeksHoursWeeks
TargetOccipital nerve rootsCentral neuronal hyperexcitabilityMusculoskeletal inflammationCervical musculature
Evidence in occipital neuralgiaLevel A (AHS consensus, RCTs/meta-analyses)Level C (case reports, off-label)No direct evidenceAdjunctive, no RCTs
RoleDiagnostic & therapeuticAdjunct or refractory casesIneffective for neuropathic generatorsSupportive

Clinical Pearls

• Palpation 1–2 cm lateral and 1 cm inferior to the external occipital protuberance reproduces pain in >90% of occipital neuralgia patients.
• Ultrasound‐guided occipital nerve blocks increase accuracy and reduce inadvertent vascular injection.
• Pulsed radiofrequency treatment is an option for patients with recurrent pain despite repeated blocks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Misdiagnosing occipital neuralgia as migraine when pain radiates frontally, leading to ineffective triptan therapy.
• Relying solely on systemic NSAIDs or muscle relaxants, delaying nerve‐targeted intervention and prolonging patient suffering.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Headache Society Consensus Statement 2019: Recommends occipital nerve block as Level A intervention for occipital neuralgia (Grade 1A evidence).
• European Federation of Neurological Societies Guidelines 2018: Classify occipital nerve block as Level B evidence, citing randomized trials showing significant pain reduction at 4–12 weeks post‐injection.

Board Examination Focus

"This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam."
Occipital neuralgia frequently appears as short‐stem vignettes testing recognition of nerve distribution and the role of targeted nerve blocks. It is tested in approximately 5–7% of headache questions, often emphasizing anatomical localization and procedural management.

question_text: What is the treatment for an acute attack of short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks (SUNCT/SUNA) are classified under trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) in the ICHD-3. They present as high-frequency (up to 200/day), very brief (1–600 s) stabs of periorbital pain with ipsilateral autonomic signs (conjunctival injection, lacrimation). Pathophysiologically, they involve hyperexcitability of trigeminal nociceptive pathways and a dysfunctional trigemino-parasympathetic reflex. Distinction from paroxysmal hemicrania (indomethacin-responsive) and trigeminal neuralgia (electric-shock quality, refractory period) is critical for targeted acute management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lidocaine exerts its abortive effect by blocking voltage-gated sodium channels in both the trigeminal ganglion and nucleus caudalis, rapidly suppressing ectopic discharges. In an open-label series (Lambru et al., Cephalalgia 2015), IV lidocaine infusions at 2–5 mg/min achieved >80% reduction in attack frequency within minutes. The European Headache Federation Consensus Statement on TACs (2019) and the American Headache Society Clinical Practice Guideline (2022) both recommend IV lidocaine as first-line acute therapy for SUNCT/SUNA (Level B/Grade 2B). Continuous cardiac monitoring is mandatory due to risk of arrhythmias. Alternative IV agents, such as phenytoin, show lower efficacy and higher toxicity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Indomethacin
– Indomethacin responsiveness is pathognomonic for paroxysmal hemicrania/hemicrania continua, not SUNCT/SUNA, reflecting distinct COX-mediated pain pathways.
– Misconception: all TACs respond to indomethacin.

C. Gabapentin
– Modulates α2δ calcium channels and is used for neuropathic pain prevention, but has no role in aborting SUNCT attacks acutely.
– Lacks rapid onset; any preventive benefit is anecdotal.

D. Topiramate
– Works via GABAergic potentiation and glutamatergic inhibition; used as a preventive agent requiring slow titration over weeks.
– Ineffective for immediate relief of brief, high-frequency SUNCT attacks.

Comparison Table

FeatureLidocaine (IV)IndomethacinGabapentinTopiramate
MechanismNa⁺ channel blockadeCOX-1/2 inhibitionα2δ subunit VGCC modGABA↑/glutamate↓
RoleAcute abortive therapyPreventive (PH)Preventive/off-labelPreventive
Onset of actionMinutesHours–daysDays–weeksWeeks
Evidence levelIIb/B (EHF 2019, AHS 2022)Ia/A (PH IHS 2018)III/CIII/C

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate IV lidocaine infusion at 2–5 mg/min under ECG and hemodynamic monitoring; titrate to clinical effect or maximum dose of ~300 mg.
• Intranasal or perilesional lidocaine has been reported in refractory cases but carries risk of local toxicity.
• For prevention, consider lamotrigine or topiramate only after abortive control; prophylactics take weeks to titrate.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mistaking SUNCT for paroxysmal hemicrania and administering indomethacin, which fails to abort SUNCT attacks.
• Attempting to abort SUNCT with preventive agents (e.g., topiramate), leading to uncontrolled pain and frequent emergency visits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Headache Federation Consensus Statement on Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgias (2019): Recommends IV lidocaine (Level B) as first-line acute therapy for SUNCT/SUNA.
• American Headache Society Clinical Practice Guideline (2022): Endorses IV lidocaine infusion (Grade 2B) for acute management of SUNCT; advises against indomethacin in SUNCT (Grade 1A for PH).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. Acute management of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias—particularly the use of IV lidocaine for SUNCT/SUNA—is frequently tested in single-best-answer format on neurology board examinations.

question_text: Q3. A case scenario of trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is presented, where the condition is triggered by touching his face and he also has lacrimation. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 1 2020] Trigeminal neuralgia arises from dysfunction of the trigeminal (cranial V) nerve, often due to vascular compression at the root entry zone causing focal demyelination and “ephaptic” cross‐talk. Clinically it presents with brief (<2 min) paroxysms of electric shock–like pain in one or more V1–V3 divisions, reproducibly triggered by innocuous stimuli (“trigger zones”) such as light touch, shaving or speaking. Although autonomic signs (lacrimation, conjunctival injection) are characteristic of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias, mild lacrimation can occur in TN due to reflex parasympathetic activation. Differentiation from other facial pain syndromes relies on attack duration, quality, triggers, associated signs and history (e.g., rash in postherpetic neuralgia or joint findings in TMJ disorder).

(Word count: 136)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Trigeminal neuralgia is defined by the International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) as “recurrent paroxysms of unilateral facial pain in the trigeminal distribution with at least three triggerable attacks.” The hallmark is shock‐like pain lasting seconds, reproducibly elicited by触发 stimuli. Vascular compression—often by the superior cerebellar artery—induces focal demyelination; MRI neurovascular imaging detects this in >80% of classical TN cases (Maarbjerg et al., Neurology 2015). European Academy of Neurology/EFNS guidelines (2019) and AAN/CNS guidelines (2018) recommend carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine as first-line therapy (Level A evidence). Autonomic features are generally mild in TN, distinguishing it from trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias, where lacrimation is more pronounced and pains last longer (15–180 min).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Cluster Headache
• Incorrect because attacks last 15–180 min (not seconds) and occur in clusters over weeks.
• Misconception: any facial pain with lacrimation is cluster headache.
• Differentiator: cluster pain is deep orbital, untriggered by touch, with restlessness.

C. Postherpetic Neuralgia
• Incorrect: follows varicella-zoster eruption; constant burning pain >3 months.
• Misconception: any neuropathic facial pain is postherpetic.
• Differentiator: dermatome‐specific rash history and allodynia, not brief shock-like paroxysms.

D. Temporomandibular Joint Disorder
• Incorrect: presents with dull, aching pain exacerbated by jaw movement, with joint sounds/tenderness.
• Misconception: facial pain always originates in the TMJ.
• Differentiator: no electric shock quality or trigger zones on non‐mastication stimuli.

Comparison Table

FeatureTrigeminal NeuralgiaCluster HeadachePostherpetic NeuralgiaTMJ Disorder
Pain qualityElectric shock–likeDeep, pressure‐likeBurning, constantDull, aching
DurationSeconds (<2 min)15–180 minHours to continuousHours, related to jaw use
TriggersLight touch, shaving, speakingSpontaneous; alcoholNone (post‐rash allodynia)Chewing, clenching
Autonomic signsMild lacrimation (reflexive)Prominent lacrimation, rhinorrheaNoNo
HistoryNo rash, sudden paroxysmsCluster pattern, seasonal tendencyShingles with rashTMJ click, limited mouth opening

Clinical Pearls

• Carbamazepine response can be diagnostic: >50% pain reduction within 1 week supports TN.
• Always obtain brain MRI with high‐resolution trigeminal views to exclude secondary causes (MS plaque, tumors).
• In refractory TN, microvascular decompression provides durable relief in 70–80% of classical cases (Love & Coakham, J Neurosurg 2001).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Overemphasizing autonomic signs: mild lacrimation in TN does not equal a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia.
2. Neglecting trigger zones: failure to ask about precipitating touch may lead to misdiagnosis as atypical facial pain.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• AAN/CNS (2018): Strong recommendation (Level A) for carbamazepine/oxcarbazepine as first-line TN therapy.
• EFNS/European Academy of Neurology (2019): MRI evaluation of the root entry zone (Grade 1B) and early consideration of surgical decompression if medication–refractory.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 1 2020 exam. Trigeminal neuralgia is frequently tested on neuroanatomy (root entry zone), pain syndromes, and first-line pharmacotherapy (carbamazepine) in short‐stem vignettes.

question_text: In SUNCT, what are the minimum ipsilateral autonomic symptoms?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2019] SUNCT (Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache with Conjunctival injection and Tearing) is one of the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs).
• The trigeminal nerve’s ophthalmic division (V1) activation triggers reflex parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and pterygopalatine ganglion, producing cranial autonomic signs.
• SUNCT is defined by very short attacks (1–600 seconds) of severe orbital or periorbital pain occurring ≥20 times/day, always accompanied by conjunctival injection and lacrimation.
• Differentiation from SUNA (which may present with any other autonomic signs) hinges on these two mandatory features.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) stipulates that SUNCT requires both conjunctival injection AND ipsilateral lacrimation during attacks. This dual-feature mandate is reflected in the acronym itself (“CT”). Pathophysiologically, intense activation of the trigeminal–parasympathetic reflex leads to vasodilation of conjunctival vessels and increased lacrimal gland secretion. No other single or paired autonomic signs can fulfil SUNCT criteria; their presence instead points toward SUNA or other TAC variants. Multiple cohort studies (e.g., Lambru et al., Cephalalgia 2016) confirm that >95% of confirmed SUNCT patients exhibit both injection and tearing, with other autonomic features being variable and non-essential for diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Nasal congestion and rhinorrhea
• Incorrect because these represent parasympathetic outflow to nasal mucosa but are not sufficient for SUNCT; they are seen in SUNA or cluster headache.
• Misconception: Any pair of autonomic signs qualifies; differentiation requires “CT.”

C. Eyelid edema and miosis
• Incorrect: Eyelid edema may occur, but miosis is a sympathetic sign—uncommon in pure parasympathetic–driven SUNCT.
• Misconception: All autonomic signs cluster together; SUNCT is parasympathetic-dominant.

D. Forehead sweating and ptosis
• Incorrect: Forehead sweating is sympathetic overactivity, ptosis implies sympathetic underactivity. Neither defines SUNCT.
• Misconception: TACs necessarily include mixed autonomic features; SUNCT is strictly “CT.”

Comparison Table

FeatureConjunctival Injection & LacrimationNasal Congestion & RhinorrheaEyelid Edema & MiosisForehead Sweating & Ptosis
ICHD-3 minimum requirement for SUNCTMandatoryNot sufficientNot sufficientNot sufficient
Autonomic pathwayTrigeminal → SSN → PterygopalatineTrigeminal nasal branchMixed parasympatheticSympathetic alteration
Presence in SUNAMay occur in SUNACommon in SUNARareRare
Reflects acronym (“CT”)YesNoNoNo

Clinical Pearls

- SUNCT attacks are extremely frequent (up to hundreds/day) but ultrashort (1–600 seconds).
• Always confirm BOTH conjunctival injection and tearing; absence of either reclassifies the headache as SUNA.
• Lamotrigine is first-line preventive therapy for SUNCT; ensure accurate diagnosis before initiating.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming any autonomic feature pair suffices for SUNCT; only “CT” qualify.
2. Confusing SUNCT with cluster headache based on lacrimation alone; cluster requires ≥15 minutes duration and other features.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society (IHS), ICHD-3 (2018): Defines SUNCT diagnostic criteria requiring both conjunctival injection and lacrimation (Level: expert consensus).
2. European Headache Federation (EHF) Clinical Recommendation (2021): Reaffirms SUNCT autonomic criteria per ICHD-3 and endorses lamotrigine as first-line preventive (Level: C).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2019 exam. SUNCT’s defining autonomic features (“CT”) are a high-yield topic on neurology boards, often tested in classification and differential diagnosis formats.

question_text: What is the treatment for hypnic headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Hypnic headache is a rare primary headache disorder characterized by strictly nocturnal attacks that awaken patients from sleep—often called “alarm clock headache.” It typically affects adults over 50 and lasts 15–180 minutes. Key concepts:
• Circadian dysregulation: dysfunction of the suprachiasmatic nucleus and melatonin secretion leads to nocturnal pain.
• ICHD-3 classification: hypnic headache is distinguished by absence of cranial autonomic features and consistent sleep onset timing.
• Chronobiotic therapy: agents that modulate circadian rhythms (e.g., lithium) are most effective prophylactically, whereas acute treatments like caffeine can abort attacks.

(Word count: 107)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lithium carbonate is the established first-line prophylactic for hypnic headache. It likely stabilizes circadian oscillators within the hypothalamus by modulating GSK-3β activity and melatonin secretion.
• Leone et al. (Headache 2002) conducted an open-label trial in 20 patients, demonstrating a ≥50% reduction in attack frequency in 80% on 200–600 mg nightly.
• The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd ed. (ICHD-3, 2018) lists lithium carbonate 200–600 mg at bedtime as Level C (consensus) prophylaxis.
• European Headache Federation (2019) guidelines recommend lithium first-line with evidence from small RCTs and open studies (Level B).
Acute abortive options (e.g., caffeine) may be used adjunctively, but no placebo-controlled RCT has shown benefit for oxygen, amitriptyline, or indomethacin in hypnic headache.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Oxygen
• Why incorrect: No trials support oxygen for hypnic headache; its efficacy is limited to cluster headache via trigeminal autonomic reflex vasoconstriction.
• Misconception: Equating nocturnal headache with cluster headache.
• Differentiation: Hypnic headaches lack autonomic signs and are not relieved by high-flow O₂.

C. Amitriptyline
• Why incorrect: Tricyclics have anecdotal reports in chronic tension-type headache but fail to prevent hypnic episodes.
• Misconception: Using broad-spectrum prophylactics across all primary headaches.
• Differentiation: Amitriptyline’s anticholinergic effects disrupt sleep architecture and may worsen nocturnal awakenings.

D. Indomethacin
• Why incorrect: Indomethacin-responsive headaches include hemicrania continua and paroxysmal hemicrania, not hypnic headache.
• Misconception: Treating any unusual headache with indomethacin to test for indomethacin-responsive syndromes.
• Differentiation: Hypnic headache shows no indomethacin response, and indomethacin carries GI/renal toxicity without benefit.

Comparison Table

TreatmentMechanismEfficacy in Hypnic HeadacheKey Differentiation
LithiumChronobiotic: GSK-3β modulation, melatonin stabilizationHigh (60–80% responder rate)First-line prophylaxis
OxygenVasoconstriction via trigeminal autonomic reflexNone in hypnic headacheEffective only in cluster headache
AmitriptylineSerotonin/norepinephrine reuptake inhibition; anticholinergicNo significant prophylactic effectUsed in tension-type headache
IndomethacinCOX-1/2 inhibition; prostaglandin reductionNo effect—hypnic headache is indomethacin-resistantDiagnostic for indomethacin-responsive headaches

Clinical Pearls

• Hypnic headache exclusively occurs during sleep in older adults; consider a trial of 1 cup of coffee (40–65 mg caffeine) at attack onset if lithium is contraindicated.
• Begin lithium at 200 mg nightly, titrate to 600 mg based on response and serum levels (target 0.4–0.8 mmol/L).
• Monitor thyroid and renal function every 6–12 months due to lithium’s narrow therapeutic index.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling hypnic headache as cluster headache because both awaken patients at night—key differentiator: hypnic lacks autonomic symptoms and has longer duration.
2. Empiric trial of indomethacin for all rare headaches—failure to recognize indomethacin-responsive vs. nonresponsive syndromes delays proper prophylaxis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society. International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd ed. (ICHD-3), 2018. Recommendation: Lithium carbonate 200–600 mg at bedtime for hypnic headache prophylaxis (Level C – consensus).
2. European Headache Federation. Evidence-Based Guideline on Treatment of Rare Headache Disorders, 2019. Recommendation: Lithium as first-line therapy for hypnic headache (Level B – open studies and small RCTs); caffeine 40–65 mg as alternative acute abortive.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Hypnic headache originates from dysregulation of the suprachiasmatic nucleus in the anterior hypothalamus, disrupting normal melatonin rhythms and sleep–wake cycle control.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

• Circadian oscillator dysfunction: aberrant firing in the suprachiasmatic nucleus.
• Neurotransmitters: altered melatonin and adenosine signaling mediate nocturnal pain thresholds.
• Chronobiotic agents (lithium) reset malfunctioning circadian pacemakers.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed sleep and headache diary.
2. Apply ICHD-3 criteria: ≥10 nocturnal attacks, 15–180 min duration, age >50.
3. Exclude secondary causes with MRI brain.
4. Trial caffeine abortive; assess response.
5. Initiate lithium prophylaxis; monitor therapeutic levels.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI is typically normal in hypnic headache but is essential to exclude structural lesions such as nocturnal temporal lobe epilepsy or tumor-induced pain.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Lithium carbonate: start 200 mg at bedtime, increase by 200 mg increments every 1–2 weeks up to 600 mg; monitor serum levels (0.4–0.8 mmol/L), renal and thyroid function. Acute caffeine: 40–65 mg at onset, up to 2 doses.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Hypnic headache treatment is a high-yield topic, often tested as a single best-answer question on rare headache syndromes and chronobiotic prophylaxis.

question_text: Q1. What is the physiology of cluster headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] Cluster headache is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by severe unilateral periorbital pain with ipsilateral autonomic features (lacrimation, rhinorrhea, ptosis). Core to its pathophysiology is abnormal activation of the posterior hypothalamus, a circadian pacemaker regulating sleep–wake cycles and hormonal release. The posterior hypothalamus interfaces via the trigeminohypothalamic tract with the spinal trigeminal nucleus and via the superior salivatory nucleus with the sphenopalatine ganglion, triggering parasympathetic outflow and neuropeptide release (CGRP, substance P). Functional neuroimaging (PET, fMRI) during attacks consistently demonstrates focal hyperactivity in the ipsilateral posterior hypothalamus, distinguishing cluster headache from migraine and other trigeminal pain syndromes.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ipsilateral posterior hypothalamic activation is the primary generator in cluster headache. Positron emission tomography by May et al. (1998) revealed a 25% increase in blood flow in the posterior hypothalamic gray matter ipsilateral to the pain during spontaneous attacks. Functional MRI studies (Matharu et al., 2004) confirmed this activation correlates with attack onset and periodicity. The hypothalamus exerts control over the trigeminal-autonomic reflex: projections to the spinal trigeminal nucleus facilitate nociceptive signaling, while connections to the superior salivatory nucleus produce parasympathetic outflow via the sphenopalatine ganglion. The European Headache Federation (EHF) 2018 consensus endorses hypothalamic deep brain stimulation (DBS) in refractory cases (level C evidence), underscoring the hypothalamus as a therapeutic target.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Imbalance neurotraumatic in the trigeminal nerve
• Incorrect because cluster headache is not due to peripheral trigeminal nerve trauma or demyelination.
• Misconception: conflates cluster headache with trigeminal neuralgia (neurovascular compression).
• Differentiator: neuroimaging localizes the generator centrally in the hypothalamus, not at the trigeminal root entry zone.

B. Brainstem change modulation
• Incorrect because although brainstem nuclei modulate pain, they are not the primary generator.
• Misconception: equates cluster headache with migraine, where the periaqueductal gray is implicated.
• Differentiator: functional studies show distinct posterior hypothalamic hyperactivity rather than periaqueductal gray change.

D. Dysfunction of the autonomic nervous system
• Incorrect because autonomic signs are a consequence of the trigeminal-autonomic reflex, not the root pathology.
• Misconception: views cluster headache as a primary autonomic neuropathy.
• Differentiator: autonomic activation is downstream of hypothalamic-triggered parasympathetic outflow, not an isolated ANS disorder.

Comparison Table

FeatureIpsilateral Hypothalamus (C)Trigeminal Nerve Imbalance (A)Brainstem Modulation (B)Autonomic Dysfunction (D)
Primary generator locationPosterior hypothalamusPeripheral trigeminal nerveBrainstem pain modulatory centersAutonomic ganglia / ANS
Functional imagingPET/fMRI activation ipsilateral to painNo specific focal changeNo consistent focal activationNon-localized ANS changes
Circadian rhythm involvementCentral pacemaker driving attack periodicityNoneIndirect modulationNone
Target for invasive therapyHypothalamic DBSNot applicableRare experimental targetsNot effective as standalone therapy

Clinical Pearls

1. High-flow oxygen (12–15 L/min via non-rebreather mask) aborts ≥70% of cluster attacks within 15 minutes by inhibiting trigeminal nociceptive transmission.
2. Verapamil is first-line prophylaxis, titrated up to 720 mg/day; perform ECG monitoring for PR prolongation.
3. Ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis) during attacks helps differentiate cluster headache from migraine.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Misdiagnosing cluster headache as migraine leads to overuse of oral triptans and risk of medication-overuse headache.
• Attributing autonomic features to a primary ANS disorder can delay effective abortive therapy such as oxygen or subcutaneous sumatriptan.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Headache Federation Consensus (2018): Recommends high-flow oxygen (level A) and verapamil prophylaxis (level B); supports hypothalamic DBS for refractory cases (level C).
• American Headache Society Position Statement (2021): Endorses galcanezumab (CGRP monoclonal antibody) for episodic cluster headache prophylaxis based on phase III RCT (level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The posterior inferior hypothalamus contains orexinergic and vasopressinergic neurons that project to the spinal trigeminal nucleus (trigeminohypothalamic tract) and to the superior salivatory nucleus, which then relay parasympathetic fibers via the facial nerve and sphenopalatine ganglion to cranial vasculature.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. Hypothalamic pacemaker overactivation triggers nociceptive signals in the spinal trigeminal nucleus.
2. Concurrent activation of superior salivatory nucleus induces parasympathetic outflow, causing cranial vasodilation and autonomic symptoms.
3. Neuropeptide release (CGRP, substance P) amplifies vascular and nociceptive responses.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: severe unilateral periorbital pain, 15–180 min, up to 8/day, with autonomic signs.
2. Examination: look for ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome.
3. Imaging: MRI with pituitary protocol if atypical features present.
4. Confirm primary cluster pattern via headache diaries.
5. Initiate abortive (O2, subcutaneous sumatriptan) and prophylactic (verapamil) therapies.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Functional imaging (PET, fMRI) demonstrates ipsilateral posterior hypothalamic activation during attacks. Structural MRI is generally normal but is indicated to exclude secondary causes (e.g., pituitary adenoma) if atypical.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Abortive: High-flow oxygen; subcutaneous sumatriptan 6 mg.
• Transitional: Prednisone taper (60 mg PO ×5 days, then taper).
• Preventive: Verapamil (240–960 mg/day with ECG monitoring); lithium (0.4–0.8 mmol/L); galcanezumab 300 mg monthly.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam. Cluster headache pathophysiology—particularly ipsilateral posterior hypothalamic involvement—is frequently tested on neurology board examinations, often via functional imaging findings, DBS indications, and treatment algorithms.

question_text: What is the main neurotransmitter involved in migraine headaches?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] Migraine is a primary headache disorder driven by abnormal neuronal excitability and vascular changes. Key concepts include:
• Trigeminovascular system: activation of trigeminal afferents causes release of vasoactive peptides.
• Serotonergic modulation: serotonin influences vascular tone and nociceptive transmission via 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors.
• Neurogenic inflammation: neuropeptides (e.g., CGRP) promote vasodilation and plasma extravasation.
Understanding these principles helps integrate how neurotransmitters orchestrate headache initiation and guide targeted therapies.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine, 5-HT) is central to migraine pathophysiology: activation of presynaptic 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors on trigeminal neurons inhibits release of CGRP and glutamate, reducing vasodilation and nociception (Goadsby et al., 2017). Triptans, potent 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists, remain first-line acute treatment per American Headache Society 2015 guidelines (Level A evidence). Platelet serotonin depletion during attacks and altered central serotonergic tone in imaging studies further confirm its role (Ferrari et al., 2010). While CGRP is now recognized as a key peptide mediator (Lassen et al., 2002), serotonin’s modulation of vascular and nociceptive pathways makes it the primary “neurotransmitter” traditionally implicated in migraine.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Glutamate
• Incorrect because, although cortical spreading depression releases glutamate, it is an excitatory amino acid, not the main therapeutic target.
• Misconception: equating excitatory drive with primary mediator.
• Differentiator: glutamate antagonists (e.g., topiramate) are prophylactic, not acute abortive agents.

C. Dopamine
• Dopamine may underlie premonitory symptoms (yawning, nausea) but is not central to headache generation.
• Misconception: associating dopaminergic dysregulation with migraine aura.
• Differentiator: dopamine antagonists (e.g., metoclopramide) treat nausea, not headache itself.

D. GABA
• GABA is inhibitory and may be protective; deficits could predispose to migraine but it is not the primary neurotransmitter.
• Misconception: assuming all inhibitory transmitters counter headache.
• Differentiator: GABAergic agents (e.g., benzodiazepines) are not standard migraine therapies.

Comparison Table

NeurotransmitterRole in Migraine PathophysiologyTherapeutic Target Agents
SerotoninModulates vascular tone, inhibits CGRP release via 5-HT₁B/₁DTriptans (sumatriptan), Lasmiditan
GlutamateDrives cortical spreading depressionTopiramate (prophylactic)
DopamineMediates premonitory features (nausea, yawning)Antiemetics (metoclopramide)
GABAGeneral inhibitory tone, not headache-specificNot utilized acutely or preventively

Clinical Pearls

- Triptans are selective 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists; avoid in uncontrolled hypertension or ischemic heart disease.
• Serum serotonin levels drop during migraine attacks; rebound increases can trigger aura-like phenomena with SSRIs.
• Newer ditans (lasmiditan) target 5-HT₁F, avoiding vasoconstriction, beneficial in cardiovascular risk patients.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating CGRP (a neuropeptide) with “neurotransmitter” – CGRP is central but pharmacologically distinct.
2. Presuming dopamine agonists abort headache – in reality, dopaminergic blockers treat associated symptoms, not pain.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society (2021): Endorses gepants (CGRP receptor antagonists) and ditans for acute migraine with Level B evidence.
2. European Headache Federation (2022): Recommends early triptan use within 2 hours of onset; Level A evidence for 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists in moderate–severe attacks.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine pain arises from activation of first-order neurons in the trigeminal ganglion projecting to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis. Serotonergic neurons in the dorsal raphe modulate this pathway.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

1. Cortical spreading depression → neuronal depolarization cascade.
2. Trigeminovascular activation → serotonin receptor–mediated inhibition or excitation.
3. Release of CGRP, substance P → vasodilation, plasma extravasation, pain.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Apply ICHD-3 criteria: ≥5 attacks, 4–72 h, unilateral throbbing, nausea, photophobia.
2. Rule out red flags: neuroimaging only if atypical features, focal deficits, systemic signs.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Routine imaging is normal; MRI/MRA indicated for late-onset or progressive headache, abrupt “thunderclap” onset, or focal neuro deficits.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acute: triptans (5-HT₁B/₁D agonists), lasmiditan, gepants.
• Preventive: beta-blockers, anticonvulsants (topiramate), CGRP monoclonal antibodies.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam. Migraine neurotransmitter questions are frequently tested in single-best-answer format, often linking pathophysiology to triptan mechanism.

question_text: Q66. What is a contraindication for using NSAIDs in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2022] 1. NSAID pharmacology: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs inhibit cyclo-oxygenase (COX-1 and COX-2), reducing prostaglandin synthesis. In migraine, they relieve pain by decreasing neurogenic inflammation.
2. Fetal circulation: Prostaglandin E₂ maintains patency of the ductus arteriosus in utero. Inhibition of prostaglandins in the third trimester leads to ductal constriction and closure, precipitating neonatal pulmonary hypertension.
3. Teratogenic timing: First-trimester exposures risk malformations; third-trimester exposures risk hemodynamic complications (e.g., oligohydramnios, ductal closure). NSAIDs are generally safe in early pregnancy but contraindicated after 30 weeks.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus (Option B) is the only true contraindication to NSAID use in late pregnancy. Prostaglandins—particularly PGE₂—are critical for ductal patency. COX inhibition by NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen, naproxen) after 30 weeks gestation reduces PGE₂ levels, causing ductal constriction. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG, 2017) and the FDA (Drug Safety Communication, 2020) recommend avoidance of NSAIDs beyond 32 weeks. A prospective cohort study (Davis et al., J Matern Fetal Neonatal Med 2018) demonstrated a 2.5-fold increased risk of ductal constriction when NSAIDs were used after 32 weeks. This hemodynamic insult can precipitate persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Risk of headache
– NSAIDs are frontline for tension-type headaches and mild-to-moderate migraines; headache is a treated symptom, not an adverse effect.
– Misconception: confusing rebound headache with drug contraindication.

C. Increased risk of nausea
– Gastrointestinal upset is a known side effect of NSAIDs but not specific to third trimester or a contraindication.
– Key differentiator: nausea does not involve fetal hemodynamics.

D. Ineffectiveness in treating migraines
– NSAIDs are effective abortive agents for mild-to-moderate migraine attacks.
– Misconception: assuming all analgesics lose efficacy in pregnancy.

Comparison Table

OptionMechanism/EffectRelevance in 3rd Trimester
Premature closure of ductus↓ PGE₂ → ductus arteriosus constriction → PPHNProven contraindication; avoid NSAIDs after 30–32 weeks
Risk of headacheHeadache is indication, not adverse effectNot a contraindication; NSAIDs treat headaches
Increased risk of nauseaGI mucosal irritation via COX-1 inhibitionCommon side effect at any gestation; not trimester-specific
Ineffectiveness for migrainesNSAIDs block CGRP-mediated inflammationProven efficacy in mild-to-moderate migraines

Clinical Pearls

• Avoid NSAIDs (including ibuprofen, indomethacin) after 30 weeks to prevent premature ductal closure and oligohydramnios.
• First-line analgesics in late pregnancy for headache are acetaminophen and non-pharmacologic measures.
• Monitor fetal echocardiography if inadvertent NSAID exposure occurs in the third trimester.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating side effects (nausea, headache) with fetal contraindications; only fetal hemodynamic effects matter in late pregnancy.
2. Forgetting the gestational age window—NSAIDs are safe in the first and second trimesters but contraindicated late.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ACOG Committee Opinion No. 775 (2017): Recommends discontinuing NSAIDs after 32 weeks due to risk of ductal constriction (Level B evidence).
2. FDA Drug Safety Communication (2020): Advises against use of NSAIDs after 20 weeks for oligohydramnios risk and after 30 weeks for ductal closure (based on observational studies).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• COX-1 vs. COX-2 inhibition: Both isoforms contribute to PGE₂ synthesis in the fetal ductus.
• Dosing: Even a single dose of indomethacin in late pregnancy can cause significant ductal constriction.
• Alternatives: Acetaminophen is the safest analgesic choice throughout pregnancy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2022 exam.
NSAID use in pregnancy is frequently tested as a pharmacology/obstetrics crossover, often focusing on timing-dependent fetal risks such as ductus arteriosus constriction and oligohydramnios.

question_text: A young man has a history of headaches lasting 15–20 minutes, located over his orbit, associated with nasal congestion. His wife reports that he becomes irritated and angry during these episodes. What is the best treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] Cluster headache is the prototypical trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by:
• Excruciating, strictly unilateral orbital or temporal pain lasting 15–180 minutes.
• Ipsilateral cranial autonomic features (lacrimation, nasal congestion, ptosis).
• Restlessness or agitation during attacks implicating hypothalamic and trigeminovascular activation.
Pathophysiology involves trigeminal nerve activation with parasympathetic reflex via the sphenopalatine ganglion. Attacks occur in circadian and circannual patterns. Acute abortive therapy aims to abort pain rapidly; prophylaxis targets attack frequency.

Evidence-Based Analysis

High-flow 100% oxygen at ≥12 L/min via non-rebreather mask for 15 minutes aborts attacks in ~70–80% of patients within 15 minutes (Cohen et al., Cephalalgia 2009). The American Headache Society (AHS) 2019 guidelines assign Level A evidence for oxygen as first-line abortive therapy in cluster headache, citing randomized trials (Siekierka-Jarosz et al., Headache 2015). Oxygen’s mechanism likely involves cerebral vasoconstriction and inhibition of trigeminovascular nociception. Compared to subcutaneous sumatriptan, oxygen has fewer contraindications (no systemic vasoconstriction) and an excellent safety profile.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Indomethacin
• Incorrect because indomethacin is specific for paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua, not cluster headache.
• Misconception: All trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias respond to indomethacin.
• Differentiator: Cluster attacks last 15–180 min vs. paroxysmal hemicrania 2–30 min but respond dramatically to indomethacin only in the latter.

C. Sumatriptan
• Although subcutaneous sumatriptan (6 mg) is an effective abortive option (Level B evidence), it is second-line to oxygen per AHS due to cardiovascular contraindications.
• Misconception: Any acute migraine agent is first-line in cluster headache.
• Differentiator: Sumatriptan carries systemic vasoconstrictive risk, whereas oxygen is safer without vasoconstriction.

D. Verapamil
• Verapamil is the mainstay of prophylaxis, not acute abortive therapy.
• Misconception: Preventive medications relieve acute attacks.
• Differentiator: Verapamil dosing (240–960 mg/day) reduces attack frequency over weeks, with no rapid abortive effect.

Comparison Table

FeatureHigh-Flow Oxygen (B)Sumatriptan (C)Indomethacin (A)Verapamil (D)
Onset of action5–15 minutes10–20 minutesNot effective in clusterNone (preventive only)
Level of evidenceA (AHS 2019)B (AHS 2019)A for paroxysmal hemicraniaA (preventive only)
Safety profileExcellent; no vasoconstrictionContraindicated in CAD/HTNGI and renal side effectsBradycardia, AV block
MechanismCerebral vasoconstriction, trigeminal inhibition5-HT1B/1D agonist; vasoconstrictionCOX inhibitionL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockade
Use in cluster headacheFirst-line abortiveSecond-line abortiveNot indicatedFirst-line prophylaxis

Clinical Pearls

- Always ask about restlessness/agitation; it distinguishes cluster headache from migraine.
• Provide oxygen prescription and a mask for home use; portability kits improve adherence.
• In smokers (≥80% of cluster patients), counsel on cessation—smoking may trigger attacks.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating acute cluster attacks with prophylactic agents (verapamil) leads to persistent pain.
2. Confusing indomethacin-responsive headaches (paroxysmal hemicrania) with cluster headache based solely on duration.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society (AHS) 2019: Oxygen 100% at ≥12 L/min for 15 min is Level A recommendation for abortive therapy in cluster headache.
• European Headache Federation (EHF) 2020: Confirms oxygen as first-line abortive; supports subcutaneous sumatriptan as Level B alternative.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. Cluster headache management is frequently tested on neurology boards as an example of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia requiring oxygen therapy as first-line abortive treatment.

question_text: A 30-year-old female patient, known to have migraine, presented with a new headache unlike her usual migraines for more than 3 months. It is more constant, not associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia, and not improved with usual analgesics. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2023] Headache disorders are classified by the International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 criteria into primary (e.g., migraine, tension-type) and secondary causes. Chronic daily headache (CDH) refers to headache on ≥15 days/month for >3 months and includes chronic migraine, medication-overuse headache (MOH), chronic tension-type, and new daily persistent headache (NDPH).
Key distinctions:
• Onset: NDPH begins abruptly and remains unremitting from day one.
• Associated features: Migraines carry photophobia, phonophobia, nausea; tension-type headaches are pressing/tightening, mild-moderate intensity.
• Medication overuse: Requires >10-15 days/month of specific analgesics for >3 months.
Clinically, a headache that is daily, constant, and qualitatively distinct from a patient’s prior migraines, without migrainous features or analgesic overuse, is most consistent with NDPH.

Evidence-Based Analysis

New daily persistent headache (ICHD-3 code 4.10) is defined by:
1. Clearly remembered onset, with headache becoming continuous and unremitting within 24 hours of onset
2. Present daily and unremitting for >3 months
3. Typically bilateral, pressing or tightening quality, mild-moderate intensity, often without migrainous features
Multiple cohort studies (e.g., Rozen 2019, Cephalalgia) report that NDPH patients often describe abrupt onset after a viral prodrome or stressful event. MRI and lab work are usually normal, helping to exclude secondary causes. Unlike chronic migraine—where headaches evolve from episodic migraine with migrainous features on ≥8 days/month—NDPH lacks associated nausea, photophobia, or phonophobia. The absence of medication overuse (>10 days/month of triptans/NSAIDs) excludes MOH (Schytz 2021, J Headache Pain). Thus, evidence strongly supports NDPH as the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Chronic migraine headache
• Incorrect because chronic migraine requires ≥15 headache days/month for >3 months with migraine features (nausea, photophobia, phonophobia) on ≥8 days/month. This patient’s headaches are non-migraine-type and constant from onset.
• Misconception: any daily headache in a migraineur is chronic migraine.

B. Medications overuse headache
• Incorrect since MOH demands regular overuse of acute headache medications (e.g., triptans, opioids, NSAIDs) on ≥10 days/month (triptans) or ≥15 days/month (NSAIDs) for >3 months. No history of overuse is provided.
• Misconception: failure of usual analgesics implies rebound headache.

D. Tension headache
• Incorrect because chronic tension-type headache (ICHD-3 code 2.3) is bilateral, pressing/tightening, mild to moderate, and can be daily but often fluctuates; it usually improves with relaxation and does not begin abruptly.
• Misconception: absence of migrainous symptoms equals tension-type headache; fails to recognize the abrupt, unremitting nature of NDPH.

Comparison Table

FeatureChronic MigraineMedication Overuse HeadacheNew Daily Persistent HeadacheTension-Type Headache
OnsetGradual transformationVariableAbrupt, clearly rememberedGradual
Duration≥15 days/month, >3 months≥15 days/month, >3 monthsDaily, continuous >3 months≥15 days/month, >3 months
QualityPulsating, moderate–severeVariableSteady, pressing/tighteningPressing/tightening, mild–moderate
Associated featuresNausea, photophobia, etc.Nausea, may mimic migraineTypically noneNo nausea, rare photophobia
Medication useAs neededOveruse established (>10–15 days/month)No overuseAs needed

Clinical Pearls

- NDPH often follows a flu-like illness or major stressor; exact trigger may remain unidentified.
• Early recognition and differentiation from secondary causes (e.g., CVT, low-pressure headache) mandate neuroimaging.
• Standard migraine treatments (triptans, NSAIDs) are usually ineffective in NDPH; some patients benefit from nerve blocks or neuromodulation.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misclassifying all daily headaches in migraineurs as chronic migraine, overlooking the need for migrainous features on most days.
2. Assuming failure of analgesics equates to medication overuse headache without confirming actual overuse patterns.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines NDPH criteria (Level of Evidence: expert consensus).
• American Headache Society, Consensus Statement on Chronic Daily Headache (2022): Recommends MRI to exclude secondary causes in NDPH and a trial of multidisciplinary management (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

NDPH likely involves dysregulation of the trigeminovascular system and central nociceptive pathways, with possible roles for brainstem nuclei (e.g., dorsal raphe) in pain chronification.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

While migraine involves cortical spreading depression, NDPH pathogenesis is unclear; hypotheses include sustained neuroinflammation, cytokine elevation (IL-6, TNF-α), and impaired descending pain inhibition.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: onset (abrupt vs gradual), quality, associated symptoms, medication use
2. Rule out red flags (e.g., papilledema, focal deficits)
3. Neuroimaging (MRI brain with and without contrast)
4. Apply ICHD-3 criteria: confirm new daily persistent pattern >3 months
5. Exclude MOH, chronic migraine, tension-type per criteria

Neuroimaging Pearls

Brain MRI in NDPH is normal in >90% of cases; imaging primarily serves to exclude secondary etiologies (e.g., venous thrombosis).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

No FDA-approved treatments for NDPH. Empiric therapies include:
• Amitriptyline or other TCAs (dose 10–75 mg nightly)
• Gabapentin or topiramate off-label
• Occipital nerve blocks with local anesthetic and steroid for refractory cases

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2023 exam. Headache classification questions often test recognition of NDPH by its abrupt onset, continuous daily course from day one, and absence of migrainous or medication overuse features.

question_text: A patient presents with a history of unilateral headache, severe, lasting less than 5 minutes, with stabbing pain and associated autonomic symptoms on the same side (tearing). What is the best approach for treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] SUNCT (Short-lasting Unilateral Neuralgiform headache attacks with Conjunctival injection and Tearing) is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC). Key points:
• Attacks last seconds to minutes (<5 min), multiple times per day.
• Severe, strictly unilateral stabbing pain in V1 distribution.
• Ipsilateral cranial parasympathetic activation via the trigeminal–autonomic reflex (lacrimation, conjunctival injection).
• Pathophysiology involves posterior hypothalamic activation with disinhibition of the trigeminal nucleus caudalis–superior salivatory synaptic loop.

(Word count: 105)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Topiramate (Topamax) is supported by case series and open-label trials (Lambru et al., 2007; Pareja & Caminero, 2010) showing ≥50% reduction in SUNCT attack frequency at doses of 100–200 mg/day. It modulates voltage-gated sodium and calcium channels, enhances GABAergic inhibition, and antagonizes AMPA/kainate receptors, dampening hyperexcitable trigeminal pathways.
European Headache Federation consensus (2019) assigns topiramate a Level C recommendation for SUNCT prophylaxis. In contrast, lamotrigine has more limited availability and tolerability issues, making topiramate a practical first-line agent. Acute therapies (e.g., intravenous lidocaine) are reserved for intractable in-hospital management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Indomethacin
• Incorrect: Diagnostic hallmark of paroxysmal hemicrania is absolute indomethacin response. SUNCT does not remit with indomethacin.
• Misconception: “All short-lasting unilateral headaches respond to indomethacin.”
C. Oxygen therapy
• Incorrect: High-flow oxygen aborts cluster headache attacks but has no proven benefit in SUNCT.
• Differentiator: SUNCT attacks are too brief and refractory to vasoconstrictive oxygen.
D. Verapamil
• Incorrect: Calcium-channel blockade is first-line for cluster headache prophylaxis, not SUNCT.
• Misconception: “All TACs respond similarly to verapamil.”

Comparison Table

FeatureTopiramate (B)Indomethacin (A)Oxygen (C)Verapamil (D)
MechanismNa+/Ca²⁺ channel block, GABA ↑, AMPA antagonismCOX inhibitionCerebral vasoconstriction (O₂)L-type Ca²⁺ channel block
Indication in SUNCTProphylaxis (Level C)No efficacyNoneNo efficacy
Typical Dose100–200 mg/day150–300 mg/day100% O₂, 12 L/min240–480 mg/day
Response Rate~60% ≥50% reduction0%0%0%

Clinical Pearls

• Differentiate SUNCT from cluster headache by attack duration (<5 min vs. 15–180 min) and lack of circadian pattern.
• A trial of indomethacin rules in paroxysmal hemicrania but not SUNCT/SUNA.
• Consider in-hospital IV lidocaine infusion for rapid abortive control in refractory SUNCT.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all TACs for prophylaxis—indomethacin only diagnostic in paroxysmal hemicrania, not SUNCT.
2. Assuming oxygen works for any trigeminal autonomic headache; its benefit is specific to cluster headache.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Headache Federation (2019) Consensus Statement: Recommends topiramate as Level C prophylactic agent for SUNCT/SUNA.
• ICHD-3 (2018, International Headache Society): Clearly distinguishes SUNCT by attack duration (<10 s–10 min) and non-response to indomethacin.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

SUNCT pain originates in trigeminal nociceptive afferents (V1) projecting to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis. Activation of the superior salivatory nucleus via hypothalamic connections triggers parasympathetic outflow through the sphenopalatine ganglion causing tearing and conjunctival injection.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Hyperexcitable posterior hypothalamus lowers the threshold for trigeminovascular activation, promoting repetitive firing in trigeminal nociceptors and reflex parasympathetic activation (tearing, redness) through the trigeminal–autonomic reflex arc.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Topiramate dosing starts at 25 mg QHS, titrated by 25 mg/week to 100–200 mg/day divided BID. Monitor for cognitive side effects, paresthesias, kidney stones, metabolic acidosis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2018 exam. SUNCT/SUNA management questions frequently test differentiation from cluster headache and paroxysmal hemicrania, and knowing that topiramate or lamotrigine (not indomethacin, oxygen, or verapamil) are preferred prophylactic agents.

question_text: A patient presents with a headache that came out of the blue and has persisted for 3 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2024] New Daily Persistent Headache (NDPH) is a primary headache disorder in ICHD-3 characterized by abrupt onset of a daily, unremitting headache that persists >3 months. Key concepts:
• Headache classification (ICHD-3): separates primary from secondary and subdivides by temporal profile.
• Onset pattern: “came out of the blue” implies day-one daily headache.
• Duration criterion: persistence without remission ≥3 months distinguishes NDPH from transient causes.

Understanding trigeminovascular activation and central sensitization underlies many primary headache disorders, but the hallmark of NDPH is its sudden daily persistence from the very first attack.

Evidence-Based Analysis

According to ICHD-3 (2018), diagnostic criteria for NDPH require:
1. Daily and unremitting headache starting abruptly.
2. Duration >3 months.
3. Not better explained by another diagnosis.
4. No structural cause on appropriate workup.

Prospective series (Rozen & Swidan, Neurology 2007) show the abrupt onset and chronicity in >80% of NDPH patients. Unlike chronic migraine, which evolves from episodic attacks, NDPH patients recall the exact day their headache began. Imaging (MRI/MRV) is uniformly normal in primary NDPH (Silberstein et al., Cephalalgia 2014). Thus, the presentation of a new, continuous headache present daily for 3 months with an identifiable start date is pathognomonic for NDPH.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. SUNA
• Short unilateral neuralgiform headache with autonomic symptoms; attacks last seconds to minutes, not continuous.
• Misconception: all autonomic headaches are chronic; SUNA is paroxysmal.

C. HC (Hemicrania Continua)
• Continuous unilateral pain with ipsilateral autonomic features, responds completely to indomethacin.
• Key differentiator: indomethacin responsiveness and strict unilateral location.

D. Chronic Migraine
• Requires ≥15 headache days/month for ≥3 months, but typically evolves from episodic migraine with migrainous features (photophobia, phonophobia).
• Onset is gradual, not abrupt daily persistence from day one.

Comparison Table

FeatureNDPHSUNAHCChronic Migraine
OnsetAbrupt, identified day-1Paroxysmal, seconds–minutesGradual continuous unilateralInsidious over months/years
DurationDaily, unremitting >3 mos<10 s to minutes per attackContinuous >3 mos≥15 days/mo for ≥3 mos
LateralityUnilateral or bilateralStrict unilateralStrict unilateralBilateral or unilateral
Autonomic featuresRare or mildProminent ipsilateral symptomsCommon (lacrimation, ptosis)Rare
Indomethacin responseNoneNoneComplete resolutionNone

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain neuroimaging (MRI ± MRV) in NDPH to exclude secondary causes (e.g., low CSF pressure, sinus thrombosis).
• First-line prophylactics include amitriptyline or topiramate; response rates are lower than in chronic migraine.
• NDPH often shows poor response to standard migraine therapies—plan for multimodal management.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Labeling all daily headaches >3 months as chronic migraine without confirming migrainous features or onset pattern.
2. Failing to consider secondary etiologies (e.g., idiopathic intracranial hypertension) in a “new” persistent headache before diagnosing NDPH.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): Defines NDPH criteria (Level I consensus).
• European Headache Federation Guideline (2023): Recommends MRI ± MRV in all NDPH presentations to exclude secondary causes (Level B evidence).
• American Headache Society Consensus Statement (2021): Suggests amitriptyline or topiramate as first-line agents in NDPH (Level C evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

NDPH likely involves sustained activation of the trigeminovascular system with central sensitization in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and thalamic relay nuclei, though specific loci remain under investigation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Proposed mechanisms include persistent neurogenic inflammation, dysregulated central pain processing, and maladaptive plasticity in pain pathways, accounting for the refractory nature of NDPH.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: confirm abrupt daily onset and duration >3 mos.
2. Rule out secondary causes: MRI ± MRV, fundus exam, CSF opening pressure if indicated.
3. Apply ICHD-3 criteria.
4. Initiate prophylactic therapy; monitor response and reconsider diagnosis if atypical.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Routine brain MRI in NDPH is typically normal; key role is exclusion of neoplasm, CVST, or demyelination.
• Consider MRV if suspicion for venous thrombosis exists.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Amitriptyline: start 10 mg at bedtime, titrate to 50 mg.
• Topiramate: initiate 25 mg BID, max 100 mg/day.
• Refractory: trial of onabotulinum toxin A or occipital nerve blocks.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part I 2024 exam.
Abrupt onset of a daily, persistent headache from day one is classic for NDPH and is a frequently tested ICHD-3 concept, often presented as time-course differentiation from other chronic headaches.

question_text: Q54. A patient presents with a history of unilateral headache, severe, lasting less than 5 minutes, with stabbing pain and associated autonomic symptoms on the same side (tearing). What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part I 2018] - Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are primary headaches featuring unilateral trigeminal pain plus ipsilateral cranial autonomic signs (lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion).
• Attack duration and frequency are key: SUNCT attacks last seconds (1–600 s), chronic paroxysmal hemicrania 2–30 min, cluster headache 15–180 min, hemicrania continua is continuous with superimposed exacerbations.
• Autonomic features arise via the trigeminal–parasympathetic reflex mediated by the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and the superior salivatory nucleus through the facial nerve to the sphenopalatine ganglion.

Evidence-Based Analysis

SUNCT meets International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) criteria: strictly unilateral attacks lasting 1–600 s with prominent conjunctival injection and tearing in most attacks, often hundreds per day. The patient’s episodes (<5 min), stabbing quality, and ipsilateral tearing without mention of indomethacin response strongly favor SUNCT over other TACs. Multiple case series (e.g., Sjaastad & Fredriksen, 2020) and expert consensus confirm the brevity and high frequency of SUNCT attacks, distinguishing it from paroxysmal hemicrania, which is indomethacin-responsive and typically lasts longer (2–30 min).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Hemicrania continua
• Incorrect because pain is continuous with superimposed exacerbations lasting hours to days, not brief paroxysms.
• Absolute response to indomethacin is diagnostic; absent here.

C. Chronic paroxysmal hemicrania
• Attacks last 2–30 min and respond completely to indomethacin (150–225 mg/day).
• Frequency (5–40/day) is lower and duration longer than SUNCT’s typical seconds-long attacks.

D. Cluster headache
• Attacks last 15–180 min, usually once to eight times daily, often with restlessness and strong response to oxygen or subcutaneous sumatriptan.
• Duration far exceeds the <5 min episodes described.

Comparison Table

FeatureSUNCTChronic Paroxysmal HemicraniaCluster HeadacheHemicrania Continua
Attack duration1–600 seconds2–30 minutes15–180 minutesContinuous with exacerbations
FrequencyUp to hundreds/day5–40/day1–8/dayVariable
Indomethacin responseNoYesNoYes
Main autonomic featuresConjunctival injection, tearingLacrimation, nasal congestionLacrimation, rhinorrheaMild ipsilateral features

Clinical Pearls

- SUNCT requires both conjunctival injection AND tearing in most attacks; always query both signs.
