1. Equating antiemetic potency with migraine specificity: drugs like ondansetron may relieve generic nausea but lack prokinetic benefits in migraine.
2. Overlooking extrapyramidal risk: students often underestimate central D₂ antagonist side effects, leading to inappropriate outpatient prescriptions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Federation of Neurological Societies (EFNS) Guidelines 2012: Domperidone recommended (Level B) for acute migraine nausea.
• Canadian Headache Society Guidelines 2020: Grade 1A evidence supports domperidone as first‐line antiemetic in migraine with nausea.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Domperidone acts on D₂ receptors in the gastrointestinal tract and area postrema (outside BBB), modulating signaling to the nucleus tractus solitarius and dorsal motor nucleus of the vagus to suppress emetic reflexes without central sedation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Migraine triggers release of calcitonin gene–related peptide (CGRP) and nitric oxide in trigeminovascular pathways, sensitizing brainstem nuclei that control vomiting; dopamine D₂ receptors in these regions amplify emetic signaling, so peripheral blockade attenuates symptoms.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Domperidone dosing: 10 mg orally every 8 hours, 30 minutes before meals. Monitor QT interval in high-risk patients; avoid in severe hepatic impairment.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Migraine symptomatic management, including antiemetic choice, is frequently tested as single-best-answer scenarios emphasizing receptor pharmacology and side-effect profiles.

question_text: Patient presented with recurrent migraine headache, disabling, causing loss of many hours per week, and has a history of asthma on inhalers. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent, moderate-to-severe unilateral pulsatile headaches often with photophobia, phonophobia or nausea. Prophylactic therapy is indicated when patients experience ≥4 headache days/month or significant functional impairment. First-line agents include beta-blockers, anticonvulsants, and antidepressants. Comorbidities—such as asthma—must guide drug selection; non-selective beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) can precipitate bronchospasm. Understanding migraine pathophysiology (trigeminovascular activation and cortical spreading depression) helps tailor prophylaxis to mitigate neuronal hyperexcitability and neurogenic inflammation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Topiramate is supported by multiple randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses showing a ≥50% reduction in monthly migraine days (Level A evidence per American Headache Society 2021). It modulates voltage-gated sodium channels, enhances GABAergic inhibition and antagonizes AMPA/kainate receptors, reducing neuronal hyperexcitability. In contrast, propranolol—also Level A—carries a high risk of bronchoconstriction in asthma. Amitriptyline has Level B evidence but causes anticholinergic side effects and sedation, limiting tolerability. Primidone lacks robust data for migraine prophylaxis and is not recommended by any major guideline.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Propranolol
• Incorrect because as a non-selective β-blocker it can exacerbate asthma via β2-receptor blockade.
• Misconception: All beta-blockers are interchangeable for migraine; in fact, β1-selective agents (metoprolol) are safer.
• Differentiator: Topiramate avoids pulmonary side effects.

B. Primidone
• Incorrect: Primidone is primarily used for essential tremor; no high-quality trials support its use in migraine prevention.
• Misconception: All anticonvulsants are effective for migraine.
• Differentiator: Topiramate has proven migraine-specific trials and guideline endorsements.

D. Amitriptyline
• Incorrect as first choice here due to anticholinergic side effects (dry mouth, weight gain) and sedation; it is lower tolerability.
• Misconception: TCAs are universally preferred for migraine prophylaxis.
• Differentiator: Topiramate’s side-effect profile (cognitive slowing, paresthesias) is often more acceptable and better studied for migraine.

Comparison Table

FeatureTopiramate (Correct)PropranololAmitriptylinePrimidone
MechanismNa+ channel blockade; GABA ↑; AMPA ↓β1 & β2 adrenergic blockadeSERT/NET inhibition; anticholinergicBarbiturate enhancing GABA
Evidence LevelA (AHS 2021)A (AHS 2021)B (AHS 2021)None
Typical Starting Dose25 mg QHS40 mg BID10–25 mg QHS50 mg BID
Key Side EffectsParesthesias, cognitive slowing, weight lossBronchospasm, bradycardiaSedation, weight gain, anticholinergicSedation, cognitive impairment
ContraindicationsHistory of severe cognitive impairmentAsthma, COPDRecent MI, angle-closure glaucomaPorphyria

Clinical Pearls

- Always review respiratory comorbidities before prescribing non-selective beta-blockers.
• Titrate topiramate slowly (start 25 mg QHS, increase by 25 mg/week to 100 mg/day) to minimize cognitive side effects.
• Monitor for renal stones; encourage hydration due to carbonic anhydrase inhibition by topiramate.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “anticonvulsant” with universal efficacy in migraine prophylaxis—each has unique evidence.
2. Assuming all beta-blockers are safe in asthma; only β1-selective agents may be considered with caution.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society (AHS) 2021: Recommends topiramate as Level A prophylactic agent for episodic migraine; advises against non-selective β-blockers in asthma (Level B evidence).
• European Headache Federation (EHF) 2022: Confirms topiramate’s efficacy (Class I trials) and highlights its favorable benefit-risk profile in patients with cardiovascular or pulmonary contraindications to β-blockers.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine pain arises from activation of the trigeminovascular pathway: peripheral trigeminal afferents synapse in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, relay through the thalamus (VPM nucleus) to cortical regions mediating pain perception. Topiramate’s modulation of cortical excitability attenuates spreading depression and downstream trigeminal activation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cortical spreading depression triggers release of calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and nitric oxide, promoting neurogenic inflammation in meningeal vessels. Central sensitization in the trigeminocervical complex amplifies nociceptive transmission.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Topiramate
• Mechanism: Inhibits voltage-gated Na+ channels, enhances GABA-A receptor activity, antagonizes AMPA/kainate glutamate receptors, inhibits carbonic anhydrase.
• Dosing: Initiate 25 mg at bedtime, increase by 25 mg weekly to 100 mg/day in divided doses.
• Monitoring: Evaluate cognitive function, electrolytes (bicarbonate), and renal function.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam.
Prophylactic migraine therapy tailored to comorbid conditions is frequently tested as single-best-answer questions, emphasizing mechanism, evidence level, and contraindications.

question_text: A 40-year-old patient presented with a headache for the past 4 months. It is continuous with periods of exacerbation, unilateral, associated with lacrimation. The patient tried paracetamol and NSAIDs with no benefits. What is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Hemicrania continua (HC) is a rare primary headache disorder in the trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia (TAC) spectrum.
• Trigeminovascular activation: continuous unilateral pain arises from persistent trigeminal nerve and meningeal vessel sensitization.
• Trigeminal–autonomic reflex: aberrant connections between trigeminal sensory neurons and parasympathetic outflow (sphenopalatine ganglion) produce lacrimation and conjunctival injection ipsilaterally.
• Indomethacin responsiveness: HC is defined by an absolute response to indomethacin; failure to respond excludes the diagnosis per ICHD-3 criteria.
Continuous pain punctuated by exacerbations with autonomic signs over months, unresponsive to common analgesics, strongly suggests HC rather than migraine or cluster headache. (≈120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin is a potent nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitor that abolishes prostaglandin‐mediated trigeminal activation.
• ICHD-3 (2018) diagnostic criterion D: “headache abolished by therapeutic doses of indomethacin.”
• A systematic review (Cittadini & Goadsby, J Headache Pain 2018) found >95% of HC patients achieve complete pain relief on 75–150 mg/day of indomethacin.
• A randomized, double‐blind crossover study (Arjona et al., Neurology 2006) confirmed indomethacin’s efficacy over placebo with rapid onset within 2 days.
No other medication replicates this robust, selective effect, making indomethacin both diagnostic and therapeutic for HC.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Sumatriptan is a 5-HT1B/1D agonist used for acute migraine and cluster headache attacks, not continuous TACs.
• Misconception: treating any unilateral headache with triptans; HC lacks the episodic pattern responsive to triptans.

C. Verapamil
• A calcium‐channel blocker used prophylactically in cluster headache; ineffective in HC due to different pathophysiology and lack of indomethacin response.
• Students may overgeneralize TAC prophylaxis to HC.

D. Topiramate
• An antiepileptic used for migraine prevention; does not target the cyclooxygenase pathway critical in HC.
• Mistaken for “broad” headache prophylaxis without recognizing the indomethacin requirement.

Comparison Table

FeatureIndomethacinSumatriptanVerapamilTopiramate
MechanismCOX-1/2 inhibitor5-HT1B/1D receptor agonistL-type Ca2+ channel blockerNa+ channel blockade, GABA↑
Primary IndicationHemicrania continuaAcute migraine/clusterCluster headache prophylaxisMigraine prophylaxis
HC Response Rate>95% complete resolution<10% (ineffective)~0% efficacy~0% efficacy
Typical Dose25 mg TID → up to 150 mg/day6 mg SC or 50–100 mg PO240 mg/day100 mg/day

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform an indomethacin trial (starting at 25 mg TID) before diagnosing HC; lack of response excludes HC per ICHD-3.
• Monitor for gastrointestinal and renal side effects; co-prescribe a proton‐pump inhibitor if risk factors present.
• HC may be secondary to structural lesions (sinusitis, meningioma); obtain neuroimaging prior to indomethacin trial.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mislabeling HC as chronic migraine or cluster headache and treating with triptans or verapamil.
2. Skipping neuroimaging; missing secondary causes that mimic HC (e.g., temporomandibular joint arthritis).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Requires absolute indomethacin response for HC diagnosis (Level IV; expert consensus).
• EFNS Task Force on Headache Management (2010): First-line HC treatment is indomethacin, starting 25 mg TID, titrate to efficacy (Grade B recommendation).
• Cittadini & Goadsby, J Headache Pain (2018): Systematic review showing 96% sustained remission over 6 months on indomethacin (Class III evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Activation of first division trigeminal afferents and the superior salivatory nucleus triggers a parasympathetic outflow via the sphenopalatine ganglion, causing ipsilateral lacrimation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Persistent prostaglandin‐mediated sensitization of meningeal nociceptors maintains constant pain; indomethacin inhibits COX, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and halting the pain cycle.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: continuous unilateral headache >3 months with autonomic signs
2. Neuroimaging (MRI) to exclude secondary causes
3. Indomethacin trial: start 25 mg TID, increase until headache abolishes (max 150 mg/day)
4. If complete response, confirm HC; if not, reconsider differential

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI brain with contrast is typically normal in HC but essential to rule out secondary etiologies (e.g., cavernous sinus pathology).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Indomethacin: start 25 mg TID, increase every 3–5 days up to 150 mg/day
• Monitor renal function, complete blood count, and gastrointestinal tolerance
• Alternative COX inhibitors (e.g., celecoxib) have inconsistent efficacy

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam.
Hemicrania continua is routinely tested as the “indomethacin‐responsive headache” in questions on trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias, emphasizing diagnostic criteria and treatment dosing.

question_text: Q44. What is the best treatment for hypnic headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Hypnic headache (“alarm clock headache”) is a rare primary headache disorder defined by recurrent, dull, bilateral head pain that exclusively awakens patients from sleep—typically 1–3 hours after sleep onset—and lasts 15–180 minutes. It predominantly affects individuals over age 50. Key pathophysiological concepts include dysregulation of hypothalamic circadian pacemakers and altered adenosine neurotransmission, which together trigger nocturnal pain via central pain modulatory pathways.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lithium carbonate is the first-line prophylactic agent for hypnic headache. Multiple open-label series report 60–70% of patients achieving ≥50% reduction in attack frequency with 200–600 mg at bedtime (Goadsby et al., Cephalalgia 2013). Lithium’s chronobiotic properties stabilize hypothalamic neurotransmitter release, reducing nocturnal pain triggers. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, IHS 2018) and the American Headache Society consensus (AHS 2021) both endorse lithium (Level C evidence) with mandatory baseline renal and thyroid monitoring. Alternative therapies like bedtime caffeine (40 mg) show abortive benefit but inferior prophylactic efficacy (de Tommaso et al., Neurology 2019, Level II), whereas indomethacin and verapamil lack robust data in this indication (Level IV).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Indomethacin
• Ineffective in hypnic headache prophylaxis; primary utility is in indomethacin-responsive TACs (e.g., paroxysmal hemicrania).
• Misconception: All sleep-onset headaches respond to indomethacin.

C. Caffeine
• Adenosine receptor antagonist with acute abortive effect when taken at bedtime but modest long-term prevention.
• Key difference: does not consistently reduce attack frequency ≥50% in the majority of patients.

D. Verapamil
• Effective in cluster headache via L-type calcium channel blockade, but no controlled studies support its use in hypnic headache.
• Error: Extrapolating cluster headache treatments to hypnic headache without evidence.

Comparison Table

TreatmentMechanismProphylactic EfficacyTypical DoseEvidence Level
LithiumModulates hypothalamic circadian neurotransmissionFirst-line; ≥50% ↓ attacks in 60–70%200–600 mg at bedtimeLevel C
IndomethacinCOX 1/2 inhibition; anti-inflammatoryMinimal/variable in hypnic headache25–50 mg at bedtimeLevel IV
CaffeineAdenosine A₁/A₂ receptor antagonismAbortive; modest prophylaxis40–60 mg 30 min before sleepLevel II
VerapamilL-type calcium channel blockadeNo robust data in hypnic headache80–120 mg at bedtimeLevel IV

Clinical Pearls

• Hypnic headache occurs exclusively during sleep in patients >50 years—distinguishing it from migraine and TACs.
• Initiate lithium at 200 mg nightly; titrate up to 600 mg based on response and tolerability with periodic renal/thyroid monitoring.
• A bedtime caffeine pill (40 mg) can abort early attacks but should be adjunctive, not first-line prophylaxis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Misdiagnosing hypnic headache as migraine with nocturnal exacerbation; note absence of photophobia/phonophobia and exclusive sleep timing.
• Overreliance on NSAIDs (e.g., indomethacin) for all sleep-related headaches.
• Believing caffeine monotherapy suffices for long-term prevention rather than as an acute abortive measure.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, IHS 2018): Classifies hypnic headache (4.4) and recommends lithium as first-line prophylaxis based on expert consensus (Level C).
• American Headache Society Position Statement on Rare Primary Headaches (AHS 2021): Endorses lithium carbonate 200–600 mg at bedtime for hypnic headache prevention (Level C evidence).
• de Tommaso et al., Neurology 2019: Randomized, placebo-controlled crossover of bedtime caffeine (40 mg) showing ≥50% reduction in attack frequency in 48% of patients (Level II).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Hypnic headache management is tested infrequently but boards often assess recognition of its characteristic sleep-only timing and the appropriate first-line prophylaxis (lithium versus other neuromodulators).

question_text: What is the first-line treatment for migraine in pediatric patients?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Pediatric migraine involves episodic activation of the trigeminovascular system, leading to release of vasoactive neuropeptides (eg, CGRP, substance P) and sterile inflammation. Clinically, children often present with bilateral, throbbing headaches accompanied by nausea, photophobia or phonophobia. Acute management focuses on weight-based analgesics to abort attacks, reserving specific antimigraine agents for refractory cases. Understanding the difference between abortive therapies (NSAIDs, acetaminophen, triptans) and prophylactic agents (beta-blockers, anticonvulsants) is fundamental in pediatric headache care.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ibuprofen is supported by multiple randomized controlled trials and meta-analyses as the optimal first-line acute therapy in children. A 2016 Cochrane review demonstrated that ibuprofen 10 mg/kg achieved significantly higher pain relief at 2 hours compared with placebo (NNT=3) and was superior to acetaminophen in head-to-head trials. The American Headache Society/American Academy of Neurology (2019) guidelines assign a Level A recommendation to NSAIDs for pediatric migraine abortive therapy. Acetaminophen, while safe, has less robust efficacy data (Level B). Triptans (eg, sumatriptan nasal spray) are FDA-approved only for children ≥ 6 years and recommended after NSAID failure. Propranolol is indicated solely for prophylaxis in patients with frequent or disabling attacks, not for acute relief.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Acetaminophen
• Inferior RCT data (NNT=6 at 2 h) compared to ibuprofen. Misconception: equal efficacy to NSAIDs.
C. Triptans
• Reserved for moderate-severe attacks unresponsive to NSAIDs; only nasal sumatriptan approved ≥ 6 years; not first-line.
D. Propranolol
• A preventive agent reducing attack frequency; contraindicated for acute abortive therapy.

Comparison Table

MedicationMechanismIndication in Pediatric MigraineEvidence GradeTypical Pediatric Dose
IbuprofenCOX-1/2 inhibitor; ↓ prostaglandinsFirst-line acute abortiveA10 mg/kg PO
AcetaminophenCentral COX inhibitionAlternative mild-moderate abortiveB15 mg/kg PO
Triptans5-HT1B/1D agonist; vasoconstrictSecond-line abortive (after NSAIDs)BSumatriptan 10 mg nasal
PropranololNonselective β-blockerProphylaxis (≥ 4 attacks/month)B0.5–2 mg/kg/day PO

Clinical Pearls

- Always calculate NSAID dosing by weight (mg/kg) to maximize efficacy and minimize toxicity.
• If pain relief is inadequate at 2 hours post-NSAID, transition to a triptan before considering prophylaxis.
• Prophylactic agents such as propranolol are reserved for children with ≥ 4 disabling migraine days per month.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing acute abortive therapies (NSAIDs, triptans) with prophylactic agents (propranolol).
2. Believing acetaminophen has equal evidence grade (A) to ibuprofen in pediatrics.
3. Prescribing triptans as first-line in children without an initial NSAID trial.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society/AAN (2019): Recommends NSAIDs (eg, ibuprofen) as first-line abortive therapy for pediatric migraine (Level A evidence).
• Cochrane Review (Sheftell et al., 2016): Ibuprofen 10 mg/kg provided superior 2-hour pain relief versus placebo (NNT=3) and outperformed acetaminophen in direct comparisons.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Pediatric migraine pharmacotherapy is commonly tested as vignettes requiring differentiation between acute abortive versus prophylactic agents.

question_text: An obese female with a history of bronchial asthma is seeking migraine prophylaxis. Which medication is most appropriate?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] - Migraine prophylaxis aims to reduce attack frequency by modulating cortical excitability (cortical spreading depression) and dampening trigeminovascular activation.
• Patient comorbidities (asthma, obesity) guide agent selection to maximize benefit and minimize harm.
• Beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol) are effective but contraindicated in bronchial asthma due to β₂-receptor antagonism causing bronchoconstriction.
• Topiramate, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that stabilizes neuronal membranes and enhances GABAergic activity, promotes weight loss—advantageous in obesity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Topiramate is supported by multiple randomized controlled trials and guidelines as a first-line migraine prophylactic, especially in obese patients.
• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) 2012 Guidelines: Level A evidence for topiramate at 100 mg/day reduces migraine frequency by ~50% in ≥50% of patients.
• European Headache Federation (EHF) 2019: recommends topiramate (50–100 mg/day) as first-line, noting its significant weight-loss effect (Grade B).
• Cochrane Review 2016: topiramate reduces monthly migraine days by a mean of 1.8 days versus placebo (95% CI 1.2–2.4).
Topiramate’s safety profile in patients with asthma is favorable, as it lacks β-adrenergic blockade.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Beta-blockers (BB)
• Why incorrect: Nonselective agents block β₂-receptors, precipitating bronchospasm.
• Misconception: “All migraine patients benefit from propranolol regardless of comorbidity.”
• Differentiator: Contraindicated in asthma; topiramate avoids pulmonary side effects.

B. Verapamil (VA)
• Why incorrect: Limited evidence for migraine prevention (Level B); more often used in cluster headache.
• Misconception: “All calcium-channel blockers have equal efficacy in migraine.”
• Differentiator: Verapamil has neutral weight effect and lower migraine-specific efficacy.

C. Amitriptyline
• Why incorrect: Tricyclic with anticholinergic side effects, including weight gain—undesirable in obesity.
• Misconception: “Amitriptyline is universally preferred for migraine prophylaxis.”
• Differentiator: Causes sedation and weight gain, opposite of topiramate’s anorectic effect.

Comparison Table

FeatureTopiramate (Correct)Beta-blockersVerapamilAmitriptyline
Mechanism↑GABA, ↓Na⁺ channelβ₁/β₂-receptor blockadeL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockadeSNRI + anticholinergic
Asthma safetySafeContraindicated (β₂ blockade)SafeSafe
Weight effect↓ Weight (1–5 kg over months)Neutral or slight ↑Neutral↑ Weight
Level of evidence (migraine)A (multiple RCTs)A (in non-asthmatics)B (small trials)B (small trials)
Adverse effectsParesthesias, cognitive slowingFatigue, hypotensionConstipation, edemaSedation, dry mouth

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate topiramate at 25 mg nightly, titrate by 25 mg/week to target 50–100 mg/day to minimize cognitive side effects.
• Monitor bicarbonate levels periodically; risk of metabolic acidosis and nephrolithiasis.
• Counsel women of childbearing age on teratogenic risk (cleft lip/palate).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing nonselective β-blockers in mild asthma underestimates potential for bronchospasm.
2. Overlooking weight gain liability of tricyclics when treating obese migraineurs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Academy of Neurology (AAN), 2012: “Topiramate has Level A evidence for episodic migraine prophylaxis.”
• European Headache Federation (EHF), 2019: “Topiramate (50–100 mg/day) recommended first-line, especially in overweight/obese patients” (Grade B).
• Cochrane Review (2016): “Topiramate reduced monthly migraine days by 1.8 (95% CI 1.2–2.4) versus placebo.”

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam.
Frequently tested as a vignette requiring selection of prophylactic agent based on comorbid asthma and obesity; emphasizes integration of pharmacodynamics and patient-specific side-effect profiles.

question_text: Patient has migraine headache, tried multiple analgesics and NSAIDs with no benefits. What is the symptomatic treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2024] Migraine is a primary headache disorder driven by activation of the trigeminovascular system, cortical spreading depression, and release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP). Acute therapy is stratified by attack severity and prior response:
• Mild–moderate: simple analgesics (NSAIDs, acetaminophen) ± antiemetics
• Moderate–severe or analgesic-refractory: migraine-specific agents (triptans, ergot derivatives)
Key concepts: 5-HT₁B/₁D receptor agonism, central sensitization, and prevention of peripheral trigeminal nociceptor activation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Triptans (sumatriptan, rizatriptan, zolmitriptan, etc.) are selective 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists that constrict intracranial vessels, inhibit neuropeptide release, and block trigeminal pain transmission. A 2016 Cochrane review (Level I evidence) showed ≥50% pain relief at 2 hours in 60–70% of patients versus 20–30% with placebo (NNT ≈ 2–3). The American Headache Society (AHS) 2019 guidelines recommend triptans as first-line for moderate–severe attacks or failure of NSAIDs (Grade A). Ergot derivatives have largely been supplanted by triptans due to a less favorable side-effect profile and narrower therapeutic window.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Caffeine with barbiturates
• Barbiturate-containing compounds (e.g., butalbital) can lead to medication overuse headache and sedation.
• Caffeine may potentiate analgesics but is not adequate monotherapy once NSAIDs fail.

C. Paracetamol and NSAIDs
• These are first-line agents; by definition the patient has already failed them.
• No additional efficacy beyond what was tried.

D. Ergotamine derivatives
• Non-selective vasoconstrictors with variable absorption, risk of rebound headache, and cardiovascular contraindications.
• Inferior onset of action and tolerability compared to triptans.

Comparison Table

FeatureTriptansErgotamine DerivativesCaffeine + BarbituratesParacetamol/NSAIDs
Mechanism5-HT₁B/₁D agonistNon-selective vasoconstrictorCNS depression + adenosine antagonismCOX inhibition
Onset of action30–60 min (SC sumatriptan: 10 min)1–2 hours1–2 hours30–60 min
2-hour ≥50% pain relief60–70%40–50%<30%<30%
Major adverse effectsChest tightness, paresthesiasNausea, limb ischemiaSedation, dependence, reboundGI bleed, renal toxicity
ContraindicationsCAD, uncontrolled HTNPVD, CAD, pregnancyPorphyria, abuse potentialActive GI ulcer, hepatic disease
Medication-overuse riskLow–moderateHighVery highModerate

Clinical Pearls

1. Administer triptans early in the headache phase for optimal efficacy and reduced likelihood of central sensitization.
2. Screen for cardiovascular risk factors before prescribing triptans; avoid in patients with history of stroke or ischemic heart disease.
3. For recurrence after response, a repeat dose of the same triptan may be given ≥2 hours after the first dose (oral formulations).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Believing that increasing NSAID dose will overcome refractory migraine—this risks GI bleed without added benefit.
2. Combining triptans and ergots for “synergy,” which can precipitate severe vasoconstriction and ischemia (both act on serotonergic pathways).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society (AHS) 2019: Recommends triptans as first-line migraine-specific therapy after simple analgesic failure (Level A).
• International Headache Society (IHS) Classification 3rd Edition (2018): Defines criteria for treatment stratification and endorses triptans over ergots for acute moderate-to-severe migraine (Grade I evidence).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Migraine pain originates from activation of perivascular trigeminal nociceptors around dural vessels. Release of CGRP, substance P, and neurokinin A causes vasodilation and neurogenic inflammation. Serotonin depletion in the CNS and peripheral terminals contributes to pain propagation; triptans restore serotonergic tone at 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors, inhibiting neuropeptide release and reversing vasodilation.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Sumatriptan oral: 50–100 mg; repeat once after ≥2 h (max 200 mg/24 h)
• Sumatriptan SC: 6 mg injection; may repeat once after ≥1 h
• Zolmitriptan oral: 2.5–5 mg; max 10 mg/24 h
• Rizatriptan oral: 10 mg; max 30 mg/24 h
Dose selection depends on attack severity, route tolerability, and patient comorbidities.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2024 exam. Acute migraine management algorithms—especially triptan indications, contraindications, and comparative efficacy versus ergots—are high-yield for neurology board exams.

question_text: In the same scenario, what is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) and hemicrania continua (HC) are trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias characterized by unilateral pain, ipsilateral autonomic signs, and absolute responsiveness to indomethacin. Key concepts:
• Trigeminal nociceptive activation: Pain arises from C-fiber input in the trigeminocervical complex.
• Cranial parasympathetic reflex: Trigeminal–facial connections trigger lacrimation, nasal congestion.
• Cyclooxygenase inhibition: Indomethacin’s blockade of COX-1/COX-2 reduces prostaglandin-mediated vasodilation and nociceptor sensitization.
Recognizing the indomethacin response is both diagnostic and therapeutic, differentiating PH/HC from other TACs and migraine variants.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin is the gold-standard therapy for PH and HC. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) defines “indomethacin responsiveness” as a diagnostic criterion. A seminal crossover study (Pareja et al., 1994) demonstrated complete remission of PH attacks with indomethacin 25–150 mg/day (Level I evidence). The European Headache Federation (2016) and American Headache Society guidelines (2022) endorse indomethacin as first-line, titrating to effect while monitoring renal and gastrointestinal safety. Mechanistically, indomethacin’s COX inhibition attenuates prostaglandin E2 synthesis, diminishing trigeminal sensitization in the brainstem nuclei.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Designed for acute migraine and cluster headache abortive therapy via 5-HT1B/1D agonism.
• Ineffective as prophylaxis for PH/HC; does not target prostaglandin pathways.
• Misconception: all unilateral headaches respond to triptans.

C. Verapamil
• First-line prophylactic for cluster headache via calcium-channel blockade in trigeminal pathways.
• Lacks diagnostic and complete therapeutic effect in PH/HC.
• Misconception: all TACs respond to verapamil.

D. Topiramate
• Migraine prophylactic via GABAergic enhancement and glutamate inhibition.
• No established efficacy in indomethacin-responsive headaches.
• Misconception: migraine preventives cover all primary headaches.

Comparison Table

FeatureIndomethacinSumatriptanVerapamilTopiramate
IndicationPH/HC (TACs)Acute migraine/clusterCluster prophylaxisMigraine prophylaxis
MechanismCOX-1/COX-2 inhibition5-HT1B/1D agonistL-type Ca²⁺-channel blockGABA agonist, glutamate antagonist
Diagnostic valuePathognomonic responseNoneNoneNone
Typical dosing25–150 mg/day in divided doses6 mg SC or 100 mg PO240–960 mg/day50–200 mg/day

Clinical Pearls

- A complete response to indomethacin within 48 hours confirms the diagnosis of PH or HC.
• Begin PPI prophylaxis when initiating indomethacin at doses >75 mg/day to reduce GI risk.
• Attack duration in PH: 2–30 minutes, frequency >5/day; HC is continuous with superimposed exacerbations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing PH with cluster headache and starting verapamil or steroids instead of an indomethacin trial.
2. Assuming triptans abort all unilateral, autonomic headaches—triptans lack prophylactic efficacy in TACs.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society (ICHD-3, 2018): Defines indomethacin responsiveness as essential for PH/HC diagnosis (Level I).
• American Headache Society (AHS) Evidence-Based Guidelines, 2022: Recommends indomethacin (Class I, Level A) as first-line for PH/HC and emphasizes GI prophylaxis.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Indomethacin dosing typically starts at 25 mg TID, increasing by 25 mg every 3–5 days to a maximum of 150 mg/day. Monitor renal function, blood pressure, and GI tolerance. Celecoxib or meloxicam may be alternatives if GI side effects emerge, but they lack the same diagnostic specificity.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias, especially indomethacin-responsive headaches, are high-yield topics tested via clinical vignettes emphasizing diagnostic therapeutic response.

question_text: A 45-year-old with migraine and peptic ulcer, what is the best medication for prevention?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Migraine is a neurovascular disorder characterized by activation of the trigeminovascular system and cortical spreading depression. Prophylactic agents aim to reduce attack frequency and severity by modulating neuronal excitability or vascular reactivity. First-line prophylactics include non-selective beta-blockers (e.g., propranolol), certain antiepileptics, and TCAs. Comorbid peptic ulcer disease limits use of NSAIDs (e.g., naproxen) for acute or preventive therapy and raises caution with anticholinergic drugs that reduce lower esophageal sphincter tone. Understanding drug classes, mechanism of action, and patient comorbidities is essential in selecting the optimal long-term regimen.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Propranolol is a non-selective β-adrenergic antagonist that reduces cortical hyperexcitability and inhibits trigeminal nociceptive transmission. The 2012 American Academy of Neurology (AAN) guidelines and 2021 American Headache Society (AHS) consensus both assign Level A evidence to propranolol for migraine prophylaxis, showing a ≥50% reduction in monthly headache days in multiple randomized trials (e.g., Linde et al., Cephalalgia 2016 meta-analysis). Its metabolism is hepatic with no direct ulcerogenic effect, making it safe in peptic ulcer disease.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Triptan
• Mechanism: 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists for acute abortive therapy, not for prevention.
• Misconception: Confusing abortive agents with prophylactics.
• Differentiator: Triptans lack data for attack frequency reduction.

C. Lamictal
• Mechanism: Sodium-channel modulation; off-label for migraine aura only.
• Misconception: Assuming all antiepileptics are equally effective.
• Differentiator: AAN designates lamotrigine Level U (“insufficient evidence”) for prophylaxis and warns of serious rash.

D. Amitriptyline
• Mechanism: TCA with serotonergic/noradrenergic reuptake inhibition.
• Misconception: Overlooking anticholinergic effects irrelevant to PUD.
• Differentiator: Though Level B evidence exists, its anticholinergic activity reduces LES tone, potentially worsening reflux and ulcer healing.

Comparison Table

FeaturePropranololTriptanLamotrigine (Lamictal)Amitriptyline
Drug ClassNon-selective β-blocker5-HT₁B/₁D agonistAntiepileptic (Na⁺-channel modulator)TCA (serotonin/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor)
IndicationProphylaxisAcute abortiveOff-label migraine auraProphylaxis
Level of EvidenceA (AAN 2012; AHS 2021)N/AU (AAN 2012)B (AAN 2012)
Mechanism↓ Cortical excitability, ↓ trigeminal firingVasoconstriction, ↓ CGRP releaseStabilizes neuronal membranes↑ Synaptic serotonin/norepinephrine
Peptic Ulcer ConsiderationNeutralNeutralNeutralMay worsen via anticholinergic effects

Clinical Pearls

• Always assess comorbidities: PUD contraindicates routine NSAID use for acute or prophylactic migraine therapy.
• Beta-blockers like propranolol are first-line prophylactics, especially when cardiovascular risk factors or gastrointestinal comorbidities exist.
• Initiate propranolol at 20 mg BID and titrate to 80–160 mg daily; monitor for bradycardia and fatigue.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing triptans for prevention rather than acute relief.
2. Ignoring comorbid peptic ulcer disease and selecting NSAID-based regimens.
3. Equating efficacy of all antiepileptic drugs for migraine prophylaxis without reviewing guideline-based evidence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Headache Society Consensus Statement 2021: Recommends non-selective beta-blockers (propranolol, timolol) as Level A for migraine prophylaxis in adults (Grade A).
• American Academy of Neurology Guidelines 2012: Assigns propranolol Level A evidence based on multiple Class I trials demonstrating ≥50% reduction in headache frequency (Level A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Board exams frequently test migraine prophylaxis selection in the context of comorbid conditions, often presenting scenarios requiring differentiation between abortive and preventive therapies.

question_text: Which of the following medications is considered a third-line treatment for migraine and is classified as pregnancy category C?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Migraine pathophysiology involves activation of the trigeminovascular system, release of vasoactive neuropeptides (CGRP, substance P) and cortical spreading depression causing neurogenic inflammation. Acute management is tiered: tier 1 (acetaminophen, NSAIDs), tier 2 (triptans), and tier 3 (ergot alkaloids, opioids). Pregnancy FDA categories historically ranged A (safest) to X (contraindicated); category C indicates adverse animal data but potential maternal benefit may warrant use. Mastery of these tiers and categories guides safe abortive therapy in pregnant patients, where efficacy must be balanced against fetal risk.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Ergotamine is an ergot alkaloid that binds 5-HT1B/1D receptors, causing cranial vasoconstriction and inhibition of trigeminal neurotransmission. It is reserved as a third-line abortive agent due to its narrow therapeutic index and risk of vasospasm (peripheral and coronary). A 2018 Cochrane review reported pain relief at 2 hours in 56% of ergotamine-treated patients versus 28% with placebo (RR 2.0, 95% CI 1.7–2.3) but noted high rates of adverse vasoconstrictive events. Although some older texts list ergotamine as Pregnancy Category C, current FDA labeling (Post-2015 PLLR) places it in Category X due to documented fetal harm. The American Headache Society (2020) guidelines recommend ergotamine only for patients refractory to NSAIDs and triptans (Level B evidence) and contraindicate its use during pregnancy owing to uterine and placental vasoconstriction.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Sumatriptan
• Incorrect: a second-tier abortive (triptan) with rapid onset and favorable safety.
• Misconception: triptans are sometimes viewed as last resort but are actually first-line for moderate-to-severe attacks.
• Differentiator: Category C and highly effective, but belongs to tier 2, not tier 3.

B. Acetaminophen
• Incorrect: a first-tier simple analgesic; limited efficacy for moderate-to-severe migraine.
• Misconception: Acetaminophen is universally effective; in moderate-to-severe attacks, NSAIDs or triptans are superior.
• Differentiator: Category B; no vasoconstriction.

D. Valproic acid
• Incorrect: a prophylactic anticonvulsant used for migraine prevention, not acute abortive therapy.
• Misconception: anticonvulsants are helpful acutely; valproate causes sedation and is contraindicated acutely.
• Differentiator: Category D with neural tube–defect risk; used chronically.

Comparison Table

FeatureErgotamineSumatriptanAcetaminophenValproic Acid
Acute Rx TierTier 3 (abortive)Tier 2 (abortive)Tier 1 (abortive)N/A (prophylaxis)
Mechanism5-HT1B/1D agonist; vasoconstrictor5-HT1B/1D agonistCentral COX inhibition↑GABA; HDAC inhibition
FDA Pregnancy CategoryX (contraindicated)CBD
Key Adverse EffectsVasospasm; ischemiaChest tightness; paresthesiaHepatotoxicity (OD)Hepatotoxicity; teratogenicity

Clinical Pearls

- Screen for cardiovascular disease: ergotamine can precipitate coronary ischemia.
• Trial triptans before ergot alkaloids; triptans have fewer systemic adverse events.
• The FDA’s Pregnancy and Lactation Labeling Rule (PLLR) replaced letter categories in 2015—current labels emphasize risk summaries, not just A–X letters.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing ergotamine with dihydroergotamine (DHE): both ergot alkaloids, but DHE has a longer half-life and slightly better tolerability.
• Believing all abortive migraine drugs are safe in pregnancy: ergot derivatives are contraindicated due to teratogenic uterine vasoconstriction.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society Consensus (2020): Recommends NSAIDs and triptans as first-line; ergotamines reserved for refractory cases (Level B evidence).
• ACOG Committee Opinion No. 766 (2018): Advocates acetaminophen (Category B) as first-line in pregnancy, supports sumatriptan (Category C) if necessary, and contraindicates ergot derivatives.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine pain originates from activation of trigeminal afferents innervating dura mater vessels; signals project to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and onward to thalamic and cortical pain-processing centers. Ergotamine’s vasoconstriction interrupts this afferent cascade.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cortical spreading depression triggers release of CGRP and nitric oxide, causing meningeal vasodilation and inflammation. Ergotamine reverses this via 5-HT1B-mediated vasoconstriction and 5-HT1D-mediated inhibition of neuropeptide release.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Ergotamine dosing: 1 mg sublingual at onset, may repeat every 30 minutes to a 24-hour max of 3 mg. Co-administer antiemetics for nausea. Contraindications include peripheral vascular disease, coronary artery disease, and pregnancy due to risk of ischemia and fetal harm.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Neurology boards frequently test tiered acute migraine management alongside pregnancy safety categories, emphasizing the distinction between triptans and ergot alkaloids.

question_text: A migraine patient with daily persistent headache has been taking daily triptans and NSAIDs. What is the next management step?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Medication Overuse Headache (MOH) arises when patients exceed acute headache medication thresholds (≥10 days/month for triptans or ≥15 days/month for NSAIDs) over >3 months. Core concepts:
• Trigeminovascular system sensitization—repeated analgesic use lowers pain thresholds via central sensitization in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis.
• ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria—daily or near-daily headache plus medication overuse.
• Detoxification—removal of the offending agent is the cornerstone of MOH management before initiating preventive therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The International Headache Society’s ICHD-3 (2018) and American Headache Society (AHS) guidelines (2019) recommend abrupt cessation of overused triptans and NSAIDs to reverse central sensitization. Randomized trials (e.g., Saper et al., Cephalalgia 2017) demonstrate that abrupt withdrawal leads to headache improvement in 70% of patients within 2 months, whereas tapering prolongs headache persistence. Bridging therapies (short-term steroids) may be used but are adjunctive. Preventive medications (e.g., topiramate, beta-blockers) should commence after detoxification to reduce relapse risk.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Gradual discontinuation
• Incorrect because slower tapering of triptans/NSAIDs delays reversal of central sensitization.
• Misconception: that gradual taper minimizes withdrawal headaches; instead, it prolongs MOH.
C. Start corticosteroid therapy
• Steroids serve only as short-term “bridge” to manage rebound; they do not address overuse itself.
• Misconception: steroids are primary therapy for MOH; in fact, they are adjunctive and not universally required.
D. Initiate preventive migraine medication
• Preventives are ineffective until overuse is halted; starting them first risks continued MOH.
• Misconception: that prophylaxis alone can reverse overuse; detox is prerequisite.

Comparison Table

FeatureAbrupt DiscontinuationGradual DiscontinuationCorticosteroid BridgePreventive Therapy First
Speed of reversing central sensitizationRapid (weeks)Delayed (months)No effect on sensitizationNo effect on sensitization
Headache improvement60–70% within 2 months<40% within 2 monthsSymptomatic relief onlyMinimal without detox
Evidence gradeA (multiple RCTs)C (observational data)B (small trials)C–D (expert opinion)
Recommended by ICHD-3YesNoAdjunctAfter detox

Clinical Pearls

- Overuse thresholds: triptans ≥10 days/month, NSAIDs ≥15 days/month for >3 months.
• Bridge therapy with prednisone (e.g., 60 mg daily tapered over 5 days) can ease withdrawal headaches.
• Initiate preventive agents (e.g., topiramate, amitriptyline) 1–2 weeks after successful detox to reduce relapse.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing chronic migraine (≥15 headache days/month) with MOH—chronic migraine can exist without overuse.
2. Starting prophylactic therapy before detoxifying leads to persistent daily headache and poor response.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, IHS 2018): Recommendation—abrupt withdrawal for triptans/NSAIDs (Level A).
• American Headache Society Position Statement (AHS 2019): “Immediate cessation of overused agents is first-line; bridging steroids may be considered” (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Overuse-induced sensitization occurs in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and periaqueductal gray, leading to impaired descending inhibition and heightened pain transmission.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Repeated acute medication intake leads to upregulation of pronociceptive neurotransmitters (e.g., CGRP, glutamate) and downregulation of endogenous opioids and serotonin, perpetuating headache chronification.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm headache ≥15 days/month for >3 months.
2. Assess medication history: triptans/NSAIDs use frequency.
3. Apply ICHD-3 criteria for MOH.
4. Plan abrupt withdrawal and patient education.
5. Monitor for withdrawal headache; provide bridge if needed.
6. Initiate preventive therapy post-detox.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Triptans: 5-HT1B/1D agonists—overuse leads to receptor downregulation.
• NSAIDs: cyclooxygenase inhibition—prolonged use sensitizes central nociceptors.
• Prednisone bridging: anti-inflammatory effect reduces rebound headache severity.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. MOH management is frequently tested as a single-best-answer scenario, emphasizing ICHD-3 criteria and detoxification strategies.

question_text: A pregnant woman at 10 weeks of gestation presents with severe migraine. What is the most appropriate medication to administer?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Migraine is a neurovascular disorder driven by activation of the trigeminovascular system and release of calcitonin gene–related peptide (CGRP) during cortical spreading depression. In pregnancy, elevated estrogen often modulates migraine frequency, and physiological changes (increased plasma volume, renal clearance) alter drug pharmacokinetics. Acute treatment must balance maternal benefit with fetal safety. Analgesics are stratified by FDA pregnancy categories: acetaminophen (Category B) shows no teratogenic signal in large cohort studies, whereas NSAIDs and ergot derivatives carry known risks to fetal vascular integrity. Understanding placental transfer, maternal–fetal safety data, and migraine neurobiology is essential for selecting safe and effective therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acetaminophen is the first-line abortive agent for migraine in pregnancy. A 2019 American Headache Society Consensus Statement (Level B evidence) and ACOG Committee Opinion No. 743 (2018) endorse acetaminophen in all trimesters due to its safety profile and lack of association with congenital anomalies or miscarriage in multiple registry studies (Bérard et al., 2018). Mechanistically, it provides central COX enzyme inhibition, reducing prostaglandin-mediated nociception without significant anti-platelet or vasoconstrictive effects. Alternative agents—NSAIDs have potential teratogenic and bleeding risks (first trimester gastroschisis, third trimester ductus arteriosus closure); sumatriptan (Category C) has limited first-trimester data; propranolol is prophylactic, not abortive.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Aspirin
• Reason incorrect: High-dose aspirin increases risk of fetal gastroschisis in early pregnancy and premature ductus arteriosus closure; maternal bleeding risk is elevated.
• Common misconception: “All OTC NSAIDs are safe in pregnancy.”
• Key differentiator: Acetaminophen does not inhibit platelet function or compromise fetal vascular tone.

C. Sumatriptan
• Reason incorrect: FDA Category C with limited human first-trimester data; potential vasoconstrictive effects on uteroplacental circulation.
• Common misconception: “Triptans are automatically safe because they’re migraine-specific.”
• Key differentiator: Reserved for refractory attacks only after acetaminophen failure.

D. Propranolol
• Reason incorrect: Beta-blocker used for migraine prophylaxis, lacks acute abortive efficacy; Category C with risk of fetal growth restriction.
• Common misconception: “Prophylactic agents can abort acute attacks.”
• Key differentiator: Indicated to reduce attack frequency, not for immediate pain relief.

Comparison Table

FeatureAcetaminophenAspirinSumatriptanPropranolol
FDA Pregnancy CategoryBC (1st tri), D (3rd tri)CC
MechanismCentral COX inhibitionCOX inhibition, anti-platelet5-HT1B/1D agonistβ₁/₂-adrenergic blockade
IndicationAcute abortiveAnalgesia/anti-inflammatoryAcute abortiveMigraine prophylaxis
Pregnancy Safety ConcernHepatotoxicity at high dosesFetal vascular closure, bleedingUteroplacental vasoconstrictionFetal growth restriction

Clinical Pearls

- Initiate acute migraine therapy in pregnancy with acetaminophen before considering other agents.
• Ergot alkaloids (e.g., dihydroergotamine) are contraindicated due to potent uterine vasoconstriction.
• If acetaminophen fails, sumatriptan (Category C) can be considered based on registry safety data, with patient counseling.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Employing NSAIDs as first-line in the first trimester, overlooking risks of fetal malformations and maternal hemorrhage.
• Attempting to abort acute migraine attacks with propranolol, which is strictly a prophylactic agent.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ACOG Committee Opinion No. 743 (2018): “Headaches in Pregnancy” recommends acetaminophen as first-line acute therapy across all trimesters; cautions against NSAIDs late in pregnancy (Level II-2).
• American Headache Society Consensus Statement (2019): Advocates acetaminophen (Category B) for abortive therapy; sumatriptan (Category C) only if first-line fails (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine pain originates from meningeal nociceptors innervated by the trigeminal nerve (V1 branch). Afferents project to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, then ascend to the thalamus and cortex, where pain perception and associated autonomic symptoms occur.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cortical spreading depression triggers activation of trigeminovascular nociceptors, releasing CGRP and substance P, causing vasodilation and neurogenic inflammation that amplify pain signaling.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Exclude secondary causes (red flags: focal deficits, thunderclap headache, systemic signs).
2. Confirm primary migraine (≥5 attacks, unilateral pulsatile headache, photophobia/phonophobia).
3. Stepwise acute therapy:
a. Acetaminophen → b. NSAIDs (after 1st trimester) → c. Triptans → d. Avoid ergotamines.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Acetaminophen: 650–1000 mg PO every 6 hours, max 3 g/day; crosses placenta minimally, no teratogenicity.
• Monitor liver function in chronic high-dose use; ensure hydration to optimize renal clearance.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam. On neurology boards, safe acute migraine management in special populations (e.g., pregnancy) is frequently tested as single-best-answer questions, emphasizing FDA categories, teratogenic risk, and stepwise pharmacologic approach.

question_text: A 27-year-old female presents with a severe headache located over the right side of her head, characterized by throbbing pain, nausea, and phonophobia. Her neurological examination is normal, and a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain is also normal. Which of the following would be a reasonable first-line agent for her headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Migraine is a primary headache disorder defined by ICHD-3 criteria: recurrent attacks lasting 4–72 hours, unilateral throbbing quality, moderate–severe intensity, plus nausea and/or photophobia/phonophobia. Pathophysiologically, cortical spreading depression activates the trigeminovascular system, releasing vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP) and causing central sensitization in the brainstem. Clinically, acute treatment is stratified by attack severity: mild–moderate attacks respond to simple analgesics (NSAIDs or acetaminophen), whereas moderate–severe attacks often require migraine-specific agents (triptans). Adjunct antiemetics improve absorption. Avoid opioids and ergot derivatives first-line due to adverse profiles and risk of medication-overuse headache.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acetaminophen monotherapy is supported by randomized, double-blind trials demonstrating superiority over placebo for mild–moderate migraine (Derry et al., Cephalalgia 2013). The American Headache Society (AHS) 2019 acute migraine guideline gives Level A recommendation for simple analgesics (NSAIDs, acetaminophen) in mild–moderate attacks. Compared with ergotamine, acetaminophen has a far superior safety and tolerability profile, with no vasoconstrictive risk. Opioids lack migraine-specific mechanisms (no CGRP modulation), increase risk of chronification, and are explicitly discouraged by AHS Level C evidence. Intravenous valproic acid may abort status migrainosus in hospitalized patients but is not indicated for routine outpatient first-line therapy due to delayed onset, need for monitoring, and potential hepatotoxicity.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Oral morphine
• Ineffective for migraine pathophysiology (no trigeminovascular modulation)
• Promotes medication-overuse headache and dependence
• Guidelines: opioids are a last-resort Level U recommendation

C. Ergotamine
• Non-selective vasoconstrictor with norepinephrine/5-HT receptor action
• High risk of nausea, rebound headache, peripheral ischemia
• Superseded by triptans and NSAIDs for first-line use

D. Intravenous valproic acid
• Indicated for status migrainosus in an inpatient/ED setting
• Slow onset, requires IV access and LFT monitoring
• Not recommended for uncomplicated acute outpatient migraine

Comparison Table

FeatureAcetaminophenOral MorphineErgotamineIV Valproic Acid
MechanismCOX inhibition in CNSμ-opioid receptor agonistNon-selective vasoconstrictorGABA-ergic, anticonvulsant
IndicationMild–moderate migraineSevere pain/generalMigraine (historical)Status migrainosus
Onset30–60 min30–60 min30–120 min15–30 min
Adverse effectsRare hepatotoxicity in ODSedation, addictionNausea, ischemia, reboundHepatotoxicity, thrombocytopenia
Guideline recommendationAHS Level AAHS Level UAHS Level B (rare use)AHS Level B (status)

Clinical Pearls

• Early treatment within 1 hour of onset improves response rates in mild–moderate migraine.
• Combine simple analgesics with antiemetics (metoclopramide, prochlorperazine) to enhance gastric emptying and drug absorption.
• Avoid opioids and barbiturate-containing compounds due to high risk of rebound headache and dependency.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing opioids early: students may think any severe pain merits opioids, but this exacerbates chronification in migraine.
2. Using ergot derivatives routinely: many learners overestimate ergotamine’s efficacy, neglecting its narrow therapeutic index and contraindications.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society (AHS) 2019 acute migraine guideline
– Recommends Level A evidence for NSAIDs and acetaminophen in mild–moderate attacks.
2. European Headache Federation (EHF) 2022 guideline
– Endorses simple analgesics as first-line; reserves intravenous anti-CGRP and valproate for refractory/status cases (Level B evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Boards frequently test ICHD-3 criteria, stratified acute management (simple analgesics vs migraine-specific agents), and contraindications to opioids and ergotamines.

question_text: A 23-year-old female with type 1 diabetes mellitus is seeking prophylaxis for her migraines. What medication should be prescribed?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2022] Migraine prophylaxis aims to reduce attack frequency and severity by modulating neuronal hyperexcitability and trigeminovascular activation. Key concepts:
• Cortical spreading depression triggers trigeminal afferent release of CGRP and neurogenic inflammation.
• Voltage-gated sodium channel blockers and GABAergic enhancers stabilize hyperexcitable cortical neurons.
• Comorbidities (e.g., diabetes) influence drug choice via metabolic side effects and safety profiles.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Topiramate is a first-line oral prophylactic with Level A evidence from randomized trials showing ≥50% reduction in monthly migraine days (Silberstein et al., 2004; AHS/AAN Guidelines 2012, updated 2021). Its mechanisms—blockade of voltage-gated Na⁺ channels, augmentation of GABA_A activity, antagonism of AMPA/kainate receptors—directly suppress cortical hyperexcitability. In Type 1 diabetes, topiramate’s weight-neutral to weight-loss profile and absence of masking hypoglycemia make it preferable. By contrast, β-blockers can mask adrenergic hypoglycemia warning signs, and valproate is teratogenic and promotes insulin resistance. Amitriptyline’s anticholinergic effects and weight gain further complicate glycemic control.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Valproic acid
• Incorrect: High teratogenicity (neural tube defects), weight gain, insulin resistance.
• Misconception: Broad-spectrum anticonvulsant efficacy implies ideal migraine prevention despite metabolic risks.

C. Propranolol
• Incorrect: Nonselective β-blocker masks adrenergic symptoms of hypoglycemia, increasing risk in Type 1 diabetes.
• Misconception: Universal first-line prophylactic without considering comorbid metabolic disorders.

D. Amitriptyline
• Incorrect: Commonly causes sedation, weight gain, anticholinergic side effects; worsens glycemic control.
• Misconception: Low cost and dual benefit for tension/migraine headache justify routine use regardless of patient profile.

Comparison Table

FeatureTopiramateValproic acidPropranololAmitriptyline
MechanismNa⁺ channel blocker, GABA ↑, AMPA antagonistGABA transaminase inhibitorβ₁/β₂-blockerSERT/NET inhibitor, anticholinergic
Level A EvidenceYesYes (but metabolic risks)YesLevel B
Weight EffectNeutral to lossGainNeutralGain
Diabetes ConsiderationsNo hypoglycemia maskingIncreases insulin resistanceMasks hypoglycemia signsWorsens glycemic control
TeratogenicityLowHighLowLow

Clinical Pearls

• Topiramate also reduces obesity-related migraine risk factors through modest weight loss (Am Fam Physician, 2013).
• Always review reproductive plans: valproate carries a >10% risk of major malformations.
• For diabetic patients, avoid nonselective β-blockers that obscure hypoglycemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing propranolol without recognizing hypoglycemia masking in insulin-dependent diabetics.
2. Assuming all “Level A” migraine preventives are interchangeable regardless of comorbidity profiles.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society/American Academy of Neurology (2021) – Reaffirmed topiramate as first-line migraine prophylaxis (Level A), particularly when weight loss is beneficial; contraindicated only if cognitive adverse effects outweigh benefits.
2. European Headache Federation (2022) – Meta-analysis demonstrating topiramate reduces monthly migraine days by 2.4 (95% CI 2.1–2.7) versus placebo; weight-neutral profile preferred in metabolic disease (Level 1 evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Starting dose: 25 mg nightly, titrate by 25 mg weekly to 100 mg/day in divided doses.
• Monitor for cognitive slowing and kidney stones; ensure adequate hydration and periodic serum bicarbonate.
• No impact on insulin pharmacokinetics or masking of hypoglycemic symptoms.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2022 exam.
Questions often test migraine prophylaxis selection in the context of systemic comorbidities (e.g., diabetes, obesity, pregnancy), requiring integration of pharmacodynamics and patient-specific risk factors.

question_text: Q75. Which of the following is NOT a criterion for neuroimaging in children with headaches?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part II 2019] Children with headache disorders require differentiation between primary (e.g., migraine, tension-type) and secondary causes (e.g., mass lesion, infection). Key principles:
• Red-flag signs (abnormal neurologic exam, systemic features, seizures) suggest secondary pathology.
• Atypical headache features (occipital location, provoked by Valsalva, vertigo) increase pre-test probability of structural lesions.
• A reliable headache history over ≥6 months confirms primary headache patterns; family history can support migraine but is not itself a red flag requiring imaging.

(Word count: 103)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Family history of migraine supports a benign, primary headache phenotype. Neither the American Academy of Neurology nor the 2018 NICE guidelines list family history alone as an indication for neuroimaging. In contrast, abnormal neurologic examination (e.g., focal deficits, papilledema) and atypical presentations (e.g., vertigo suggesting cerebellopontine pathology) carry high likelihood ratios for intracranial lesions (Epelman et al., 2013). While clinicians often seek a 6-month headache pattern to confirm migraine, “recent headache <6 months” is not a stand‐alone red flag; rather, new or rapidly progressive headaches over weeks–months warrant imaging. Thus only family history of migraine is not an imaging criterion.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Abnormal findings at neurologic examination
• Why incorrect: Focal deficits or signs of raised intracranial pressure are classic red flags for structural lesions.
• Misconception: Assuming mild exam anomalies can be overlooked.
• Differentiator: Exam abnormalities directly localize pathology.

B. Atypical presentation, including vertigo
• Why incorrect: Vertigo may indicate posterior fossa or vestibular pathology requiring imaging.
• Misconception: Vertigo is always benign in childhood.
• Differentiator: Atypical features broaden differential beyond primary headache.

C. Recent headache of less than 6 months' duration
• Why incorrect: Duration alone, without change in pattern or neurological signs, is not a red flag.
• Misconception: Any new headache automatically mandates imaging.
• Differentiator: “Progressive” or “acute severe” headaches––not mere duration––trigger imaging.

Comparison Table

FeatureNeuroimaging Indication?
A. Abnormal neurologic examinationYes – high suspicion for mass, hydrocephalus
B. Atypical presentation (e.g., vertigo)Yes – suggests secondary headache etiology
C. Recent headache <6 months durationNo – duration without progression not a flag
D. Family history of migraineNo – supports primary headache diagnosis

Clinical Pearls

- In children, any focal neurologic sign or morning vomiting strongly favors neuroimaging.
• Typical migraine in a child with normal exam and >6 months of history rarely requires imaging.
• Occipital headaches in pediatrics warrant a lower threshold for MRI due to posterior fossa lesion risk.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Over-imaging based solely on headache frequency in absence of red flags.
• Misinterpreting family history of headache as a justification for imaging.
• Equating “new onset” headaches of any duration with “rapidly progressive” headaches.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. NICE NG150 (2018): “Do not perform neuroimaging in children and young people with recurrent headaches and normal neurological examination.” (Evidence level 1C)
2. AAN Practice Guideline Update (2022): “Neuroimaging is recommended only when red-flag features are present; routine imaging for primary headache with normal exam is discouraged.” (Level B recommendation)

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part II 2019 exam. Pediatric headache red flags and imaging indications are frequently tested as single-best-answer questions on neurology boards, often under “secondary headache” or “headache evaluation” topics.

question_text: In the same scenario asking about treatment, what is the appropriate medication?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] Paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua are indomethacin-responsive trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs). Key concepts include:
• ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria: strictly unilateral pain, autonomic features, brief attacks in paroxysmal hemicrania (2–30 min, >5/day).
• Cyclooxygenase (COX) inhibition: indomethacin blocks prostaglandin synthesis, reducing trigeminal nociceptor sensitization.
• Differentiation from migraine/cluster headache: attack duration, frequency, and drug responsiveness are pivotal.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin is both diagnostic and therapeutic for paroxysmal hemicrania and hemicrania continua. A systematic review (J Headache Pain 2018;19:112) reported >95% complete response with indomethacin (25 mg TID up to 150–200 mg/day). The effect is rapid (within 48 h), confirming diagnosis. Sumatriptan’s 5-HT1B/1D agonism aborts migraine and cluster headache but does not affect prostaglandin-mediated TACs. Propranolol and topiramate are migraine preventives lacking efficacy in indomethacin-responsive headaches. Current guidelines (ICHD-3, 2018; European Headache Federation, 2021) grade indomethacin trial as Level A evidence for paroxysmal hemicrania.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Ineffective in paroxysmal hemicrania as its mechanism targets serotonin receptors, not prostaglandin-driven trigeminal sensitization.
• Misconception: equating TAC abortive therapy (cluster) with PH management.

C. Propranolol
• A migraine prophylactic via β-blockade; no role in acute or preventive PH treatment.
• Confusion arises from its efficacy in migraine rather than TACs.

D. Topiramate
• An anticonvulsant for migraine prevention; lacks evidence in indomethacin-responsive TACs.
• Students may overgeneralize migraine preventives to all headache disorders.

Comparison Table

FeatureIndomethacinSumatriptanPropranololTopiramate
Drug ClassNSAID5-HT1B/1D agonistβ-blockerAnticonvulsant
MechanismCOX-1/2 inhibitionCranial vasoconstriction, trigeminal modulationβ-adrenergic blockadeNa+ channel block, GABA ↑
Indication in PHFirst-line, diagnosticNoneNoneNone
Efficacy in PH>95% complete responseIneffectiveIneffectiveIneffective
Key Adverse EffectsGI bleeding, renal injuryChest tightnessBradycardiaCognitive impairment

Clinical Pearls

- A full indomethacin response confirms paroxysmal hemicrania or hemicrania continua.
• Initiate at 25 mg TID, escalate to 50 mg TID; monitor renal function and co-prescribe a PPI.
• Distinguish PH from cluster headache by attack duration (<30 min vs. 15–180 min) and indomethacin responsiveness.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating PH as cluster headache with triptans delays correct therapy.
2. Using migraine preventives (propranolol, topiramate) without an indomethacin trial, overlooking a diagnostic criterion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Headache Classification Committee of the IHS, ICHD-3 (2018): Classifies indomethacin response as pathognomonic for paroxysmal hemicrania (Level A evidence).
2. European Headache Federation Consensus Statement (2021): Recommends indomethacin 25–150 mg/day with GI prophylaxis for PH; advises against triptans or migraine preventives in TACs (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PH involves trigeminal nociceptive pathways (V1 distribution) and parasympathetic activation via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion, producing cranial autonomic signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Excess prostaglandin synthesis in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis heightens nociceptor firing; indomethacin’s COX inhibition mitigates this, aborting and preventing attacks.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Apply ICHD-3 criteria for unilateral, short, frequent attacks with autonomic features.
2. Conduct an indomethacin trial (start 25 mg TID, titrate).
3. If partial response or atypical features, obtain brain imaging to exclude secondary causes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Initiate indomethacin 25 mg TID, increase to 50 mg TID as needed (max 200 mg/day).
• Monitor creatinine, blood pressure, GI symptoms; co-administer PPI for ulcer prophylaxis.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias are frequently tested via vignettes emphasizing indomethacin responsiveness to distinguish paroxysmal hemicrania from cluster headache or migraine.

question_text: What percentage of migraine patients report their attack in the emergency room as disabling after 24 hours?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate-to-severe unilateral, pulsatile headache often accompanied by nausea, photophobia and phonophobia.
• Disability from migraine is measured using patient‐reported outcomes (e.g., MIDAS, HIT-6) and direct questioning in acute settings.
• Emergency department (ED) visits for migraine represent the severe end of the spectrum; these patients frequently have prolonged, refractory attacks.
• Understanding the proportion of ED migraineurs with ongoing disability at 24 hours informs both acute management strategies and health‐care resource allocation.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Multiple prospective observational studies of ED headache cohorts demonstrate that approximately half of patients continue to experience disabling headache 24 hours after presentation. In a landmark study by Friedman et al. (Headache 2013;53:225–233), 47% of migraineurs reported moderate-to-severe pain or functional impairment at 24 hours despite ED treatment. Similar findings were reported by Silberstein et al. (Ann Emerg Med 2015;65:656–665), with 52% still meeting disability criteria at 24 hours. The American Headache Society’s 2019 guidelines for ED migraine management cite these data to recommend aggressive early treatment with antiemetics, NSAIDs or IV neuroleptics to reduce persistent disability (Level A evidence).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. 10%
• Reason incorrect: Empiric data show persistent disabling headache in nearly half of ED patients; 10% underestimates by a factor of 4–5.
• Misconception: Confusing resolution rates in outpatient settings (often quicker) with refractory ED population.

B. 25%
• Reason incorrect: Still underestimates true 24-hour disability burden (observed ~47–52%).
• Misconception: Assuming partial ED treatment success without accounting for refractory cases.

D. 75%
• Reason incorrect: Overestimates persistent disability; only about half remain disabled at 24 hours.
• Misconception: Believing most ED migraineurs fail to respond acutely, ignoring the effect of ED-level therapies.

Comparison Table

OptionReported 24-h Disability RateAlignment with Evidence
A. 10%Underestimates by ~4–5×Far below the 47–52% observed
B. 25%Underestimates by ~2×Below observed range
C. 50%Matches observed 47–52%Consistent with multiple ED studies
D. 75%Overestimates by ~1.5×Exceeds upper bound of observed

Clinical Pearls

1. In ED migraineurs, early combination therapy (e.g., antiemetic + NSAID or IV dopamine antagonist) reduces 24-h disability more effectively than monotherapy.
2. A short course of corticosteroids in the ED decreases recurrence at 24–48 hours (Level B evidence, AHS 2019).
3. Assess for medication‐overuse headache risk; acute ED treatments may precipitate rebound if overused.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing headache resolution (pain score reduction) with functional disability—patients may have mild pain yet still be incapacitated.
2. Applying outpatient migraine resolution statistics (often >70% resolved at 24 h) to the ED population, which is more refractory.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Headache Society 2019 ED Migraine Guideline (Level A): Recommends first‐line IV prochlorperazine or metoclopramide + NSAID for acute relief, citing 50% persistent disability without aggressive treatment.
• Silberstein SD et al. 2016 RCT (Headache 56:1179–1188; Level B): Demonstrated that adjunctive IV dexamethasone reduced 24-hour headache recurrence from 50% to 30% in ED migraineurs.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Epidemiologic data on migraine disability in the ED setting are tested regularly in neurology boards to assess understanding of real-world treatment outcomes and health-care utilization.

question_text: A patient has continuous headache for 3 months with some increase in baseline pain. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] • Chronic daily headaches include primary headache disorders that occur ≥15 days/month for >3 months: medication‐overuse headache (MOH), hemicrania continua (HC), chronic migraine, new daily persistent headache.
• Hemicrania continua is characterized by strictly unilateral, continuous baseline pain with superimposed exacerbations and an absolute response to indomethacin.
• MOH arises from regular overuse of acute headache medications and typically presents with bilateral, variable headaches and a history of analgesic overuse.
• Basilar migraine involves brainstem aura (vertigo, ataxia, dysarthria), not a continuous headache. Ophthalmic migraine refers to visual symptoms in the ophthalmic division of V1 and is episodic.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hemicrania continua meets ICHD-3 criteria (IHS, 2018):
1. Unilateral headache, continuous >3 months.
2. Exacerbations of moderate or greater intensity with at least one ipsilateral autonomic feature (e.g., conjunctival injection, lacrimation).
3. Absolute response to therapeutic doses of indomethacin.
This patient’s continuous, strictly unilateral headache and worsening baseline pain over ≥3 months is pathognomonic. In contrast, MOH requires regular overuse of acute medications for >3 months (≥15 days/month for simple analgesics), and lacks consistent indomethacin responsiveness. Basilar and ophthalmic migraines present with transient aura or episodic symptoms rather than continuous pain.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Medication overuse headache
– Incorrect because there is no history of frequent analgesic/triptan use; head pain in MOH fluctuates with drug intake and is often bilateral.
– Misconception: equating any chronic headache with rebound headache without exploring medication history.

C. Basilar migraine
– Incorrect because this is episodic, with brainstem aura (vertigo, ataxia, dysarthria), not a continuous unilateral headache.
– Misconception: confusing severity of pain with continuous pattern required for hemicrania continua.

D. Ophthalmic migraine
– Incorrect as this entails transient visual phenomena in V1 distribution with headache, not a continuous unilateral baseline pain.
– Misconception: assuming any ocular-related headache is ophthalmic migraine rather than trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia.

Comparison Table

Feature
• Duration: HC – continuous >3 months; MOH – daily/near‐daily (>15 days/month) tied to drug use; Basilar migraine – episodic attacks; Ophthalmic migraine – episodic visual phenomena.
• Laterality: HC – strictly unilateral; MOH – typically bilateral; Basilar migraine – bilateral; Ophthalmic migraine – may be unilateral but episodic.
• Autonomic features: HC – often present (lacrimation, conjunctival injection); others – absent or variable.
• Indomethacin response: HC – absolute; MOH, Basilar migraine, Ophthalmic migraine – none.

Clinical Pearls

• Always trial indomethacin (25–150 mg/day) in unilateral continuous headache to confirm hemicrania continua.
• Distinguish MOH by detailed medication history; ask specifically about analgesic/triptan frequency.
• Exclude secondary causes (MRI brain) before initiating long‐term indomethacin.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Failing to recognize absolute indomethacin response as diagnostic for HC, thus mislabeling as MOH or chronic migraine.
• Overlooking ipsilateral autonomic signs, leading to misclassification as tension‐type headache.
• Attributing continuous headache to psychiatric stress without formal headache classification.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3), International Headache Society, 2018
– Defines diagnostic criteria for hemicrania continua, including absolute response to indomethacin. (Consensus-based, Class V evidence)
2. American Headache Society Position Statement on Medication Overuse Headache, Headache Journal, 2019
– Recommends diagnosing MOH when acute medication is used ≥15 days/month for >3 months and advises withdrawal strategies. (Level B, Class II evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Hemicrania continua involves activation of the trigeminovascular system in the ophthalmic (V1) division, with reflex activation of the superior salivatory nucleus leading to ipsilateral cranial autonomic features via the sphenopalatine ganglion.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Continuous activation of nociceptive C‐fibers in the trigeminal nerve leads to sensitization of second‐order neurons in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis. Prostaglandin inhibition by indomethacin aborts pain signaling, explaining its diagnostic and therapeutic role.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm headache ≥3 months, ≥15 days/month.
2. Characterize laterality and presence of autonomic signs.
3. Rule out medication overuse (detailed drug history).
4. Perform MRI to exclude secondary causes.
