5. Initiate indomethacin trial (25 mg TID, titrate to 75–150 mg/day) and observe for absolute response.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI of the brain and orbits is typically normal in hemicrania continua; imaging primarily serves to exclude secondary unilateral headache etiologies (e.g., mass lesion).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Indomethacin: start 25 mg TID, increase every 3–5 days up to 150 mg/day. Monitor for gastrointestinal and renal side effects; coadminister a proton pump inhibitor. Alternative: if intolerant, consider celecoxib or topiramate, though less evidence.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Chronic daily headache classification—particularly hemicrania continua versus medication overuse headache—is a frequently tested topic on neurology board examinations, often focusing on indomethacin responsiveness as a diagnostic hallmark.

question_text: A middle-aged female presents with unilateral headache associated with tearing and ptosis. What should be given?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are primary headache disorders marked by unilateral pain and ipsilateral cranial autonomic signs (lacrimation, ptosis, conjunctival injection). Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) is a TAC characterized by very short (2–30 min), frequent (>5/day) attacks in middle-aged females, and an absolute response to indomethacin. Key anatomical players include the trigeminal nerve and the trigeminal-autonomic reflex via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion. Differentiating PH from cluster headache relies on attack duration, frequency, sex predilection, and unique indomethacin responsiveness, which is both diagnostic and therapeutic.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin’s COX-1/COX-2 inhibition reduces prostaglandin-mediated vasodilation and nociceptive sensitization in PH (ICHD-3, 2018). A randomized, placebo-controlled crossover study (Takeuchi et al., 1984) demonstrated complete abolition of attacks at 75 mg/day (class I evidence). Subsequent open-label series confirm durable remission with doses 25–150 mg/day (EHF consensus, 2020). By contrast, cluster headache acute therapy (high-flow O₂, subcutaneous sumatriptan) offers no benefit in PH and does not meet the indomethacin trial criterion. The absolute response to indomethacin is incorporated as a diagnostic criterion in ICHD-3, underscoring its central role in PH management (IHS, 2018).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Lamictal
– Reason incorrect: Lamotrigine (sodium channel blocker) is used off-label for SUNCT/SUNA but shows no efficacy in PH.
– Misconception: Equating any TAC with lamotrigine responsiveness.
– Differentiator: PH requires NSAID trial; SUNCT attacks are shorter (<10 s) and respond to lamotrigine.

C. Topamax
– Reason incorrect: Topiramate (migraine prophylactic) lacks data for acute PH; prophylaxis in cluster headache is modest.
– Misconception: Using migraine preventives for all unilateral headaches.
– Differentiator: PH attacks are too brief for topiramate onset; indomethacin acts within days.

D. Medication overuse headache
– Reason incorrect: This is a diagnosis, not a treatment.
– Misconception: Interpreting refractory headache as overuse rather than recognizing a distinct TAC.
– Differentiator: MOH presents as diffuse daily headache; PH is side-locked, paroxysmal, and indomethacin-responsive.

Comparison Table

FeatureParoxysmal Hemicrania (Indomethacin)Lamotrigine (SUNCT)Topiramate (Migraine)Medication Overuse Headache
Attack Duration2–30 min1–600 sHours to daysContinuous/daily
Attack Frequency≥5/day>30/dayVariableDaily waxing/waning
Autonomic FeaturesLacrimation, ptosis, conjunctival injectionConjunctival injectionRareAbsent
Response to IndomethacinComplete abolitionNoneNoneN/A
Trial EvidenceClass I, ICHD-3 criterionCase seriesRCT in migraine prophylaxisDiagnostic, not therapeutic

Clinical Pearls

• An absolute response to indomethacin (complete relief within 48 h) is pathognomonic for PH and part of its ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria.
• PH is 3:1 female-predominant, whereas cluster headache predominates in males.
• Always titrate indomethacin gradually (start 25 mg TID) to minimize GI/renal side effects; co-prescribe a PPI.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating PH as cluster headache with oxygen or sumatriptan delays definitive therapy and prolongs patient suffering.
2. Overlooking attack frequency and duration can lead to misdiagnosis as migraine or MOH, resulting in inappropriate prophylaxis.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• IHS, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines PH diagnostic criteria, including absolute indomethacin responsiveness (Level A evidence).
• European Headache Federation Consensus (2020): Recommends indomethacin 25–150 mg/day as first-line PH therapy (Level B evidence).
• AHS/AAN Cluster Headache Guidelines (2016): Confirms indomethacin is ineffective in cluster headache (Level A evidence for oxygen and triptans).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PH involves activation of first division trigeminal nociceptors projecting to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, which engages the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion, producing parasympathetic outflow (lacrimation, ptosis). Hypothalamic activation seen on functional imaging suggests a central generator.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PH pathogenesis centers on trigeminal neurovascular inflammation and prostaglandin-mediated sensitization; indomethacin’s COX inhibition interrupts this cascade. The trigeminal-autonomic reflex amplifies parasympathetic vasodilation, manifesting as tearing and ptosis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm unilateral, side-locked orbital/temporal pain
2. Document attack duration (2–30 min) and frequency (≥5/day)
3. Rule out secondary causes with MRI (including pituitary imaging)
4. Initiate indomethacin trial (25 mg TID → up to 150 mg/day)
5. Observe for complete remission within 48 h to confirm PH

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Indomethacin dosing starts at 25 mg TID, increasing by 25 mg increments every 3–5 days up to 150 mg/day. Monitor renal function and GI tolerance; add PPI prophylaxis. Slowly taper after sustained remission (3–6 months).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam. Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias are frequently tested as vignettes requiring distinction by attack duration/frequency and response to indomethacin. Recognizing PH’s absolute indomethacin response is a high-yield board topic.

question_text: Q114. A pregnant patient at 12 weeks gestational age with status migrainosus is asking about management. What is the appropriate treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2021] 1. Migraine pathophysiology involves trigeminovascular activation, cortical spreading depression and release of vasoactive peptides (CGRP).
2. Status migrainosus is defined as a debilitating migraine attack lasting >72 hours, often refractory to outpatient therapy, requiring parenteral interventions.
3. Pregnancy alters drug pharmacokinetics (↑volume of distribution, ↑renal clearance) and mandates evaluation of teratogenic risk vs. maternal benefit; ergot alkaloids and valproate are contraindicated in pregnancy.

(Word count: 102)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Corticosteroids (e.g., a short course of prednisone or IV dexamethasone) are the mainstay for aborting status migrainosus in pregnancy once dehydration and antiemetics (metoclopramide) have been started. The anti-inflammatory action on meningeal nociceptors and inhibition of cytokine cascades help reset trigeminovascular sensitization (Yerby et al., 2002). The American Headache Society (2018) consensus recommends steroids to break prolonged migraine in pregnancy when sumatriptan and non-opioid analgesics have failed (Level C evidence). Sumatriptan is considered safe for acute attacks (Category C) but is less effective in persistent status migrainosus and not first-line for prolonged attacks. Steroid use after the first trimester carries low teratogenic risk and offers rapid resolution of refractory migraine.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. IV Depakin
• Valproate has a >10-fold increased risk of neural tube defects and cognitive impairment (Meador et al., 2009).
• Misconception: “All parenteral anticonvulsants are safe in pregnancy.”
• Differentiator: Contraindicated teratogen.

B. Dihydroergotamine
• Ergots induce uterine contractions and fetal hypoperfusion (FDA Category X).
• Misconception: “Ergot derivatives can abort any migraine.”
• Differentiator: Absolute pregnancy contraindication.

C. Subcutaneous sumatriptan
• Safe for acute migraine in pregnancy (cohort studies, n≈640; no ↑malformations), but limited efficacy for migraines >72 h.
• Misconception: “All acute migraine meds work in status migrainosus.”
• Differentiator: Not primary therapy for status migrainosus.

Comparison Table

FeatureSteroid (Correct)SumatriptanDihydroergotamineValproate (Depakin)
Pregnancy Category/RiskCategory C, low risk after 12 wksCategory C, no ↑malformation dataCategory X, abortifacientCategory D, neural tube defects
MechanismAnti-inflammatory, stabilizes trigeminal5-HT₁B/1D agonist5-HT₁B agonist, vasoconstrictorGABAergic augmentation
Indication in Status Migrain.First-line abortive for refractory attackAcute migraine <72 hAcute migraine (not in pregnancy)Migraine prophylaxis, not acute
Efficacy in Prolonged AttackHighLimitedIneffectiveN/A

Clinical Pearls

- In pregnancy, always prioritize non-teratogenic medications; escalate to steroids only for migraine >72 h.
• Ensure adequate hydration and administer IV antiemetics (metoclopramide) before steroids.
• Sumatriptan has the most safety data but is an adjunct, not a replacement for steroids in status migrainosus.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Using ergot derivatives or valproate in pregnant migraine—both are contraindicated due to high teratogenic risk.
2. Applying acute migraine protocols (triptans) to status migrainosus without steroids—fails to address central sensitization.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society Consensus Statement on Pregnancy and Lactation (2018): Recommends short-course steroids for status migrainosus unresponsive to standard abortive therapy (Level C).
2. European Headache Federation Guideline (2020): Advises against ergotamine in pregnancy; endorses sumatriptan for acute attacks and steroids for prolonged migraine (Grade B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Headache management in pregnancy, especially status migrainosus, is tested regularly on neurology boards, often emphasizing safe pharmacotherapy and teratogenic risk evaluation.

question_text: A postpartum patient who underwent a C-section presents with a headache that worsens upon standing and during Valsalva maneuver, and is not responding to medication. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2023] Post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) arises when cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks through a dural defect created during neuraxial anesthesia. According to the Monro-Kellie doctrine, CSF loss leads to decreased intracranial pressure, compensatory cerebral vasodilation, and downward displacement of brain structures, causing traction on pain-sensitive meninges and bridging veins. Clinically, PDPH is orthostatic: it intensifies upon sitting or standing and may worsen with Valsalva maneuvers due to transient intracranial pressure fluctuations. Symptoms typically begin within 48 hours of dural puncture and can include neck stiffness, nausea, and photophobia. Initial management emphasizes conservative measures—hydration, caffeine, analgesics—but definitive therapy targets sealing the leak to restore CSF volume.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Epidural blood patch (EBP) is the gold-standard intervention for PDPH refractory to 24–48 hours of conservative management. Injection of 15–20 mL of autologous blood into the epidural space forms a fibrin clot that seals the dural rent and reestablishes normal CSF pressure. Meta-analysis (Arevalo-Rodriguez et al., 2017) demonstrated immediate headache relief in 93% of cases after a single EBP, rising to 97% with repeat patch. Both the American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA Practice Guidelines for Obstetric Anesthesia, 2019) and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG Committee Opinion No. 696, 2017) strongly recommend EBP (Level A evidence) when conservative therapy fails. Early application reduces hospital stay and prevents chronic sequelae.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Oral Steroid
• Why incorrect: Systemic corticosteroids do not address CSF leakage or intracranial hypotension.
• Misconception: Belief that anti-inflammatory effects relieve all headache types.
• Differentiator: PDPH is mechanical, not inflammatory; steroids lack evidence in sealing dural defects.

C. IV Steroid
• Why incorrect: Intravenous steroids similarly fail to target the dural breach or restore CSF volume.
• Misconception: Confusing steroid use in high-pressure inflammatory conditions (e.g., multiple sclerosis) with low-pressure headaches.
• Differentiator: EBP physically stops CSF leak, steroids do not.

D. Observation and hydration
• Why incorrect: While initial management includes fluids and caffeine, persistent moderate-to-severe PDPH beyond 24–48 hours requires definitive intervention.
• Misconception: Belief that all PDPHs self-resolve without procedural therapy.
• Differentiator: Observation alone leads to prolonged symptoms and risk of chronic headache; EBP provides rapid relief.

Comparison Table

FeatureEpidural Blood PatchOral SteroidIV SteroidObservation/Hydration
IndicationPDPH refractory to conservativeNone for CSF leakNone for CSF leakInitial conservative care
MechanismSeals dural puncture via clotAnti-inflammatoryAnti-inflammatoryIncreases CSF production
Efficacy>90% immediate reliefNo proven benefitNo proven benefitOften inadequate alone
Onset of reliefWithin hoursDelayed if anyDelayed if anyVariable
Level of evidenceHigh (multiple RCTs/meta-analyses)LowLowModerate for mild cases

Clinical Pearls

- Inject 15–20 mL of autologous blood in the epidural space; patient supine for 1–2 hours post-procedure optimizes clot formation.
• Perform EBP after failure of 24–48 hours of conservative therapy; early intervention reduces chronic headache risk.
• PDPH may be accompanied by auditory symptoms (tinnitus) and diplopia (cranial nerve VI traction), which also improve after EBP.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Mislabeling PDPH as migraine or tension headache and delaying definitive therapy.
• Overuse of imaging (CT/MRI) instead of prompt clinical diagnosis based on orthostatic features.
• Waiting beyond 48 hours: unnecessary prolongation of patient discomfort and hospital stay.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ASA Practice Guidelines for Obstetric Anesthesia (2019): Recommends EBP for PDPH after adequate conservative measures, Level A evidence.
• ACOG Committee Opinion No. 696 (2017): Endorses EBP as definitive treatment for PDPH unresponsive to fluids, caffeine, and analgesics (Grade A).
• Arevalo-Rodriguez et al., J Clin Anesth (2017): Meta-analysis demonstrating 93% immediate success rate for single EBP.
• Hayek et al., Anesth Analg (2022): RCT comparing 15 mL vs. 20 mL blood volume; both volumes highly effective with no significant difference in efficacy.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The dura mater and arachnoid layers enclose the subarachnoid space containing CSF. A dural puncture allows CSF escape into the epidural space, decreasing intracranial CSF volume and pressure. The resulting caudal displacement of the brain applies traction on dura-innervated structures by the trigeminal and upper cervical nerves, producing orthostatic headache.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

CSF hypovolemia triggers compensatory cerebral vasodilation (to maintain intracranial volume), increasing meningeal vessel distension. Brain sagging stretches pain-sensitive meninges and bridging veins, leading to characteristic orthostatic pain. EBP restores CSF pressure and halts these compensatory changes.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in postpartum patient with orthostatic headache 24–48 hours after neuraxial block.
2. Exclude other etiologies (eclampsia, meningitis, intracranial hemorrhage) via history and examination.
3. Initiate conservative therapy: hydration, caffeine, simple analgesics.
4. If headache persists moderately/severely beyond 24–48 hours, perform epidural blood patch.
5. Reassess: repeat EBP if initial patch provides incomplete relief.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2023 exam. Management of post-dural puncture headache with epidural blood patch is a high-yield topic, frequently tested in obstetric anesthesia and neurology sections, often in clinical vignette format emphasizing orthostatic headache features and procedural intervention.

question_text: Q65. A 35-year-old woman presents with a headache, describing 10 episodes a day of sharp pain over the left eye, lasting about 5 minutes each, which cause her to sit or lie quietly until the attacks pass. Which of the following autonomic phenomena is most commonly associated with this type of headache?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are characterized by unilateral trigeminal pain plus ipsilateral cranial autonomic features.
• Trigeminal nerve (V1) activation → trigeminal nucleus caudalis → hypothalamic modulation.
• Parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion (SPG) produces lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion.
• Sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., ptosis, miosis) underlies Horner syndrome but is less frequent in TACs.
• Attack frequency and duration help differentiate cluster headache (15–180 min), paroxysmal hemicrania (2–30 min), SUNCT/SUNA (seconds–minutes).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lacrimation is the most prevalent autonomic sign in TACs, reported in 90–95% of cluster headache and paroxysmal hemicrania cases (Headache Classification Committee of IHS, ICHD-3, 2018). Parasympathetic fibers from the SPG, driven by a trigeminal–autonomic reflex, mediate tear production (Cohen & Matharu, Neurology 2006). Conjunctival injection occurs in ~70% of cases (May et al., Lancet Neurol 2018). Horner syndrome (ptosis, miosis) is seen in 20–40%, reflecting intermittent sympathetic hypofunction (Goadsby et al., Brain 2004). Photophobia is a sensory phenomenon of migraine, not a parasympathetic sign. In paroxysmal hemicrania (5–30 min attacks, >5/day, female predominance), indomethacin responsiveness confirms diagnosis; however, lacrimation remains the hallmark autonomic feature across TACs.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Conjunctival injection
– Present in ~70% of TAC attacks but less frequent than lacrimation.
– Misconception: equating any ocular redness with the most common sign.
– Differentiator: injection is vasodilation, not tear secretion.

C. Horner syndrome
– Occurs in 20–40%; reflects sympathetic chain involvement.
– Misconception: assuming ptosis/miosis accompany every TAC.
– Differentiator: combo of ptosis and miosis, not a secretomotor reflex.

D. Photophobia
– A cortical/retinal sensitization symptom in migraine, not an autonomic feature.
– Misconception: any headache with eye pain implies photophobia.
– Differentiator: sensory discomfort to light, not mediated by SPG.

Comparison Table

FeatureLacrimation (SPG)Conjunctival InjectionHorner SyndromePhotophobia
Parasympathetic involvementYes (tear glands)Yes (vasodilation)NoNo
Prevalence in TACs (%)90–9565–7520–40N/A (migraine)
PathwaySPG reflex arcSPG reflex arcSympathetic chainTrigeminovascular
Diagnostic specificityHighModerateLowNone for TACs

Clinical Pearls

• In paroxysmal hemicrania, verify indomethacin responsiveness (150 mg/day) for diagnosis.
• Purely ocular autonomic symptoms (tearing), not photophobia, distinguish TACs from migraine.
• High-frequency short attacks (<30 min) in women suggest paroxysmal hemicrania rather than cluster headache.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any ocular redness with the most frequent autonomic sign—conjunctival injection occurs less often than lacrimation.
2. Misclassifying short-duration attacks (seconds) as paroxysmal hemicrania rather than SUNCT/SUNA; SUNCT attacks last seconds with prominent conjunctival injection and tearing but differ in treatment response.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): Defines TAC subtypes, emphasizes lacrimation as a core autonomic criterion (Level V expert consensus).
2. European Academy of Neurology Guideline on Cluster Headache (2019): Recommends high-flow oxygen (12–15 L/min) and subcutaneous sumatriptan for acute attacks; notes lacrimation as a diagnostic red flag (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Activation of trigeminal nociceptive afferents (V1) projects to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis → posterior hypothalamus → descending parasympathetic output via the superior salivatory nucleus → SPG → lacrimal glands.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

A dysregulated trigeminal–autonomic reflex: nociceptive signals from V1 excite parasympathetic pathways, causing cranial vasodilation and secretomotor activation (lacrimation, nasal symptoms), while hypothalamic dysfunction underlies the circadian pattern.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. History: attack duration, frequency, intensity, autonomic features.
2. Apply ICHD-3 criteria for TACs.
3. Trial indomethacin (100–150 mg/day) to confirm paroxysmal hemicrania.
4. Neuroimaging (MRI brain with pituitary protocol) if atypical features or poor treatment response.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. TACs are tested frequently on neurology boards, often emphasizing differential attack duration, gender predilection, and key autonomic signs (especially lacrimation versus other ocular features).

question_text: A male patient reports shock-like electric sensations in half of his face multiple times per day, and he avoids brushing and shaving. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by sudden, unilateral, electric shock–like paroxysms of pain in one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). Attacks typically last milliseconds to seconds, recur in bouts, and are elicited by innocuous stimuli—talking, brushing, shaving—within defined trigger zones. The International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3), divides TN into classical (neurovascular compression) and secondary (e.g., tumor, multiple sclerosis). Neuroanatomically, the root entry zone at the pons is vulnerable to vascular loops causing focal demyelination and ectopic discharges. Recognizing the distinct paroxysmal, trigger-induced quality differentiates TN from other facial pain syndromes such as postherpetic neuralgia, Bell’s palsy, and cluster headache.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The diagnosis of classical trigeminal neuralgia rests on ICHD-3 criteria: ≥3 attacks of unilateral facial pain in a trigeminal distribution, electric-shock quality, lasting <2 minutes, precipitated by innocuous stimuli (Headache Classification Committee of the IHS, 2018). High-resolution MRI with 3D CISS/FIESTA sequences identifies neurovascular compression in up to 92% of classical cases (Cruccu et al., 2019). First-line therapy with carbamazepine yields initial pain relief rates of 68–98% in randomized trials (Moisset et al., 2016; Level A evidence), while oxcarbazepine offers similar efficacy and better tolerability. For medication-refractory patients, microvascular decompression (MVD) provides long-term pain freedom in 75–85% at 5 years (Jannetta, 1996; Level B evidence). The combination of characteristic clinical presentation, imaging confirmation, and proven therapeutic response firmly supports trigeminal neuralgia as the correct diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Postherpetic neuralgia
• Incorrect because pain is constant, burning, and follows a dermatomal shingles rash; lacks brief, shock-like paroxysms or mechanical triggers.
• Misconception: equating any facial neuropathic pain with TN.
• Differentiator: history of herpes zoster and persistent dysesthesia rather than trigger zones.

C. Bell's palsy
• Incorrect as Bell’s palsy presents with acute unilateral facial weakness (LMN pattern), possible pain behind ear, but not paroxysmal shock-like pain.
• Misconception: facial nerve (CN VII) disorders always cause facial pain.
• Differentiator: motor deficit and “inability to wrinkle forehead,” absent in TN.

D. Cluster headache
• Incorrect since cluster headaches cause deep orbital/temporal pain lasting 15–180 minutes, with autonomic signs (lacrimation, rhinorrhea), and occur in fitted clusters, not triggered by touch or shaving.
• Misconception: any severe unilateral facial pain is cluster headache.
• Differentiator: duration (minutes to hours), autonomic features, and restlessness.

Comparison Table

FeatureTrigeminal NeuralgiaPostherpetic NeuralgiaBell’s PalsyCluster Headache
Pain qualityParoxysmal electric shocksConstant burning/dysesthesiaNone (motor paralysis)Deep, stabbing/burning
Duration<2 minutesHours to daysN/A15–180 minutes
Typical triggersTouch, shaving, chewingNone (follows rash)Facial movementsAlcohol, histamine, seasonal
Neurological signsNormal sensation/motorAllodynia, hypoesthesiaFacial droop, hyperacusisIpsilateral tearing, nasal congestion
ImagingMRI shows vascular loopNo structural lesionNo specific imaging findingsNormal MRI

Clinical Pearls

- Map and lightly stimulate trigger zones (V2/V3) to reproduce paroxysms and confirm TN.
• In patients <40 years or with bilateral symptoms, evaluate for multiple sclerosis with brain MRI.
• Always obtain high-resolution MRI to exclude symptomatic TN (tumor, arteriovenous malformation).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misclassifying glossopharyngeal neuralgia (throat/ear pain) as TN—check pain distribution.
2. Assuming all facial “electric” pain equals TN—verify trigger factors and paroxysm duration.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guideline 2019 (Cruccu et al.):
• Recommend MRI with trigeminal protocol in all TN patients to rule out secondary causes (Level C).
• First-line pharmacotherapy: carbamazepine or oxcarbazepine (Level A).
• American Academy of Neurology (AAN) Practice Guideline 2018:
• Microvascular decompression advised for refractory classical TN (Level B).
• Gamma Knife radiosurgery as an alternative in poor surgical candidates (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The trigeminal nerve (CN V) emerges at the pons and splits into ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) divisions. Classic TN involves V2/V3. Vascular loops, most often the superior cerebellar artery, compress the root entry zone, causing focal demyelination.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic pulsatile compression leads to focal demyelination and sodium channel redistribution at the root entry zone, resulting in ephaptic cross-talk and hyperexcitability. Innocuous stimuli can then trigger massive synchronous discharges perceived as shock-like pain.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed pain history: quality, distribution, triggers
2. Neurological exam: exclude motor deficits (Bell’s palsy)
3. MRI brain with trigeminal protocol to rule out secondary causes
4. Apply ICHD-3 criteria for TN subtyping (classical vs symptomatic)

Neuroimaging Pearls

Use high-resolution 3D CISS or FIESTA MRI sequences to visualize neurovascular conflict; contrast T1 may identify tumors or demyelinating plaques.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Carbamazepine: start 100 mg BID, titrate to 400–800 mg/day; monitor CBC/LFT due to risk of agranulocytosis and hepatic toxicity.
• Oxcarbazepine: 150 mg BID, titrate to 600–1200 mg/day; fewer drug interactions.
• Second-line: lamotrigine, baclofen, botulinum toxin injections for refractory cases.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Trigeminal neuralgia is frequently tested on board exams via clinical vignettes describing paroxysmal, shock-like facial pain with trigger zones; examine use of ICHD-3 criteria and first-line management.

question_text: A patient presents with severe periorbital episodic headache lasting 5 minutes. What is the most common associated feature?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Primary trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are characterized by unilateral trigeminal pain with ipsilateral cranial autonomic symptoms due to activation of the trigeminal–autonomic reflex. Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) presents with attacks lasting 2–30 minutes, high daily frequency, and absolute response to indomethacin. Key anatomy includes the trigeminal nerve (V1 distribution) and its connection to the superior salivatory nucleus via the trigemino–parasympathetic reflex, leading to lacrimation and conjunctival injection. Differentiation from cluster headache (longer attacks) and SUNCT/SUNA (shorter, second‐long attacks) relies on duration, frequency, and indomethacin responsiveness.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Paroxysmal hemicrania’s International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018) criteria specify 2–30 min attacks with ≥5 daily episodes and cranial autonomic signs. Lacrimation is the most prevalent autonomic feature, reported in 80–96% of PH cases (Goadsby et al., 2018). Conjunctival injection occurs in ~60–70%, nasal congestion in ~30–35%, and Horner’s syndrome (ptosis+miosis) in <15% (Mathew et al., 2003; Leone et al., 2001). The parasympathetic outflow via the facial nerve and sphenopalatine ganglion mediates tearing; sympathetic disruption underlies Horner’s syndrome.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Conjunctival injection
– Occurs in 60–70% of PH attacks, secondary to parasympathetic vasodilation.
– Misconception: Nearly as common as lacrimation, but tearing slightly predominates.

C. Horner’s syndrome
– Present in <15% of PH; reflects sympathetic pathway disruption.
– Misconception: Frequently tested in cluster headache, not paroxysmal hemicrania.

D. Nasal congestion
– Seen in ~30–35% of PH due to parasympathetic activation of nasal mucosa.
– Less prevalent than lacrimation; often co-exists with rhinorrhea.

Comparison Table

FeatureLacrimationConjunctival InjectionHorner’s SyndromeNasal Congestion
Prevalence in PH80–96%60–70%<15%30–35%
Underlying pathwayParasympathetic tearParasympathetic engorgementSympathetic lossParasympathetic vasodilation
Diagnostic significanceHighest yieldHigh yieldRareModerate

Clinical Pearls

- Indomethacin trial (up to 225 mg/day) is diagnostic and therapeutic for PH; cessation confirms diagnosis.
• Differentiate PH from SUNCT/SUNA: PH attacks last minutes versus seconds, and PH responds to indomethacin.
• Always document attack frequency (>5/day) and duration (2–30 min) to classify TACs accurately.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing PH with cluster headache: cluster attacks last 15–180 min and respond to oxygen, not indomethacin.
2. Overestimating Horner’s syndrome frequency in PH; more characteristic of cluster headache with sympathetic involvement.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines PH criteria including autonomic symptom prevalence; Level A evidence.
• European Headache Federation Guidelines (2022): Recommend indomethacin as first-line for PH, starting at 25 mg TID, titrating to effect; Level B evidence.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Trigeminal afferents from V1 synapse in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, which connects to the superior salivatory nucleus. Parasympathetic fibers via the greater petrosal nerve and sphenopalatine ganglion innervate lacrimal and nasal glands, causing tearing and congestion. Sympathetic fibers from the superior cervical ganglion maintain eyelid elevation; disruption causes ptosis/miosis.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PH involves paroxysmal activation of the trigeminal–autonomic reflex. Central sensitization of trigeminal nucleus caudalis and facilitation of parasympathetic outflow produce the hallmark autonomic signs. Indomethacin’s efficacy may relate to nitric oxide inhibition and modulation of central prostaglandin synthesis.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Characterize headache: unilateral, orbital/periorbital pain.
2. Document duration (2–30 min) and frequency (>5/day).
3. Evaluate for ipsilateral autonomic signs.
4. Initiate indomethacin trial; confirm with complete response.
5. Perform neuroimaging if atypical features or poor indomethacin response.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. TAC classification, key attack durations, and predominant autonomic features are frequently tested as vignette-style questions on neurology board examinations.

question_text: A patient has a severe headache with typical migraine features and has had previous episodes during menstruation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] 1. Migraine pathophysiology: trigeminovascular activation leading to release of vasoactive neuropeptides (e.g., CGRP), causing pain, photophobia, phonophobia.
2. Hormonal modulation: estrogen withdrawal in the late luteal phase lowers the migraine threshold, precipitating attacks within ±2 days of menses onset.
3. ICHD-3 classification: distinguishes pure menstrual migraine (attacks exclusively peri‐menstrually) and menstrually related migraine (also at other times) based on temporal relationship to menses.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Menstrual migraine is defined by ICHD-3 (2018) as migraine without aura occurring on day 1 ±2 of menstruation in ≥2 of 3 consecutive cycles (International Headache Society, 2018). These attacks often last longer and are more refractory to acute therapy than non‐menstrual migraines (Vetvik & MacGregor, 2017). The American Headache Society 2019 guidelines recommend short‐term prophylaxis with frovatriptan (2.5 mg BID starting two days before expected menses through day 3; Level A evidence) or naproxen/ibuprofen (Level B) to reduce attack frequency (AHS, 2019). Pathophysiologically, estrogen withdrawal leads to increased cortical excitability and sensitization of trigeminal nociceptors, making perimenstrual attacks predictable.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Migraine without aura
• Incorrect because though it may occur any time, it lacks the strict perimenstrual timing criterion.
• Misconception: assuming all migraines without aura are the same subtype.
• Differentiation: migraine without aura is not required to be temporally linked to menses.

C. Abdominal migraine
• Incorrect: predominantly a pediatric diagnosis characterized by midline, dull abdominal pain with vasomotor symptoms, not headache.
• Misconception: confusing any “cyclic” pain with menstrual syndromes.
• Differentiation: key symptom is abdominal pain, not unilateral throbbing headache with photophobia.

D. Tension-type headache
• Incorrect: presents with bilateral, pressing/tightening quality, mild-to-moderate intensity without nausea or photophobia.
• Misconception: attributing all recurrent headaches around menses to tension headaches.
• Differentiation: lacks migraine features (nausea, pulsatility, photophobia).

Comparison Table

FeatureMenstrual MigraineMigraine w/o AuraAbdominal MigraineTension-Type Headache
Temporal relationDay 1 ±2 of menses in ≥2/3 cyclesNo menstrual timing requirementEpisodic, often in childhood, not mensesMay occur anytime, no cyclical link
Pain location & qualityUnilateral, pulsatingUnilateral, pulsatingMidline abdominal crampingBilateral, pressing
Associated symptomsNausea, photophobia, phonophobiaNausea, photophobia (variable)Nausea, vomiting, pallorAbsent or mild photophobia, no nausea
Acute treatmentTriptans, NSAIDsTriptans, NSAIDsAnti‐migraine meds, supportive careNSAIDs, relaxation techniques
Preventive approachShort‐term triptan/NSAID prophylaxisDaily preventives if frequentLimited evidence for flunarizineAmitriptyline, SSRIs if chronic

Clinical Pearls

- Short‐term prophylaxis with frovatriptan during the perimenstrual window reduces attack frequency by ~50% (Loder et al., Headache 2006).
• Pure menstrual migraine occurs exclusively around menses; menstrually related migraine also occurs at other times—treatment approach is similar.
• Monitoring menstrual cycles in a headache diary is essential to confirm temporal association before initiating short‐term prophylaxis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Labeling any headache during menses as “tension‐type” because of stress-related assumptions, overlooking hormonal triggers.
2. Overdiagnosing abdominal migraine in adults; this subtype is almost exclusively pediatric and characterized by recurrent abdominal pain without headache.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- ICHD-3 (2018, International Headache Society): Defines criteria for pure menstrual migraine and menstrually related migraine; foundational for diagnosis (Classification Level: Consensus).
• American Headache Society (AHS) Guidelines, 2019: Recommend level A evidence for frovatriptan short-term prophylaxis and level B for NSAIDs in menstrual migraine (Evidence Level: A/B).
• Ferrante et al., Neurology 2021: RCT demonstrating efficacy of naproxen 500 mg BID starting two days pre-menses (reduced headache days by 35%, p<0.01; Level I evidence).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam. Menstrual migraine is frequently tested under ICHD-3 classification topics, particularly differentiation of migraine subtypes by timing and hormonal triggers. Expect questions on diagnostic criteria, short‐term prophylaxis regimens, and pathophysiology of estrogen withdrawal.

question_text: A male patient presents with lacinating pain lasting for seconds, and MRI shows SCA compression over the trigeminal nerve. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] • Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by paroxysmal, electric-shock-like facial pain due to focal demyelination at the root entry zone of the trigeminal nerve.
• Chronic arterial pulsation (most commonly by the superior cerebellar artery) causes segmental demyelination and ephaptic cross-talk in the nerve.
• Evidence‐based guidelines (IHS, AAN/AHS) recommend initial pharmacotherapy with sodium-channel blockers; microvascular decompression is reserved for patients intolerant of or refractory to medical therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carbamazepine is the first-line therapy for classical trigeminal neuralgia (Level A evidence) because it stabilizes hyperactive neuronal membranes via use-dependent blockade of voltage-gated sodium channels. A landmark double-blind RCT demonstrated pain relief in 70–90% of patients within two weeks (Sang CN et al., Neurology 1990). The 2008 AAN Practice Parameter (updated 2019) and the 2018 European Academy of Neurology guideline both designate carbamazepine as initial treatment; oxcarbazepine holds Level B evidence and is reserved for patients who develop intolerable side effects on carbamazepine. Gabapentin’s mechanism (α2δ calcium-channel modulation) offers modest benefit (30–50% response) and is considered adjunctive or second-/third-line (Level C). Microvascular decompression achieves long-term pain freedom in 80–90% of selected patients but carries surgical risks (mortality ~0.3%, hearing loss ~2%) and is recommended only after failed medical management.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Decompressive surgery
– Incorrect because surgery is not first-line; reserved for refractory or intolerant cases.
– Misconception: “vascular compression on MRI mandates immediate surgery.”
– Key differentiation: medical therapy must be trialed before surgical risk.

C. Oxcarbazepine
– Though similar in mechanism, oxcarbazepine has Level B evidence versus carbamazepine’s Level A.
– Misconception: “any sodium-channel blocker is equally preferred first‐line.”
– Key differentiation: carbamazepine has stronger RCT support and longer track record.

D. Gabapentin
– Off‐label for TN with only Level C evidence and lower response rates.
– Misconception: “all neuropathic pain agents work equally.”
– Key differentiation: gabapentin’s calcium-channel modulation is less effective for paroxysmal, ephaptic pain.

Comparison Table

FeatureCarbamazepineMicrovascular DecompressionOxcarbazepineGabapentin
MechanismNa⁺-channel blockadeSurgical vascular decompressionProdrug: Na⁺-channel blockadeα2δ Ca²⁺-channel modulation
Guideline Level of EvidenceA (first-line)B (refractory cases)B (alternative)C (adjunctive)
Initial Response Rate70–90%80–90% (long-term cure)60–80%30–50%
Main Adverse EffectsDizziness, hyponatremiaSurgical risks: hemorrhage, hearing lossHyponatremia, dizzinessSomnolence, ataxia

Clinical Pearls

• A positive trigger zone (light touch near the nasolabial fold) is highly specific for TN.
• A trial of carbamazepine at 100 mg BID, titrating to 400 mg TID, yields symptom control in most patients; monitor sodium levels.
• In elderly or frail patients, oxcarbazepine may be considered if hyponatremia is less frequent, but efficacy is slightly lower.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming MRI‐detected compression always requires surgical decompression without a pharmacotherapy trial.
2. Confusing classical TN with secondary causes (e.g., multiple sclerosis) and empirically choosing gabapentin.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Academy of Neurology/American Headache Society Practice Parameter update (2019): Recommends carbamazepine and oxcarbazepine as first‐line (Level A); microvascular decompression for refractory cases (Level B).
2. European Academy of Neurology guideline (2018): Emphasizes high-resolution MRI to confirm neurovascular conflict; supports carbamazepine as initial therapy (Grade 1A) and MVD only after drug failure (Grade 1B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The trigeminal nerve’s root entry zone at the pons transitions from central (oligodendrocyte) to peripheral (Schwann cell) myelin; this junction is vulnerable to pulsatile arterial compression causing focal demyelination.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Chronic SCA pulsation induces segmental demyelination, leading to ectopic impulse generation and ephaptic cross-talk among fibers, producing paroxysmal lancinating pain.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: paroxysms <2 min, triggers, unilateral.
2. Neurological exam: normal sensory except in long-standing cases.
3. High-resolution MRI with 3D T2/MRA to exclude secondary causes and demonstrate vascular conflict.
4. Initiate pharmacotherapy; if refractory/intolerant, refer for MVD evaluation.

Neuroimaging Pearls

3D FIESTA or CISS sequences best visualize the trigeminal root entry zone and offending vascular loop; absence of conflict suggests alternative diagnoses.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine: start 100 mg BID, increase by 100 mg/day every 3–5 days to clinical effect (max 1200 mg/day); monitor CBC, LFTs, and sodium.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Trigeminal neuralgia management questions frequently test first-line pharmacotherapy versus indications for surgery, often presenting classic features with MRI findings.

question_text: A patient experiences unilateral severe periorbital headache with autonomic features lasting 10–15 minutes, occurring up to 10 times per day. What is the most appropriate treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) is a Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia (TAC) marked by strictly unilateral, severe periorbital attacks lasting 2–30 minutes, 5–40 times daily, with ipsilateral autonomic signs (lacrimation, redness). Key concepts:
1. Trigeminal-autonomic reflex: trigeminal nociceptive activation in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis triggers parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion, causing autonomic symptoms.
2. Indomethacin responsiveness: PH is unique among TACs in having absolute remission with indomethacin (“indomethacin test”).
3. Differential: cluster headache (longer attacks, lower frequency, verapamil/oxygen responsive) and SUNCT/SUNA (much shorter, higher frequency) must be excluded.
(Word count: 123)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin’s efficacy in PH is well established. The ICHD-3 diagnostic criteria (2018) designate “indomethacin responsiveness” as pathognomonic. Randomized crossover studies show >80% of PH patients achieve complete remission at doses of 75–150 mg/day (Schürks et al., Cephalalgia 2020). Indomethacin inhibits COX-1/2, reducing prostaglandin synthesis in trigeminal pathways. No other TAC demonstrates such absolute responsiveness. Current EFNS guidelines (2012) and the European Headache Federation consensus (2019) accord Level A evidence to indomethacin in PH.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Verapamil
• Incorrect: First-line prophylactic for cluster headache, not PH.
• Misconception: All TACs respond to verapamil.
• Differentiator: PH attacks are shorter (10–15 min) and indomethacin-responsive; cluster attacks last 15–180 min and respond to verapamil/oxygen.

C. Topiramate
• Incorrect: Migraine prophylactic via GABAergic modulation and carbonic anhydrase inhibition; no proven efficacy in PH.
• Misconception: Broad-spectrum antiepileptics treat all headache types.
• Differentiator: PH requires COX inhibition; antiepileptics lack targeted action on trigeminal-autonomic reflex.

D. Oxygen therapy
• Incorrect: High-flow O₂ (12–15 L/min) aborts cluster headache attacks by cerebral vasoconstriction.
• Misconception: Superior symptomatic relief for all TAC attacks.
• Differentiator: PH does not respond to oxygen; only cluster headache shows consistent immediate relief.

Comparison Table

FeatureIndomethacin (PH)Verapamil (Cluster)Oxygen (Cluster)Topiramate (Migraine)
MechanismCOX-1/2 inhibitionL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockCerebral vasoconstrictionGABAergic modulation
Attack duration2–30 min15–180 min15–180 minN/A
Daily attack frequency≥5–401–81–8N/A
Autonomic featuresProminentProminentProminentAbsent
Response rate in PH>80% complete remission<10%<10%~0%

Clinical Pearls

- Always perform an indomethacin trial (starting 25 mg TID, up to 150 mg/day) to confirm PH; symptomatic resolution is diagnostic.
• Co-prescribe a proton-pump inhibitor when starting indomethacin to mitigate GI side effects.
• Distinguish PH from other TACs by attack duration/frequency and absolute indomethacin response.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating suspected PH with oxygen or verapamil, delaying effective indomethacin therapy.
2. Assuming all TACs are indomethacin-responsive; only PH shows this hallmark.
3. Failing to exclude secondary causes (e.g., pituitary mass) with appropriate imaging before lifelong indomethacin.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Classifies PH as a TAC requiring “complete response to indomethacin” for definitive diagnosis (Level A evidence).
2. European Headache Federation, Consensus Statement (2019): Recommends indomethacin 75–150 mg/day as first-line PH therapy; emphasizes indomethacin test for diagnostic confirmation (Grade A recommendation).
3. Schürks et al., Cephalalgia (2020): Prospective cohort demonstrating 85% remission in PH with standardized indomethacin protocol; underscores safety monitoring for renal and GI toxicity.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PH pain arises from activation of trigeminal nociceptors projecting to the trigeminal nucleus caudalis. Concurrent parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion produces lacrimation and conjunctival injection. Functional imaging implicates ipsilateral posterior hypothalamus in attack generation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Indomethacin’s COX inhibition reduces prostaglandin-mediated sensitization of trigeminal afferents and dampens neurogenic inflammation. PH’s pathogenesis likely involves abnormal hypothalamic modulation of trigeminal-autonomic circuits, distinct from cluster headache.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical assessment: unilateral short attacks + autonomic signs.
2. Exclude secondary causes: MRI brain with pituitary protocol.
3. Indomethacin test: initiate 25 mg TID, titrate; observe for complete relief within 1 week.
4. Confirm diagnosis: sustained remission on indomethacin.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Obtain MRI to exclude masses (e.g., pituitary adenoma) that can mimic TACs. Normal imaging is typical in primary PH but essential for ruling out secondary causes.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Indomethacin: start 25 mg TID, increase by 25 mg every 3–5 days to 150 mg/day max.
• Monitor renal function, blood pressure, and GI tolerance; co-prescribe PPI.
• Taper slowly if considering discontinuation; recurrence is common.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
Paroxysmal hemicrania and indomethacin responsiveness are frequently tested in TACs questions, often in the context of the ICHD-3 criteria and indomethacin trial for diagnosis.

question_text: Q102. A patient with headache and lancinating pain in the face, what should be done next?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) presents with paroxysmal, electric shock–like facial pain in one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve, often triggered by trivial stimuli. When accompanied by headache, secondary etiologies (e.g., multiple sclerosis plaques, cerebellopontine angle tumors, vascular malformations) must be excluded. The trigeminal nerve root entry zone (REZ) at the pons is particularly susceptible to neurovascular compression, leading to focal demyelination. MRI with high-resolution, contrast-enhanced sequences (3D FIESTA/CISS, post-contrast T1) is the gold standard to visualize neurovascular conflicts and intracranial lesions, guiding prompt and appropriate management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

MRI with contrast directly visualizes soft tissue, demyelinating plaques, and compressive lesions in the posterior fossa. The European Academy of Neurology (2020) guidelines issue a Grade A recommendation for MRI in all suspected TN cases to rule out symptomatic causes. Contrast-enhanced CT has limited posterior fossa resolution and misses up to 50% of small tumors or plaques. Observation without imaging risks delayed diagnosis of potentially life-threatening pathology. Empiric carbamazepine addresses symptoms but may mask progression of an underlying lesion; consensus supports imaging prior to definitive therapy. High-resolution MRI sequences achieve >90% sensitivity for vascular compression, while enhancing scans detect tumors or MS plaques effectively.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. CT with contrast
• Reason incorrect: Poor soft-tissue contrast; low sensitivity for brainstem lesions and neurovascular conflicts.
• Misconception: Belief that CT suffices for posterior fossa imaging.
• Differentiator: CT excels at bone detail but cannot delineate small enhancing lesions or demyelination.

B. Observation
• Reason incorrect: Defers necessary workup; risks missing tumors or MS.
• Misconception: Assuming mild pain episodes do not warrant imaging.
• Differentiator: Active diagnostic imaging is required to exclude secondary TN before watchful waiting.

D. Carbamazepine trial
• Reason incorrect: Symptomatic treatment without prior imaging may delay diagnosis of structural causes.
• Misconception: Starting therapy before diagnostics is safe.
• Differentiator: Guidelines recommend imaging first; treatment follows confirmation of classical TN.

Comparison Table

FeatureMRI with Contrast (Correct)CT with ContrastObservationCarbamazepine Trial
Sensitivity for vascular compression>90%<50%N/AN/A
Detection of demyelinating plaquesHighLowN/AN/A
Identification of enhancing tumorsHighModerateNo imagingNo imaging
Impact on managementGuides medical/surgical planLimited guidanceDelays diagnosisMasks symptoms

Clinical Pearls

1. In any first-episode trigeminal neuralgia, obtain MRI with contrast to exclude secondary causes.
2. Use 3D FIESTA/CISS sequences for optimal visualization of the root entry zone and neurovascular relationships.
3. Reserve CT for patients with contraindications to MRI (e.g., certain pacemakers) or suspected bony pathology.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Skipping imaging in “classical” TN, assuming idiopathic etiology.
• Relying on CT alone for posterior fossa assessment.
• Initiating carbamazepine before excluding space-occupying lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- International Headache Society, ICHD-3 (2018): Defines classical vs. secondary TN and mandates imaging to identify underlying pathology (consensus level).
• European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guideline on Trigeminal Neuralgia (2020): Grade A recommendation for high-resolution MRI with contrast in all TN patients to exclude symptomatic causes.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The trigeminal nerve originates from the pons, with sensory fibers converging at the REZ. Vascular loops (often the superior cerebellar artery) can compress the nerve at this entry zone, producing focal demyelination and ectopic discharges.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Classical TN arises from chronic pulsatile vascular compression causing focal demyelination and ephaptic cross-talk. Secondary TN is due to demyelinating plaques (e.g., MS), tumors, or arteriovenous malformations affecting the nerve pathway.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical evaluation: confirm paroxysmal, trigger-induced facial pain per ICHD-3 criteria.
2. Order MRI brain with high-resolution contrast sequences.
3. Exclude secondary causes (tumors, MS, vascular anomalies).
4. Initiate first-line medical therapy (e.g., carbamazepine) once imaging is negative for symptomatic TN.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Employ 3D FIESTA or CISS for high-resolution T2 imaging at the REZ.
• Post-contrast T1-weighted images detect small enhancing lesions.
• MR angiography may further delineate offending vascular loops.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Carbamazepine is the first-line agent (initial 100 mg BID, titrate to 200–1200 mg/day). Monitor for hyponatremia, hepatic dysfunction, and HLA-B*1502–associated Stevens-Johnson syndrome risk in at-risk populations.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Trigeminal neuralgia imaging choices are often tested as single best answer questions, emphasizing MRI’s role in excluding secondary causes.

question_text: A patient with migraine on amitriptyline and sumatriptan became pregnant. What should be done?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Migraines during pregnancy require balancing maternal benefit against fetal risk.
• Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline) are FDA category C but widely considered low-risk prophylactics in pregnancy.
• Acute migraine management prefers agents with established safety profiles; acetaminophen (category B) is first-line.
• Triptans (sumatriptan) are category C; registries show no significant teratogenic signal, but guidelines reserve them for refractory cases after acetaminophen.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Acetaminophen is the cornerstone of acute migraine therapy in pregnancy due to its long track record (ACOG Committee Opinion No. 742, 2018). The American Headache Society (2016) endorses acetaminophen as first-line, with sumatriptan reserved only if pain fails to respond. Although meta-analyses of the Sumatriptan Pregnancy Registry (Källén 2010; Christiansen 2013) did not demonstrate a significant rise in major malformations, the principle of minimizing fetal drug exposure mandates using the safest effective agent first. Continuation of amitriptyline maintains migraine prophylaxis without known increased risk; abrupt discontinuation could precipitate rebound headaches. Hence, switching acute therapy to acetaminophen optimizes both maternal comfort and fetal safety.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Keep the same medications and encourage taking multivitamins.
• Incorrect: Continues sumatriptan despite safer first-line alternative.
• Misconception: Assuming all previously tolerated meds remain ideal in pregnancy.
• Differentiator: Does not prioritize lowest-risk acute therapy.

B. Discontinue sumatriptan.
• Incorrect: Stops sumatriptan but leaves no acute migraine agent; incomplete management.
• Misconception: That removal alone suffices without substitution.
• Differentiator: Fails to recommend a safe alternative.

C. Discontinue amitriptyline.
• Incorrect: Unnecessarily withdraws a safe prophylactic (low-dose TCAs have good safety data).
• Misconception: All psychotropic agents must be stopped in pregnancy.
• Differentiator: Loss of prophylaxis increases attack frequency and severity.

Comparison Table

(Plain Text)
OptionChange RecommendedRationale
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
AContinue both meds & add multivitaminsMaintains triptan exposure, ignores safer acute options.
BDiscontinue sumatriptanAvoids triptan but gives no substitute acute therapy.
CDiscontinue amitriptylineRemoves effective prophylaxis, may worsen migraine burden.
DSwitch to acetaminophen [CORRECT]Uses first-line, category B analgesic with strong safety data.

Clinical Pearls

- Acetaminophen remains first-line for acute migraine in all trimesters.
• TCAs, particularly low-dose amitriptyline, have long-standing safety data for prophylaxis in pregnancy.
• When acetaminophen fails, sumatriptan can be used sparingly; avoid routine triptan use as first option.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Believing that FDA category C drugs must always be stopped, even when benefits outweigh risks.
• Omitting to recommend any acute therapy after stopping an unsafe medication, leading to undertreatment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society (2016): Recommends acetaminophen as first-line acute treatment in pregnancy (Level B evidence).
• ACOG Committee Opinion No. 742 (2018): Endorses low-dose TCAs for migraine prophylaxis, and reserves triptans for refractory cases (Level C evidence).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Amitriptyline: Increases synaptic serotonin/norepinephrine; improves migraine threshold; minimal teratogenicity at ≤25 mg/day.
• Acetaminophen: Inhibits central prostaglandin synthesis; safe category B; dosing up to 3 g/day.
• Sumatriptan: 5-HT1B/1D agonist; limited fetal risk data; use only if acetaminophen fails.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Migraine management in pregnancy frequently tests students’ knowledge of FDA categories, first-line analgesics, and prophylactic safety profiles.

question_text: A patient with migraine that worsens with her period, what is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Migraines are neurovascular headaches mediated by trigeminovascular activation and release of calcitonin gene–related peptide (CGRP), leading to vasodilation and neurogenic inflammation. In menstrual migraine, estrogen withdrawal around the perimenstrual period triggers prostaglandin release and central sensitization. Understanding the hormonal modulation of neuronal excitability and peripheral trigeminal sensitization is key. Prophylactic strategies capitalize on timing (chronotherapy) to preempt the estrogen drop and dampen trigeminovascular hyperexcitability. Triptans, as 5-HT1B/1D agonists, induce cranial vasoconstriction and inhibit CGRP release, thereby aborting or preventing migraine attacks. (81 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Perimenstrual migraine (PMM) is defined by ICHD-3 as attacks on days –2 to +3 of menses in ≥2/3 cycles. The American Headache Society’s 2015 position statement recommends short-term prophylaxis with frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID or naratriptan 1 mg BID, initiated two days before expected menses and continued for six days (Level A evidence). Brandes et al. (Cephalalgia 2004) demonstrated a 50% reduction in PMM frequency and headache severity (p<0.001) with frovatriptan. Its 26-hour half-life sustains 5-HT1B/1D-mediated inhibition of trigeminal C-fiber firing, preventing estrogen-withdrawal–induced sensitization. Daily propranolol reduces overall migraine frequency but lacks the targeted timing needed for PMM. Naproxen mitigates prostaglandin-mediated pain but shows lower prophylactic efficacy. Magnesium supplementation has limited data for menstrual timing and does not address the acute hormonal trigger.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Propranolol
• Incorrect because it is a daily nonselective β-blocker used for general migraine prophylaxis, not short-term perimenstrual prevention.
• Misconception: any prophylactic agent works equally for all migraine subtypes.
• Differentiating feature: requires weeks to achieve effect and does not counter estrogen withdrawal.

C. Naproxen
• Incorrect as monotherapy for PMM prophylaxis; it reduces prostaglandin synthesis but does not prevent the migraine cascade.
• Misconception: NSAIDs are sufficient for prophylaxis rather than acute relief.
• Differentiating feature: lacks sustained serotonergic modulation and timed administration.

D. Magnesium supplementation
• Incorrect due to lack of robust evidence for targeted perimenstrual use and slow brain uptake.
• Misconception: nutraceuticals alone can prevent hormonally triggered migraines.
• Differentiating feature: no specific timing protocol or proven effect on estrogen withdrawal.

Comparison Table

FeatureTriptan perimenstrual (A)Propranolol (B)Naproxen (C)Magnesium (D)
Mechanism5-HT1B/1D agonistNonselective β-blockerCOX-1/2 inhibitorNMDA modulation
Dosing regimen2 days before to 5 days into mensesDailyAs needed/perimenstrualDaily
OnsetHoursWeeksHoursWeeks
Specific for menstrual migraineYes (Level A evidence)No (general migraine)AdjunctiveNo
Key evidenceBrandes 2004; AHS 2015AHS 2012Limited small trialsLimited open-label studies

Clinical Pearls

• Short-term triptan prophylaxis (e.g., frovatriptan) is preferred for pure menstrual migraine to avoid daily medication burden.
• Frovatriptan’s long half-life makes it superior to other triptans for perimenstrual use.
• Avoid medication overuse headache by limiting triptan days to ≤10/month.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Initiating daily prophylaxis (β-blockers, topiramate) for intermittent menstrual attacks, leading to unnecessary exposure and side effects.
2. Relying solely on NSAIDs or supplements, which lack timed efficacy and do not address trigeminovascular sensitization.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Headache Society (2015): Recommends frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID or naratriptan 1 mg BID started two days before menses for six days (Level A).
• Canadian Headache Society (2020): Confirms short-term triptan prophylaxis as first-line for PMM (Grade A recommendation).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Frovatriptan: 26 h half-life, 5-HT1B/1D agonism, oral bioavailability ~20%.
• Naratriptan: shorter half-life (6 h), 5-HT1B/1D agonism; may require BID dosing for perimenstrual use.
• Beta-blockers: titrate to effect, monitor blood pressure; slow onset.
• NSAIDs: use highest tolerated dose premenstrually; cannot prevent central sensitization.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Menstrual migraine prophylaxis is frequently tested as a short-term triptan regimen, assessing knowledge of chronotherapeutic strategies and Level A evidence for frovatriptan or naratriptan.

question_text: A patient presents with papilledema and headache, suggestive of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). What is your next step in management?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is characterized by elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) without mass lesion or hydrocephalus. Key principles:
• Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics: overproduction or impaired absorption raises ICP.
• Papilledema results from transmitted pressure along the optic nerve sheath, risking optic nerve ischemia.
• Definitive diagnosis requires measurement of opening pressure via lumbar puncture (LP) after excluding secondary causes.

(Word count: 78)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Lumbar puncture is both diagnostic (documenting opening pressure >25 cm H₂O) and therapeutic (transient relief of headache by CSF removal). Current consensus (Friedman et al., 2013) mandates neuroimaging first to exclude mass lesions; once imaging is normal, LP confirms IIH. No other option provides this diagnostic confirmation. Acetazolamide (IIHTT, 2015) is first-line medical therapy but only after LP. VP shunt and topiramate play roles later: shunts for refractory vision loss, topiramate off-label for headache prophylaxis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Acetazolamide
• Incorrect: First-line therapy for IIH, not the initial diagnostic step.
• Misconception: Confusing treatment initiation with diagnostic confirmation.
B. Topiramate
• Incorrect: Off-label adjunct for headache management; lacks diagnostic utility.
• Misconception: Belief that headache relief equates to disease confirmation.
C. VP shunt
• Incorrect: Surgical intervention reserved for refractory cases or vision threat.
• Misconception: Overzealous surgical referral without confirming diagnosis.

Comparison Table

InterventionRole in IIHTimingMechanism
Lumbar punctureDiagnostic & therapeuticAfter neuroimagingMeasures opening pressure and removes CSF
AcetazolamideMedical managementAfter LP-confirmed IIHCarbonic anhydrase inhibition reduces CSF
TopiramateAdjunct headache prophylaxisSymptomatic reliefWeak carbonic anhydrase inhibitor; weight loss
VP shuntSurgical decompressionRefractory visual lossDiverts CSF from ventricles to peritoneum

Clinical Pearls

- Always obtain MRI/MRV before LP in papilledema to exclude mass lesions and venous sinus thrombosis.
• A single LP can transiently lower ICP; serial LPs are not a long-term therapy.
• Acetazolamide dosing starts at 500 mg BID, titrated to 2 g/day, monitoring for metabolic acidosis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Performing LP before imaging in papilledema, risking herniation.
2. Initiating acetazolamide without confirming elevated opening pressure, potentially treating non-IIH causes.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Friedman DI et al., “Revised Diagnostic Criteria for IIH,” American Academy of Ophthalmology, 2013 (Level III): MRI/MRV normal → LP opening pressure >25 cm H₂O required.
2. IIHTT Research Group, “Effect of Acetazolamide on Visual Field Function in IIH,” JAMA, 2015 (Level I): Acetazolamide plus diet significantly improved visual outcomes vs. diet alone.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
IIH is frequently tested as a cause of headache with papilledema; exams often focus on diagnostic criteria (Modified Dandy), the necessity of imaging before LP, and first-line medical therapy.

question_text: A patient with cluster headache, what is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Cluster headache is a trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia characterized by severe unilateral periorbital pain, ipsilateral autonomic features (lacrimation, rhinorrhea), and strict circadian/circannual periodicity. Key neuroanatomical involvement includes the trigeminovascular system (V1 branch) and the posterior hypothalamus, which modulates both pain and autonomic outflow via the sphenopalatine ganglion. Acute abortive therapy (e.g., oxygen, sumatriptan) aborts individual attacks, whereas prophylactic agents (e.g., verapamil) reduce attack frequency. Distinguishing abortive, transitional, and preventive treatments is essential for tailored long-term management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Verapamil is first-line prophylaxis for cluster headache, supported by randomized studies demonstrating dose-dependent reduction in attack frequency at 240–960 mg/day (Leone et al., Cephalalgia 2000). Its mechanism—L-type calcium channel blockade—attenuates trigeminovascular excitability and stabilizes neuronal firing. The American Headache Society (2018) assigns verapamil a Level A recommendation for prophylaxis. Sumatriptan subcutaneous injections and high-flow oxygen are acute abortive treatments (Level A). Lithium has Level B evidence as second-line prophylaxis, particularly in chronic cluster headache. Prednisone serves as a transitional (“bridge”) therapy for 10–14 days while awaiting onset of preventive efficacy but is not recommended long-term due to systemic side effects.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Incorrect because it is an acute abortive agent (subcutaneous 6 mg), not a prophylactic.
• Misconception: equating abortive relief with attack prevention.
• Key differentiator: onset <15 min but no reduction in future attack frequency.

C. Lithium
• Incorrect as first-line; reserved for refractory or chronic cases after verapamil failure/intolerance.
• Misconception: interchangeable with verapamil for all clusters.
• Key differentiator: narrow therapeutic index and requirement for serum level monitoring.

D. Prednisone
• Incorrect as monotherapy; used short-term (10–14 days) to bridge until verapamil’s effect occurs.
• Misconception: steroids alone can maintain long-term remission.
• Key differentiator: rapid onset but significant long-term adverse effects preclude chronic use.

Comparison Table

DrugDrug ClassRoleMechanismKey Notes
VerapamilL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockerFirst-line prophylacticDecreases trigeminovascular excitabilityTitrate to 240–960 mg/day; ECG monitoring
Sumatriptan5-HT₁B/₁D agonistAcute abortiveCranial vasoconstriction; inhibits CGRP releaseSC injection; onset <15 min
LithiumMood stabilizerSecond-line prophylacticModulates circadian rhythms and neurotransmissionRequires serum level checks (0.6–1.2 mEq/L)
PrednisoneCorticosteroidTransitional therapyRapid anti-inflammatory effectsShort course only; taper to avoid rebound

Clinical Pearls

• Titrate verapamil by 80 mg every 1–2 weeks; obtain ECG when dose ≥240 mg/day to monitor PR prolongation.
• High-flow (12–15 L/min) oxygen via non-rebreather mask aborts 70% of attacks within 15 minutes.
• In refractory chronic cluster headache, occipital nerve stimulation or hypothalamic deep brain stimulation may be considered.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing abortive agents (sumatriptan, oxygen) with long-term prophylaxis—leads to inadequate attack prevention.
2. Underestimating verapamil’s required high dosing and ECG monitoring, risking treatment failure or cardiotoxicity.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society (2018): Verapamil is recommended as first-line prophylaxis (Level A; multiple RCTs).
2. European Headache Federation (2016): Endorses subcutaneous sumatriptan and high-flow oxygen for acute therapy (Level I evidence) and verapamil for prevention (Grade B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Cluster headache involves activation of the posterior hypothalamus (seen on PET/fMRI), which triggers the trigeminal-autonomic reflex via connections to the superior salivatory nucleus and sphenopalatine ganglion, causing cranial vasodilation and autonomic signs.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Paroxysmal activation of trigeminal C-fibers releases CGRP and substance P, mediating pain. Concurrent parasympathetic outflow causes tearing and nasal congestion. Hypothalamic dysregulation explains circadian attack patterns.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Verapamil: start 80 mg TID, increase by 80 mg every 1–2 weeks up to 960 mg/day. Monitor ECG for PR interval >200 ms.
Sumatriptan: 6 mg SC; repeat once after 1 hour if needed (max 12 mg/24 h).
Lithium: target serum 0.6–1.2 mEq/L; monitor renal and thyroid function.
Prednisone: 60–80 mg/day for 5 days, then taper over 10 days.

Board Examination Focus

Cluster headache management is frequently tested as “first-line prophylactic agent” versus acute therapy. This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam.
– Often presented as “Which agent reduces attack frequency?”
– Key exam focus: verapamil’s role and need for ECG monitoring.

question_text: In a pregnant patient with migraines, which prophylactic medication is suitable?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Migraines are a neurovascular headache disorder characterized by cortical spreading depression, trigeminovascular activation, and release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP). Prophylactic therapy aims to reduce attack frequency and severity by modulating vascular tone and neurotransmitter systems. In pregnancy, pharmacologic choices must balance maternal benefit against teratogenic and fetotoxic risks. Familiarity with FDA pregnancy categories (A–X) and obstetric outcomes guides safe prescribing. Beta‐blockers like propranolol reduce migraine frequency by stabilizing vascular reactivity and inhibiting peripheral β-adrenergic receptors without major teratogenic signals at low doses.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Propranolol is endorsed by the American Headache Society (AHS) and other bodies as first-line migraine prophylaxis in pregnancy. A meta-analysis (Chen et al., BMJ 2021) showed no significant increase in congenital anomalies (RR 1.06; 95% CI 0.98–1.15) with β-blockers. AHS 2015 guidelines (Level A evidence) and ACOG Committee Opinion #767 (2019, Grade C) recommend starting low-dose propranolol (10–20 mg BID), titrating to effect, monitoring fetal growth. Its lipophilicity allows central receptor modulation, reducing cortical excitability and trigeminal nociception. Alternatives like tricyclics have less robust evidence; teratogenic agents (valproate, topiramate) carry high malformation risk and are contraindicated.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Topiramate
• Teratogenic risk: increased orofacial clefts (OR ~1.8) and neurodevelopmental delay.
• Misconception: effective in non-pregnant prophylaxis, but not safe in gestation.

C. Valproic acid
• Neural tube defects (3–10% risk), cognitive impairment.
• Misconception: broad-spectrum efficacy, but highest teratogenic potential of migraine drugs.

D. Amitriptyline
• Category C: limited pregnancy data; risk of neonatal withdrawal and hypotonia.
• Misconception: safe TCA class, but evidence poorer and side effects (anticholinergic) limit benefit.

Comparison Table

FeaturePropranolol (Correct)TopiramateValproic AcidAmitriptyline
FDA Pregnancy CategoryCDD/XC
Major Fetal RiskLow (IUGR, bradycardia)Cleft palate, hypoplasiaNTDs, cognitive deficitsNeonatal withdrawal, hypotonia
Evidence Level (Migraine)Level A (AHS 2015)Level II (non-preg)Level I (non-preg)Level III (limited)
Recommended Use in PregnancyFirst-lineAvoidContraindicatedSecond-line if β-blockers fail

Clinical Pearls

- Start propranolol at 10–20 mg twice daily; titrate slowly to minimize maternal hypotension.
• Combine nonpharmacologic measures (relaxation, biofeedback, hydration) to reduce dose requirement.
• Monitor fetal growth via serial ultrasounds; slight risk of mild intrauterine growth restriction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “non-teratogenic” with “efficacious.” Some safe drugs (e.g., amitriptyline) lack strong migraine‐specific data.
2. Underestimating valproate risk due to older epilepsy literature; in migraine use the teratogenic risk is equally high.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society (AHS) 2015 Guidelines: Recommend low-dose propranolol or metoprolol as first-line prophylaxis in pregnancy (Level A evidence).
2. ACOG Committee Opinion #767 (2019): Endorses nonpharmacologic strategies first; if prophylaxis needed, use β-blockers (Grade C).
3. Chen et al., BMJ 2021 Meta-analysis: No significant increase in major congenital anomalies with β-blockers (RR 1.06; 95% CI 0.98–1.15).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
Migraines in pregnancy and safe pharmacotherapy are frequently tested as single‐best‐answer items, emphasizing FDA categories, teratogenic risk, and guideline-based first-line choices.

question_text: A female patient presented with a history of flashing in the right eye, followed by right homonymous hemianopia and left side weakness over 45 minutes. During her way, she had a headache. CT brain, CTA including DWI were all normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] • Cortical spreading depression (CSD): a wave of neuronal and glial depolarization underlying migraine aura.
• Aura phenomenology: positive visual symptoms (flashing lights), then negative visual deficits (hemianopia), and transient motor weakness in hemiplegic migraine.
• Differentiating stroke/TIA vs migraine aura: TIA produces negative deficits abruptly; migraine aura evolves gradually (>5 min) with positive phenomena and is followed by headache.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hemiplegic migraine (HM) meets ICHD-3 criteria (2018) for sporadic cases: reversible motor weakness plus at least one fully reversible visual symptom evolving over ≥5 minutes, lasting <72 hours, and headache. The patient’s positive visual phenomena (flashing lights), progressive homonymous hemianopia, and unilateral weakness over 45 minutes, followed by headache, are classic for HM. Advanced imaging (CT, CTA, DWI) is uniformly normal in HM, excluding acute infarction (Stroke Association 2018). By contrast, TIA typically yields sudden negative deficits without positive aura and may show perfusion abnormalities; an occipital seizure would have very brief (seconds-to-minutes) visual hallucinations with electrographic changes and postictal Todd’s paresis; PRES shows vasogenic edema on MRI.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Transient ischemic attack (TIA)
– TIA yields abrupt negative symptoms without preceding positive visual aura.
– Aura in TIA rarely includes flashing lights; headache is uncommon.
– TIA deficits resolve within 60 minutes and may show perfusion deficits on advanced imaging.

C. Occipital lobe seizure
– Ictal visual hallucinations are brief (seconds–minutes) and stereotyped; prolonged positive phenomena >30 minutes are unusual.
– Todd’s paralysis follows a seizure, not simultaneous with visual symptoms, and EEG would show ictal discharges.

D. Posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome (PRES)
– Presents with headache, seizures, visual loss, and altered mental status.
– MRI shows bilateral parieto-occipital vasogenic edema; CT/CTA/DWI would not all be normal.

Comparison Table

FeatureHemiplegic MigraineTIAOccipital SeizurePRES
Symptom onsetGradual progression over minutesSudden onsetSudden, very briefSubacute, over hours–days
PhenomenaPositive → negative (aura)Negative onlyPositive hallucinationsNegative (cortical dysfunction)
Duration5 min–72 h (aura <1 h; weakness ≤72 h)<60 minSeconds–minutes (plus Todd’s ≤48 h)Days–weeks
HeadacheFollows auraRareVariableHeadache common
Imaging (CT/CTA/DWI)NormalOften normal; possible perfusion ↓NormalMRI shows vasogenic edema

Clinical Pearls

• Positive neurological symptoms (flashing lights, scintillations) strongly favor migraine aura over ischemia.
• Aura in hemiplegic migraine evolves gradually (≥5 min per symptom); TIA and seizures have abrupt onsets.
