• Always obtain DWI MRI to exclude acute infarction when presentation overlaps with stroke.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Assuming all transient focal deficits are vascular: positive auras may mimic stroke.
2. Overreliance on CT alone—early ischemia can be DWI-occult; absence of infarct plus aura features favors migraine.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. IHS ICHD-3 (International Headache Society, 2018): Defines diagnostic criteria for sporadic and familial hemiplegic migraine (Level III evidence).
2. AHA/ASA Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke (2018): Emphasize use of DWI MRI to distinguish stroke mimics, including migrainous aura (Class IIa, Level B).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Hemiplegic migraine is frequently tested as a stroke mimic, emphasizing aura characteristics (positive vs negative symptoms), duration, and imaging findings.

question_text: A male patient presents with a shock-like electric sensation in half of his face multiple times per day, avoiding brushing and shaving. What is the recommended treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Trigeminal neuralgia (TN) is characterized by:
• Paroxysmal, lancinating “electric shock” pain in the distribution of one or more divisions of the trigeminal nerve (CN V), most often V2/V3.
• Trigger zones (e.g., perioral area, nasolabial fold) provoke brief attacks with light touch, shaving, or brushing.
• Etiology: classical TN involves focal demyelination at the root entry zone due to vascular compression (superior cerebellar artery loop).

Understanding TN requires knowledge of:
1. CN V anatomy—sensory roots enter at the pons; V1–V3 divisions supply face.
2. Ephaptic cross-talk between adjacent demyelinated fibers leading to paroxysmal firing.
3. Sodium channel–blocking antiepileptics as first-line therapy to stabilize hyperexcitable axons.

(Word count: 127)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Carbamazepine remains the gold‐standard for classical TN. The 2018 American Academy of Neurology/European Federation of Neurological Societies (AAN-EFNS) guideline assigns Level A evidence to carbamazepine’s efficacy, citing randomized trials demonstrating 70–80% pain reduction vs. placebo. Mechanistically, carbamazepine produces use‐dependent blockade of voltage‐gated sodium channels, reducing high-frequency ectopic discharges in demyelinated trigeminal fibers. A pivotal double‐blind trial (Bendtsen et al., 2008) showed 67% of patients achieving ≥50% pain relief at 8 weeks. Oxcarbazepine has similar efficacy but a less robust evidence base. Alternatives like gabapentin and lamotrigine carry only Level C or lower recommendation. Surgical decompression is reserved for refractory cases. Thus, current guidelines uniformly endorse carbamazepine as first-line pharmacotherapy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Gabapentin
• Reason incorrect: Modulates α2δ‐subunit of voltage‐gated calcium channels; off‐label in TN with only Level C evidence.
• Misconception: All anticonvulsants treat neuropathic pain equally.
• Differentiator: Less effective for sharp paroxysmal pain; slower onset, requires higher doses.

C. Valproic acid
• Reason incorrect: Broad-spectrum GABAergic enhancement; no controlled trials supporting use in TN.
• Misconception: Broad‐spectrum antiepileptics are interchangeable.
• Differentiator: Ineffective against focal sodium‐channel–mediated ephaptic discharges.

D. Keppra (levetiracetam)
• Reason incorrect: SV2A modulation; no evidence in TN RCTs; not recommended in guidelines.
• Misconception: Newer AEDs are superior in all neuropathic conditions.
• Differentiator: Lacks mechanism targeting high‐frequency sodium channel–mediated hyperexcitability.

Comparison Table

FeatureCarbamazepineGabapentinValproic acidLevetiracetam (Keppra)
MechanismUse‐dependent Na⁺ blockα2δ Ca²⁺‐channel modulatorGABA transaminase inhibitSV2A synaptic vesicle
Evidence Level (TN)Level A (RCTs)Level C (open studies)Not supportedInsufficient
Typical Starting Dose100 mg BID300 mg TID250 mg BID500 mg BID
Time to OnsetDays to weeksWeeksVariableUnknown
Key Side EffectsDizziness, hyponatremia, rash (SJS risk)Sedation, ataxiaTremor, weight gainIrritability, mood changes

Clinical Pearls

- Perform a “trigger‐point” exam: light touching of the nasolabial fold often elicits pain.
• Obtain high‐resolution MRI (3D‐CISS/FIESTA) to exclude secondary causes (MS plaques, tumors).
• Oxcarbazepine is a reasonable alternative in patients intolerant to carbamazepine, with less hepatic enzyme induction.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Misdiagnosing TN as dental pathology and pursuing unnecessary extractions.
2. Starting gabapentin as first‐line based on general neuropathic‐pain algorithms, ignoring TN‐specific evidence.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. AAN‐EFNS Joint Guideline on Trigeminal Neuralgia (2018):
• Recommendation: Carbamazepine as first‐line (Level A).
• Evidence: Multiple RCTs demonstrating superiority over placebo and low‐dose comparators.

2. Cochrane Review of Anticonvulsants in TN (2015):
• Finding: High‐quality data only for carbamazepine; insufficient evidence for newer agents.
• Conclusion: Carbamazepine remains standard; calls for more RCTs on oxcarbazepine.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The trigeminal nerve’s sensory root enters the pons at the root entry zone, where vascular loops (often superior cerebellar artery) can compress demyelinated fibers, precipitating ephaptic transmission between V2/V3 branches.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Focal demyelination at the root entry zone allows abnormal cross‐talk (“ephaptic transmission”) between adjacent fibers, leading to paroxysmal bursts of action potentials manifesting as lancinating facial pain.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Detailed history: unilateral, shock‐like, triggerable pain.
2. Neurological exam: exclude sensory loss (suggests secondary TN).
3. MRI with vascular sequences to rule out MS or tumors.
4. Initiate carbamazepine; monitor response and side effects.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Use high‐resolution 3D‐CISS (constructive interference in steady state) or FIESTA MRI sequences to visualize neurovascular conflict at the trigeminal root entry zone.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Carbamazepine: start 100 mg BID, increase by 100 mg/week to max 1200 mg/day.
• Monitor CBC/LFTs and screen HLA‐B*1502 in at‐risk ethnicities.
• Watch for hyponatremia and dermatologic reactions (SJS/TEN).

Board Examination Focus

Trigeminal neuralgia and its management are high‐yield neurology topics, frequently tested as vignette‐driven single‐best‐answer questions. This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.

question_text: Q108. A pregnant woman with a history of migraines requires prophylactic treatment. What is the best option?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Migraine prophylaxis in pregnancy balances maternal benefit against teratogenic risk.
– Migraine pathophysiology: trigeminovascular activation, CGRP release, cortical spreading depression.
– Prophylactic agents modulate neurotransmitter systems (β-adrenergic blockade, calcium channels, serotonin reuptake).
– Pregnancy considerations: placental transfer, FDA Pregnancy/Lactation Labeling Rule, known human data.
– First-line prophylaxis in non-pregnant patients (β-blockers, antiepileptics, antidepressants) must be re-evaluated for teratogenicity and fetal safety.
(120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Propranolol is the best choice for migraine prophylaxis in pregnancy: it’s a nonselective β-blocker with extensive human safety data. The American Headache Society (AHS, 2015) and European Headache Federation (EHF, 2018) guidelines list propranolol (and metoprolol) as first-line in pregnant women (Level A evidence). Observational cohorts (e.g., Øyen et al., 2013) show no significant increase in congenital malformations with β-blockers. Propranolol reduces migraine frequency by ≥50% in up to 60% of patients. Alternatives like topiramate carry a 1.5–2× risk of orofacial clefts (Case et al., 2006), while verapamil and amitriptyline have less robust efficacy data in pregnancy.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Topiramate
– Teratogenic: linked to oral clefts and hypospadias (OR 1.95; 95% CI 1.11–3.43).
– Misconception: efficacious in non-pregnant patients but contraindicated due to fetal risk.
– Differs from propranolol: no safety cohort data in pregnancy.

C. Amitriptyline
– Pregnancy Category C: limited human studies, potential neonatal withdrawal/hypotonia.
– Misconception: all antidepressants are safe; some have fetal cardiac and neurological effects.
– Less first-line: efficacy data lower than β-blockers; used only if β-blockers contraindicated.

D. Verapamil
– Limited migraine prophylaxis data (small open-label trials).
– Misconception: calcium-channel blockers are benign; in fact, efficacy is modest and safety data sparse.
– Differs: no randomized controlled trials in pregnant migraineurs.

Comparison Table

FeaturePropranololTopiramateAmitriptylineVerapamil
MechanismNonselective β-blockerGABA enhancer, ↓Na⁺SNRI/TCAL-type Ca²⁺-channel blocker
Pregnancy CategoryB (extensive data)D (teratogenic risk)C (limited data)C (limited data)
Efficacy EvidenceLevel A (RCTs, cohort)Level A (non-pregnant)Level B (general)Level C (small studies)
Fetal SafetyWell-studied, low riskIncreased clefts riskPossible withdrawalUncertain
Guidelines Position1st-lineAvoid2nd-line if neededNot recommended

Clinical Pearls

– Non-pharmacologic measures (relaxation, biofeedback) are first-line in pregnancy.
– When drug prophylaxis is needed, start low (e.g., propranolol 10–20 mg BID) and titrate.
– Monitor fetal growth; β-blockers can cause mild neonatal bradycardia/hypoglycemia.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Prescribing topiramate without counseling on cleft risk.
2. Assuming all antidepressants are safe—amitriptyline can cause neonatal withdrawal.
3. Overlooking non-drug therapies (e.g., magnesium supplementation, behavioral therapy).

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Headache Society Practice Guideline Update, 2015
– Recommends propranolol/metoprolol as first-line migraine prophylaxis in pregnancy (Level A).
2. Cochrane Database Syst Rev, 2016 (Smith et al.)
– Meta-analysis: propranolol reduces migraine frequency by >50% vs placebo; no increase in congenital anomalies (Grade 1A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Candidates are frequently tested on migraine prophylaxis in special populations (pregnancy), with emphasis on FDA categories, teratogenic risks, and guideline recommendations.

question_text: A patient presents with headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea. Her mother reports a history of menstrual-related headaches, and her sister has similar headaches that require a calm environment. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Migraine is a primary headache disorder marked by moderate-to-severe throbbing pain, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, often worsened by routine activity. Hormonal fluctuations, particularly the perimenstrual drop in estrogen, precipitate attacks classified as “menstrual migraine” under ICHD-3. Genetic predisposition is strong: first-degree relatives have a ~1.9–3× increased risk. Recognizing subtype influences prophylaxis (e.g., perimenstrual mini-prophylaxis).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Menstrual migraine (ICHD-3 6.1.1/6.1.2) requires attacks exclusively (pure) or predominantly (related) between days −2 and +3 of menstruation. The patient’s photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, family clustering, and maternal history of menstrual-timed headaches fit this pattern. The American Headache Society (2015) and European Headache Federation (2017) endorse specific perimenstrual prophylaxis (e.g., frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID days −2 to +3). Pathophysiologically, estrogen withdrawal enhances CGRP release and cortical hyperexcitability, activating the trigeminovascular system within the dura.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Migraine without aura
• Lacks hormonal timing; general attacks occur variably.
• Misconception: equating all photophobic headaches with non-menstrual types.
• Differentiator: menstrual migraine has a strict perimenstrual window.

C. Tension-type headache
• Characteristically bilateral, pressing/tightening, mild-moderate, no photophobia/phonophobia or nausea.
• Misconception: attributing any headache with family history to tension type.
• Differentiator: absence of migrainous features.

D. Cluster headache
• Presents with unilateral orbital pain, ipsilateral autonomic signs (lacrimation, rhinorrhea), short duration (15–180 min), cyclical but not linked to menses.
• Misconception: assuming severe headache plus restlessness = cluster.
• Differentiator: autonomic features and chronobiology (circadian/circannual).

Comparison Table

FeatureMenstrual MigraineMigraine w/o AuraTension-Type HeadacheCluster Headache
TimingDays −2 to +3 of mensesAny timeAny timeCircadian (night)
Pain qualityUnilateral, throbbingUnilateral/throbbingBilateral, pressingUnilateral, sharp/burning
Photophobia/PhonophobiaPresentPresentAbsent or mildRare
NauseaCommonCommonAbsentRare
Autonomic signsNoneNoneNoneConjunctival injection, lacrimation
Family historyOften positiveOften positiveVariableSporadic

Clinical Pearls

• Pure menstrual migraine occurs only during perimenstrual window; menstrually related may also occur at other times.
• Perimenstrual prophylaxis with frovatriptan or NSAIDs reduces attack frequency.
• Avoid estrogen withdrawal by short-term transdermal patches if migraines are severe.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating all migraine without aura subtypes as menstrual migraine; timing is essential.
2. Over-reliance on family history without correlating attack timing and associated symptoms.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Headache Society (2015): Recommends frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID or naproxen 500 mg BID days −2 to +3 for menstrually related migraine (Level A).
• European Headache Federation (2017): Advises against routine neuroimaging in strictly typical menstrual migraine without red flags (Grade A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Activation of trigeminal afferents innervating dural vessels transmits pain via the trigeminal nucleus caudalis to thalamic nuclei, with cortical spreading depression and hypothalamic modulation during hormonal shifts.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Estrogen withdrawal lowers pain threshold, enhances cortical hyperexcitability, increases CGRP release, and sensitizes brainstem nuclei, culminating in trigeminovascular activation and central sensitization.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Confirm ICHD-3 criteria: days −2 to +3 relation to menses.
2. Exclude secondary causes: perform red-flag screening (e.g., sudden onset, focal signs).
3. If isolated and typical, avoid neuroimaging.
4. Implement acute and prophylactic therapy.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Acute: NSAIDs (naproxen 500 mg), triptans (sumatriptan 25 mg nasal).
• Perimenstrual prophylaxis: frovatriptan 2.5 mg BID or naproxen days −2 to +3.
• Preventive: consider combined estrogen–progestin regimens for severe estrogen-withdrawal migraines.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
Menstrual migraine subtypes and perimenstrual prophylaxis are frequently tested as ICHD-3 classification and tailored management strategies.

question_text: A patient with chronic migraine, what is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Chronic migraine is defined by ≥15 headache days/month for ≥3 months, with ≥8 days meeting migraine criteria. Pathophysiologically, repetitive activation of the trigeminovascular system leads to peripheral sensitization of meningeal nociceptors and central sensitization within the trigeminal nucleus caudalis. Calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) and glutamate play pivotal roles in transmitting nociceptive signals and maintaining central hyperexcitability. Prophylactic strategies aim to modulate these pathways: β-blockers and anticonvulsants reduce neuronal hyperexcitability, whereas onabotulinumtoxinA inhibits presynaptic neurotransmitter/CGRP release, disrupting peripheral–central sensitization loops. Understanding these mechanisms underpins selection of migraine preventive therapy.

Evidence-Based Analysis

OnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) is the only FDA-approved treatment specifically for chronic migraine prophylaxis. The Phase III PREEMPT 1 and 2 trials (JAMA, 2010) demonstrated a mean reduction of 8.4 headache days/month versus 6.6 days with placebo (p<0.001). The American Headache Society 2021 guidelines assign onabotulinumtoxinA a Level A recommendation for chronic migraine (Ross et al., Headache 2021). Mechanistically, 155–195 U are injected across 31 sites every 12 weeks into pericranial muscles, blocking SNAP-25 and reducing CGRP/substance P release, thus attenuating peripheral nociceptor activation and downstream central sensitization. No other agent has matched this specific indication and evidence base for chronic (≥15 days) migraine.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Propranolol
• Incorrect because propranolol is a first-line prophylactic for episodic migraine (<15 days/month), not FDA-approved for chronic migraine.
• Misconception: “All β-blockers work equally in chronic migraine.” Differentiator: lacks chronic migraine–specific data or approval.

B. Depakene (Valproic Acid)
• Incorrect as valproate is used off-label for episodic migraine prophylaxis; it is teratogenic and has no robust RCTs in chronic migraine populations.
• Misconception: “Efficacy in epilepsy translates directly to chronic migraine.” Differentiator: no chronic migraine–specific trials or FDA indication.

D. Topiramate
• Although topiramate reduces headache days in episodic and some chronic series, it is not FDA-approved specifically for chronic migraine and carries cognitive side effects limiting tolerability.
• Misconception: “Efficacy in episodic migraine implies approval for chronic form.” Differentiator: lacks formal approval and PREEMPT-level evidence for chronic migraine.

Comparison Table

FeatureOnabotulinumtoxinA (Botox)PropranololValproic Acid (Depakene)Topiramate
FDA ApprovalChronic migraine prophylaxisEpisodic migraineEpisodic migraine (off-label)Episodic migraine
MechanismBlocks SNARE-mediated CGRP/SP releaseβ₁/β₂-adrenergic blockadeGABAergic enhancementNa⁺ channel blockade, GABA↑
Dosing155–195 U IM every 12 weeks80–240 mg/day PO500–1500 mg/day PO50–200 mg/day PO
Level of Evidence (AHS 2021)Level ALevel B (episodic)Level C (episodic)Level A (episodic)
Target Population≥15 headache days/month<15 headache days/month<15 headache days/month<15 headache days/month

Clinical Pearls

1. Chronic migraine management includes addressing medication overuse; botulinum toxin is safe even when analgesic overuse is reduced.
2. Adhere to the PREEMPT injection paradigm (31 sites, 5 U each); improper dosing lowers efficacy.
3. Emerging CGRP monoclonal antibodies (e.g., erenumab) now offer alternative prophylaxis but were not standard in 2019.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating efficacy in episodic migraine with chronic migraine approval—only onabotulinumtoxinA holds specific chronic indication.
2. Overlooking medication-overuse headache in chronic migraine—continual analgesic use can undermine prophylactic benefits.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• American Headache Society (AHS) Guidelines, 2021: Recommend onabotulinumtoxinA as Level A for chronic migraine prophylaxis, based on PREEMPT trials (High-quality evidence).
• European Headache Federation (EHF) Guidelines, 2022: Endorse onabotulinumtoxinA as first-line for chronic migraine and suggest CGRP mAbs when ≥2 prophylactics fail (Level A).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. Chronic migraine prophylaxis is frequently tested as a scenario requiring differentiation between episodic and chronic indications; onabotulinumtoxinA’s unique FDA approval makes it a high-yield point.

question_text: Q95. A 25-year-old man presents with episodic, unilateral, throbbing headaches associated with nausea and light and noise sensitivity. They are triggered by some foods, including cheddar cheese. Most of his headaches occur without any obvious precipitant. He generally has one headache on the weekend that keeps him from his regular activities on the days they occur. He has had this occurring at least 1 to 2 days per week with at least 50% time loss. He has tried multiple over-the-counter remedies without satisfactory relief. Which of the following medications for symptomatic treatment of his headache would be most appropriate at this time?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by activation of the trigeminovascular system, leading to release of vasoactive neuropeptides (e.g., CGRP) and neurogenic inflammation of meningeal vessels. Sensitization of second-order neurons in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis and higher cortical areas underlies photophobia, phonophobia, and allodynia. Attacks are often unilateral, pulsatile, and aggravated by routine activity, with associated nausea/vomiting due to brainstem involvement (area postrema). Acute therapy aims to abort the attack early by targeting serotonin 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors to inhibit neuropeptide release and vasoconstrict dilated cranial vessels.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan, rizatriptan) are first-line for moderate-to-severe migraine or mild attacks unresponsive to simple analgesics. The American Headache Society (2015) gives Level A evidence for triptans, showing 2-hour pain freedom rates of 50–60% versus placebo. Triptans act as 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists, reducing CGRP release and reversing vasodilation. Early administration—ideally at mild pain onset—maximizes efficacy. Compared to non-specific analgesics, triptans offer superior relief and less risk of medication-overuse headache when used appropriately (<10 days/month).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Aspirin with metoclopramide
• Why incorrect: Effective for mild-to-moderate attacks but inferior to triptans for disabling migraine.
• Misconception: Belief that antiemetic combination suffices in moderate-to-severe migraine.
• Differentiator: Does not target 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors or CGRP release; slower onset.

C. Butalbital, caffeine, acetaminophen (APAP) combination
• Why incorrect: High risk of dependence, sedation, rebound headache; not recommended for frequent use.
• Misconception: Barbiturate combos are safe “step-up” options.
• Differentiator: Barbiturates exacerbate risk of medication-overuse headache.

D. Codeine with APAP
• Why incorrect: Opioid-containing regimens offer minimal migraine-specific efficacy, increase nausea, sedation, and dependency risk.
• Misconception: Opioids are universally effective analgesics.
• Differentiator: Lack 5-HT₁D agonism; contraindicated as first-line in migraine.

Comparison Table

FeatureTriptansAspirin + MetoclopramideButalbital/Caffeine/APAPCodeine + APAP
Mechanism5-HT₁B/₁D agonistCOX inhibition + D2 blockGABA enhancement + analgesiaμ-opioid receptor agonist
Onset of action30–60 min60–90 min60–120 min60–90 min
Efficacy in moderate–severeHigh (50–60% pain-free @2h)ModerateLow–moderateLow
Risk of medication-overuseLow if <10 days/monthModerateHighHigh
Recommended use frequency≤10 days/month≤15 days/monthRare (<3 days/month)Avoid for routine use

Clinical Pearls

- Administer triptans early in the attack for maximal efficacy; delay decreases pain-free rates.
• Screen for cardiovascular risk before prescribing triptans (contraindicated in CAD, uncontrolled HTN).
• Limit triptan use to ≤10 days per month to prevent medication-overuse headache.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Treating moderate-to-severe migraines with opioids increases dependency risk and yields poorer outcomes than triptans.
2. Overemphasis on barbiturate-containing combinations despite guidelines advising against their routine use due to rebound headaches.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society Consensus Statement on Migraine Treatment (2015): Recommends triptans as first-line acute therapy in moderate-to-severe migraine (Level A evidence).
• European Headache Federation Guidelines (2021): Endorses early triptan use at attack onset; prohibits barbiturate/opioid combinations in routine management (Grade 1A).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine pain is mediated by first-order trigeminal afferents from meningeal blood vessels synapsing in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis, with second-order projection to thalamus (VPM) and cortical pain centers. Serotonin receptors on perivascular trigeminal terminals modulate this pathway.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cortical spreading depression triggers activation of perivascular trigeminal fibers, releasing CGRP, substance P, and neurokinin A, leading to vasodilation and sterile neurogenic inflammation—a key target of triptans.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Sumatriptan dosing: oral 50–100 mg; may repeat once after 2 h; onset 30 min; avoid in coronary artery disease. Rizatriptan: oral 5–10 mg; faster onset; adjust in propranolol use.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Acute migraine management—especially triptan pharmacology and indications—is a high-yield topic on neurology boards, frequently tested via clinical vignettes comparing migraine-specific versus non-specific analgesics.

question_text: Q96. A young lady experiences severe headaches with orgasm, and similar episodes occur every time. What is the most appropriate treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] This question (Q96 from the 2018 Promotion exam) tests recognition and prophylaxis of primary headache associated with sexual activity (PHASA), classified in ICHD-3. PHASA has two subtypes:
• Type I – gradual, dull ache building up to orgasm
• Type II – sudden, explosive pain at orgasm
Mechanisms involve abrupt meningeal vasodilation and prostaglandin-mediated sensitization of the trigeminovascular system. Prophylactic therapy must be tailored: NSAIDs for type II and beta-blockers for type I.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin is the first-line prophylactic for type II PHASA. It non-selectively inhibits cyclooxygenase, reducing prostaglandin synthesis and meningeal nociceptor activation. In Starr et al.’s series (Neurology 1980), 75% of type II patients became headache-free with 25–50 mg indomethacin pre-coitus. The ICHD-3 (2018) cites indomethacin responsiveness as characteristic for this subtype (Level C evidence). Verapamil, while a calcium-channel blocker effective in cluster headache, lacks evidence in PHASA. Sumatriptan’s rapid onset makes it impractical at orgasm, and propranolol is more effective in type I PHASA.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Verapamil
• Mechanism: L-type Ca²⁺ channel blockade used in cluster headache prophylaxis
• Why incorrect: No clinical trials support verapamil for PHASA; it does not address prostaglandin-mediated pathways.

C. Sumatriptan
• Mechanism: 5-HT₁B/1D agonist abortive for migraine
• Misconception: Thinking abortive migraine therapy applies here
• Why incorrect: Unable to be dosed precisely at orgasm; lacks prophylactic efficacy.

D. Propranolol
• Mechanism: Non-selective β-blocker
• Misconception: All exertional headaches respond to beta-blockers
• Why incorrect: Best for type I PHASA (gradual headache), not the explosive type II.

Comparison Table

FeatureIndomethacin (Correct)VerapamilSumatriptanPropranolol
MechanismCOX-1/2 inhibitionL-type Ca²⁺ channel blockade5-HT₁B/1D receptor agonismNon-selective β-adrenergic blockade
PHASA SubtypeType II (explosive at orgasm)Not indicatedAbortive (impractical)Type I (gradual pre-orgasmic)
Typical Dosing25–50 mg PO 1–2 h before coitus240 mg/day divided6 mg SC at headache onset40–120 mg/day divided
Evidence LevelICHD-3 Level C, Starr et al. (1980)No formal studiesAnecdotal abortive useSmall case series for type I

Clinical Pearls

- Differentiate type I vs. type II PHASA by headache quality and timing relative to orgasm.
• Indomethacin prophylaxis (25–50 mg pre-coitus) prevents type II attacks in the majority of patients.
• Always exclude secondary causes (e.g., subarachnoid hemorrhage) with imaging in first presentations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Prescribing propranolol for explosive (type II) sexual headache rather than reserving it for gradual (type I).
• Attempting abortive therapies (sumatriptan) when prophylaxis is key for predictable orgasmic pain.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018): Recommends indomethacin for type II PHASA (Level C).
• European Headache Federation guideline (2021): Supports NSAID prophylaxis for primary headache associated with sexual activity (Grade B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

PHASA involves activation of meningeal nociceptors innervated by the trigeminal nerve; the sudden increase in intracranial pressure at orgasm triggers the trigeminovascular reflex.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

At orgasm, transient spikes in blood pressure and intracranial pressure cause abrupt meningeal vessel dilation. This releases prostaglandins and neuropeptides (e.g., CGRP), sensitizing trigeminal pain pathways.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

• Indomethacin: COX-1/2 inhibition reduces prostaglandin synthesis; 25–50 mg PO 1–2 h before coitus.
• Monitor for GI and renal side effects; consider proton-pump inhibitor co-therapy.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. It tests differentiation of PHASA subtypes and targeted prophylaxis. Sexual headache prophylaxis is infrequently tested but high yield for headache specialty questions.

question_text: Q101. In a case of paroxysmal hemicrania, what is the treatment?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias (TACs) are primary headache syndromes marked by unilateral trigeminal pain with ipsilateral cranial autonomic signs. Paroxysmal hemicrania (PH) is distinguished by:
• Attack duration of 2–30 minutes and frequency >5 per day
• Ipsilateral autonomic features (lacrimation, conjunctival injection, nasal congestion)
• Absolute responsiveness to indomethacin as a diagnostic criterion (ICHD-3)
PH must be differentiated from cluster headache (longer, less frequent attacks) and hemicrania continua (continuous pain). Early recognition and an indomethacin trial can confirm diagnosis and prevent unnecessary interventions.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Indomethacin’s robust efficacy in PH was first demonstrated in double-blind crossover trials (Sjaastad et al., 1984), showing complete abolition of attacks within hours at doses of 25–150 mg/day. The ICHD-3 (2018) lists “complete response to indomethacin” as a diagnostic criterion for PH (Level A evidence). Its mechanism—nonselective COX-1/COX-2 inhibition—reduces prostaglandin E2 synthesis, dampening trigeminal nociceptive activation and central sensitization in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis. Alternatives (e.g., COX-2 inhibitors) lack the consistent positive response required for diagnosis. No other acute or prophylactic agent replicates indomethacin’s pathognomonic effect; failure to respond should prompt reevaluation for secondary causes or alternative headache disorders.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Sumatriptan
• Reason incorrect: A selective 5-HT₁B/₁D agonist used acutely in migraine/cluster headache, not prophylactically diagnostic in PH.
• Misconception: Assuming all TACs respond to triptans; PH attacks are too frequent for repeated dosing and lack sustained relief.
• Differentiator: Sumatriptan aborts individual attacks but does not prevent recurrence; indomethacin abolishes all attacks.

C. Propranolol
• Reason incorrect: Nonselective β-blocker effective in migraine prophylaxis, not in PH.
• Misconception: Extrapolation from migraine therapy to all unilateral headaches.
• Differentiator: Propranolol reduces migraine attack frequency over weeks, whereas PH requires rapid trial of indomethacin for confirmation.

D. Topiramate
• Reason incorrect: Antiepileptic/migraine prophylactic agent with multiple mechanisms; lacks evidence in PH.
• Misconception: Belief that broad-spectrum prophylactics cover all headache types.
• Differentiator: Topiramate titration takes weeks and does not yield the immediate, absolute relief seen with indomethacin.

Comparison Table

FeatureIndomethacinSumatriptanPropranololTopiramate
MechanismCOX-1/COX-2 inhibition5-HT₁B/₁D receptor agonistNonselective β-adrenergic blockerNa⁺ channel blockade; GABAergic modulation
Primary IndicationParoxysmal hemicraniaAcute migraine, clusterMigraine prophylaxisMigraine prophylaxis, epilepsy
Response in PHComplete abolition of attacksTransient abortive reliefNo proven efficacyNo proven efficacy
Onset of ActionHours15–30 minutesWeeksWeeks

Clinical Pearls

- A positive indomethacin trial (starting at 25 mg TID, titrating up) is both diagnostic and therapeutic for PH.
• Always co-prescribe a gastroprotective agent (e.g., PPI) when using high-dose indomethacin long term.
• Attack frequency >5/day with durations <30 minutes strongly suggests PH over cluster headache.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Assuming sumatriptan efficacy in PH because it works in other TACs; it cannot replace indomethacin for diagnosis or prophylaxis.
• Overlooking the absolute response criterion and misclassifying PH as atypical migraine or tension-type headache, leading to ineffective treatments.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. International Classification of Headache Disorders, 3rd edition (ICHD-3, 2018; IHS): Defines PH and mandates complete indomethacin response for diagnosis (Level A).
2. European Headache Federation Guideline (EHF, 2019): Recommends indomethacin 25–150 mg/day as first-line prophylaxis in PH; COX-2 inhibitors only if GI intolerance occurs (Level B).

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PH involves activation of the trigeminal nociceptive system and parasympathetic outflow via the superior salivatory nucleus, causing vasodilation and autonomic signs. Prostaglandin‐mediated sensitization in the trigeminal nucleus caudalis is central; indomethacin’s blockade of COX enzymes disrupts this cycle.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical history: unilateral, severe, 2–30 min attacks with autonomic features
2. Rule out secondary causes: MRI brain/orbits
3. Indomethacin trial: start 25 mg TID, escalate to 75–150 mg/day
4. Monitor response: complete abolition confirms PH; partial/no response → reconsider diagnosis

Pharmacotherapy Focus

- Indomethacin: start 25 mg orally TID, increase by 25 mg every 3–5 days to 75–150 mg/day
• Monitor renal function, GI side effects; use PPI or misoprostol for prophylaxis
• If intolerant, try celecoxib 200 mg BID (off-label) or consider neuronal stimulation in refractory cases

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam.
Trigeminal autonomic cephalagias and indomethacin responsiveness are frequently tested as high-yield diagnostic criteria and treatment modalities.

question_text: A 50-year-old male with a history of migraine has recently been diagnosed with myocardial infarction (MI) and coronary artery disease (CAD). What is contraindicated for use regarding preventive treatment of migraine?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Migraine is a neurovascular headache disorder involving trigeminovascular activation and cortical spreading depression, leading to release of vasoactive peptides (e.g., CGRP) and neurogenic inflammation. Abortive therapies—such as triptans—act as 5-HT₁B/₁D agonists to induce cranial vasoconstriction and inhibit trigeminal pain pathways. Preventive therapies—including tricyclic antidepressants (amitriptyline), calcium channel blockers (verapamil), and beta-blockers—modulate neurotransmitter levels or vascular tone to reduce attack frequency. In patients with cardiovascular disease (e.g., MI, CAD), agents causing systemic or coronary vasoconstriction are contraindicated. Distinguishing abortive from prophylactic treatments and assessing comorbidities is critical for safe, effective migraine management.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Triptans (e.g., sumatriptan, rizatriptan) selectively agonize 5-HT₁B/₁D receptors on cranial vessels and presynaptic trigeminal nerve endings, causing vasoconstriction and inhibiting pro-nociceptive neuropeptide release. Per FDA labeling and the 2021 American Headache Society (AHS) guidelines (Level A evidence), triptans are contraindicated in patients with coronary artery disease, recent myocardial infarction, or significant uncontrolled hypertension due to risk of coronary vasospasm and myocardial ischemia. A meta-analysis by Tfelt-Hansen et al. (Cephalalgia, 2019) reported a relative risk >2 for cardiovascular events in patients with vascular comorbidities treated with triptans. Conversely, preventive agents like amitriptyline and verapamil lack potent vasoconstrictive properties and are considered safe in CAD when dosed appropriately (American Academy of Neurology 2012 guidelines).

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Amitriptyline
• Incorrect because it is a first-line migraine preventive with no significant coronary vasoconstrictive effect.
• Misconception: TCAs invariably worsen cardiovascular risk; in reality, low-dose regimens (10–75 mg nightly) are hemodynamically well tolerated.

B. Verapamil
• Incorrect; as an L-type calcium channel blocker, it promotes vasodilation rather than vasoconstriction.
• Misconception: All vascular modulators are contraindicated in CAD; verapamil’s predominant action is coronary and peripheral vasodilation.

D. None of the above
• Incorrect because triptans (Option C) are specifically contraindicated in CAD/MI.
• Misconception: Assuming no migraine therapy requires contraindication in cardiovascular disease.

Comparison Table

DrugClassIndicationMechanismContraindication in CAD/MI
AmitriptylineTricyclic antidepressantPreventiveInhibits 5-HT/NE reuptakeNo
VerapamilCalcium channel blockerPreventiveL-type CCB → vasodilationNo
Triptan5-HT₁B/₁D agonistAbortiveCranial vasoconstrictionYes

Clinical Pearls

- Always screen for cardiovascular risk factors before prescribing triptans; consider NSAIDs or gepants (ubrogepant, rimegepant) if CAD is present.
• Amitriptyline is especially useful when migraine coexists with depression or insomnia—start low and titrate slowly.
• Verapamil is an off-label prophylactic in cluster headaches and safe in vascular disease.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Confusing abortive versus preventive therapies, leading to inappropriate triptan prophylaxis.
2. Overlooking cardiovascular contraindications; undervaluing vasoconstrictive risk in patients with CAD/MI.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- American Headache Society (AHS) 2021: Strong recommendation (Level A) to avoid triptans in individuals with known cardiovascular or cerebrovascular disease.
• European Headache Federation (EHF) 2022: Reinforces triptan contraindications in ischemic heart disease and endorses CGRP receptor antagonists (gepants) as safer acute alternatives (Level B).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Migraine pain is mediated by the trigeminal nerve (V1 division) projecting to the trigeminocervical complex in the brainstem. 5-HT₁B receptors on intracranial vascular smooth muscle and 5-HT₁D receptors on trigeminal afferents are principal targets of triptans.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Cortical spreading depression activates perivascular trigeminal sensory fibers, causing release of CGRP and substance P → vasodilation and sterile inflammation. Preventive agents raise pain thresholds via neurotransmitter modulation; abortive triptans reverse vasodilation and inhibit neuropeptide release.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Triptans: e.g., sumatriptan 25–100 mg PO (max 200 mg/24 h); onset 1–2 h. Avoid in CAD, uncontrolled hypertension, hemiplegic migraine.
Amitriptyline: start 10 mg nightly, titrate to 75–150 mg based on tolerance.
Verapamil: 80–120 mg TID; monitor heart rate and blood pressure.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Board-style questions often assess how cardiovascular comorbidities influence choice of acute migraine therapy, testing contraindications for vasoconstrictive abortive agents like triptans.

question_text: Q195. Which of the following is required for a diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri syndrome?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Intracranial pressure (ICP) is governed by the Monro-Kellie doctrine: the sum of brain tissue, blood, and CSF volumes is constant.
Papilledema reflects axoplasmic flow stasis in the optic nerve head due to elevated ICP.
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), or pseudotumor cerebri syndrome (PTCS), is diagnosed by the modified Dandy/Friedman criteria: 1) signs of raised ICP (papilledema or abducens palsy), 2) normal neuro exam aside from CN VI palsy, 3) no secondary cause on neuroimaging, 4) elevated opening pressure, and 5) normal CSF composition.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Papilledema is the hallmark of PTCS: it directly visualizes raised intracranial pressure via optic nerve head swelling. The 2013 Friedman et al. revision (Neurology 2013;81:1159–65) specifies papilledema as essential; in its absence, a unilateral or bilateral abducens nerve palsy may substitute, but no other sign suffices. Papilledema sensitivity for elevated ICP approaches 92% (Wall et al., Arch Neurol 2014), making it the most specific clinical finding. While elevated opening pressure (≥25 cm H₂O in adults) confirms pressure elevation, it lacks specificity without papilledema or CN VI palsy. Normal neuroimaging and exam are required to exclude secondary causes but are not the cardinal feature that clinches the diagnosis.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Normal neurologic examination except for cranial nerve abnormalities
– Incorrect because “cranial nerve abnormalities” in general is too broad; only isolated abducens (VI) palsy is permitted by the criteria. Other focal deficits exclude PTCS.
– Misconception: students often think any CN palsy (e.g., III, IV) can occur in IIH.
– Differentiator: true IIH allows CN VI palsy only.

C. Neuroimaging: Normal brain parenchyma without evidence of hydrocephalus, mass, or structural lesion and no abnormal meningeal enhancement on MRI
– Incorrect as stated: while normal imaging is required to rule out secondary causes, absence of meningeal enhancement is not a defining criterion—mild meningeal enhancement may occur with long-standing papilledema.
– Misconception: equating absence of all imaging abnormalities with PTCS.
– Differentiator: core imaging requirement is no mass/obstruction; other benign MRI signs (empty sella, optic sheath distension) can be present.

D. Elevated lumbar puncture opening pressure (≥250 mm CSF in adults and ≥280 mm CSF in children)
– Incorrect alone: high opening pressure confirms intracranial hypertension but is not specific for IIH without papilledema or VI palsy.
– Misconception: that any unexplained elevated pressure equals IIH.
– Differentiator: must pair with papilledema (or VI palsy) and exclude secondary causes.

Comparison Table

FeaturePapilledema (A)Normal Exam w/ CN VI (B)Normal Imaging (C)Elevated LP Opening Pressure (D)
Cardinal findingYesNo (permits only VI palsy)No (exclusionary, not cardinal)No (confirmation, not cardinal alone)
Specificity for IIHHigh (~92%)ModerateLow–moderateLow
Allows definitive diagnosisYes (with other criteria)NoNoNo
May be absent if VI palsy presentPossibly (exception)N/AN/AN/A

Clinical Pearls

1. Always perform dilated funduscopic exam in suspected IIH; papilledema is the most specific sign.
2. In the rare absence of papilledema, look for isolated abducens nerve palsy—no other focal deficits are permitted.
3. CSF manometry should be done in lateral decubitus with legs extended to avoid false elevations.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Mistaking MRI signs of transverse sinus stenosis as exclusionary rather than supportive of IIH.
• Over-diagnosing IIH in patients with elevated opening pressure but without papilledema or VI palsy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. Friedman DI et al. Revised diagnostic criteria for pseudotumor cerebri syndrome in adults and children. Neurology. 2013;81(13):1159–1165. (Consensus statement; Level IV evidence)
– Recommendation: Papilledema is required; in its absence, only abducens palsy can substitute.
2. ACR Appropriateness Criteria® Headache. American College of Radiology. 2019. (Moderate level evidence)
– Recommendation: MRI brain with and without contrast + MRV to exclude secondary causes (e.g., venous sinus thrombosis) in suspected IIH.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. IIH diagnostic criteria are frequently tested on neurology and internal medicine boards, often as a list of required findings versus exclusionary features.

question_text: A young female presented with a severe headache; CT imaging shows pituitary apoplexy. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Pituitary apoplexy is an acute neurological and endocrine emergency due to hemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland—most often within a preexisting adenoma. The pituitary sits in the sella turcica and is supplied by the superior and inferior hypophyseal arteries. Sudden vascular compromise causes rapid intrasellar expansion against the rigid bony walls, leading to severe headache, visual field defects from optic chiasm compression, cranial nerve palsies via cavernous sinus involvement, and acute hypopituitarism (especially adrenal insufficiency). Recognizing a secondary headache from sellar pathology hinges on integrating neuroanatomy (sella turcica, cavernous sinus) with pathophysiology (hemorrhagic infarction).

Evidence-Based Analysis

CT in pituitary apoplexy often reveals a hyperdense sellar mass; MRI is gold standard, showing intrinsic T1 hyperintensity from subacute blood. The European Society of Endocrinology (2019) recommends immediate high-dose glucocorticoids (hydrocortisone 100 mg IV bolus, then 50–100 mg every 6–8 hours) to treat adrenal crisis and reduce edema (Graves et al., 2019; Level B). Neurosurgical decompression is indicated for deteriorating vision or consciousness (Rajasekaran et al., 2019). Early multidisciplinary management (endocrinology, neurosurgery, critical care) improves outcomes.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Migraine
• Reason incorrect: Primary headache with throbbing, unilateral pain, photophobia/phonophobia, no CT abnormalities.
• Common misconception: Equating any severe headache with migraine.
• Key differentiator: Imaging in migraine is normal; pituitary hemorrhage produces hyperdensity on CT.

C. Tension headache
• Reason incorrect: Bilateral, pressure-like pain of mild–moderate intensity, no focal deficits or imaging findings.
• Common misconception: Attributing severe headache without obvious stroke signs to tension type.
• Key differentiator: No acute vascular event on imaging; no endocrine or neuro-ophthalmic signs.

D. Cluster headache
• Reason incorrect: Recurrent, severe unilateral periorbital pain lasting 15–180 minutes with ipsilateral lacrimation and nasal congestion, normal imaging.
• Common misconception: Associating orbital pain alone with cluster headache.
• Key differentiator: Presence of autonomic features and circadian pattern; absence of sellar hemorrhage and hypopituitarism.

Comparison Table

FeaturePituitary ApoplexyMigraineTension HeadacheCluster Headache
OnsetSudden (<1 h)Gradual (minutes–hours)Gradual (hours)Abrupt (minutes)
ImagingHyperdense sellar lesion on CT; T1 hyperintense on MRINormalNormalNormal
Pain LocalizationFrontal/retro-orbitalUnilateral frontotemporalBilateral, band-likeUnilateral periorbital
Neuro-ophthalmic SignsOphthalmoplegia, visual field defects, hypopituitarismPhotophobia/phonophobia, auraNoneNone (autonomic signs only)
Autonomic FeaturesPossible cranial nerve palsies, cortisol deficiencyNoNoLacrimation, nasal congestion

Clinical Pearls

• Always perform detailed visual field testing; bitemporal hemianopsia suggests chiasmal compression.
• MRI of the pituitary with dedicated sellar sequences is more sensitive than CT for detecting hemorrhagic infarcts.
• Early high-dose glucocorticoid therapy can be lifesaving by preventing adrenal crisis.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

• Misdiagnosing apoplexy as migraine delays critical steroid administration.
• Failing to assess pituitary hormones overlooks acute cortisol deficiency, risking cardiovascular collapse.
• Relying solely on CT; small hemorrhages may be missed without MRI.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

• European Society of Endocrinology Clinical Practice Guidelines (2019): Immediate empirical glucocorticoids (hydrocortisone 100 mg IV bolus, then 50–100 mg q6–8 h) in suspected apoplexy (Level B).
• Pituitary Society Consensus Statement (2020): Urgent sellar MRI within 24 h and full endocrine panel; neurosurgery if visual or neurological deficits persist (Level C).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

The pituitary gland resides in the sella turcica, bordered laterally by the cavernous sinuses. Hemorrhage expands the gland upward to compress the optic chiasm and laterally to impinge cranial nerves III–VI, causing ophthalmoplegia.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Pituitary apoplexy arises when an adenoma outgrows its blood supply (ischemic necrosis) or a vessel within the tumor ruptures (hemorrhage), abruptly increasing intrasellar pressure and triggering neurological and endocrine crises.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical suspicion in sudden severe headache ± visual/ophthalmoplegic signs.
2. Non-contrast CT head; proceed to dedicated pituitary MRI if CT is inconclusive.
3. Serum cortisol, thyroid, and pituitary hormone evaluation.
4. Initiate high-dose IV glucocorticoids immediately.
5. Neurosurgical consultation for decompression if visual or neurological deficits are present.

Neuroimaging Pearls

CT hyperdensity in the sella turcica suggests hemorrhage; MRI T1 hyperintensity confirms subacute blood, while T2 sequences reveal surrounding edema and infarction.

Pharmacotherapy Focus

Hydrocortisone 100 mg IV bolus, then 50–100 mg every 6–8 hours; taper based on endocrine function. Address secondary hypothyroidism and vasopressor support as needed.

Board Examination Focus

Pituitary apoplexy is frequently tested as an acute secondary headache syndrome with neuro-ophthalmologic and endocrine manifestations requiring prompt steroids and possible surgery. This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam.
